PREFACE
This Village Code of the Village of Worth, as supplemented, contains ordinances
and resolutions up to and including Ordinance 2025-17, passed May 6, 2025, and
Resolution 2025-02, passed March 4, 2025. Ordinances and resolutions of the
Village adopted after said ordinance and resolution supersede the provisions of
this Village Code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent
therewith. Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any
particular provision of the Code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio

RESOLUTION NO. 25 – 08
 
A RESOLUTION ADOPTING THE VILLAGE OF WORTH ZONING FEE SCHEDULE
____________________________________________________________________________
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Worth (“Village”) is an Illinois municipal corporation
organized and operating under the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1, et
seq.) (“Code”); and
WHEREAS, the Code, the Illinois Constitution, and Illinois case law authorize
the Village to require parties seeking zoning approval to pay the costs the
Village incurs reviewing and processing the parties’ plans and applications;
and
WHEREAS , the Village of Worth Municipal Code (“Village Code”) Section 5-2-
6 previously provided the application fees for parties seeking zoning approval;
and
WHEREAS, pursuant to Ordinance No. 25- 24, the Village struck the zoning fees
from Village Code Section 5-2-6; and
WHEREAS, the Village now wishes to provide for zoning fees in a separate fee
schedule to increase efficiency in the administration and amendment of such
fees.
   NOW THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE
VILLAGE OF WORTH, COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS AS FOLLOWS:
 
   Section 1.   RECITALS. The foregoing recitals and all exhibits attached to
this Resolution are incorporated as though fully set forth herein.
Section 2.   FEE SCHEDULED APPROVED. The Village hereby approves the Village of
Worth Zoning Fee Schedule as provided in Exhibit A, which is attached hereto
and incorporated by reference.
Section 3.     AUTHORIZATION. The Village President and Village Clerk are
hereby authorized and directed to undertake any actions as may be necessary or
convenient to enforce this Resolution.
Section 4.   SEVERABILITY. If any part, subsection or clause of this Resolution
is deemed unconstitutional, invalid or otherwise unenforceable by a court of
competent jurisdiction, the remaining sections, subsections, and clauses not
affected thereby shall remain fully valid and enforceable.
Section 5.   EFFECTIVE DATE. This Resolution shall take full force and effect
upon its passage and approval as provided by law.
ADOPTED this 17 day of June, 2025.
 
AYES: Ryan, Urban, Dziedzic, & Packwood
NAYS: (0)
ABSENT: Muersch Jr. and Kats (2)
   
APPROVED by the Village President on June 17, 2025.

Mary Werner, Village President

ORDINANCE NO. 2025-24
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING TITLE 5, CHAPTER 2 OF THE VILLAGE OF WORTH
MUNICIPAL CODE REGARDING ZONING APPLICATION FEES
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Worth (“Village”) is an Illinois municipal corporation
organized and operating under the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1, et
seq.) (“Code”); and
WHEREAS, the Code, the State of Illinois Constitution, and Illinois case law
authorize the Village to require parties seeking zoning approval to pay the
costs the Village incurs reviewing and processing the parties’ plans and
applications; and
WHEREAS , Village of Worth Municipal Code Section 5-2-6 (“Zoning Code”)
currently provides the application fees for parties seeking zoning approval;
and
WHEREAS, the Village now wishes to update the zoning application fee schedule
and relocate the schedule to increase administrative efficiencies; and
WHEREAS, after publishing notice in the Daily Southtown on May 11, 2025, the
Real Estate Development Board (“REDB”) conducted a public hearing on June 2,
2025; and
WHEREAS, at the conclusion of the public hearing, the REDB adopted the findings
attached as Exhibit A and unanimously recommended (7-0) that the Board of
Trustees approve the proposed amendment to Title 5 to update and relocate the
fee schedule, all as set forth in this Ordinance; and
WHEREAS, the Village President and Board of Trustees find that amending the
Zoning Code pursuant to the REDB’s findings and recommendation and in
accordance with this Ordinance is in the Village’s best interests and will
promote the public health, safety, and welfare by enhancing the Village’s
ability to efficiently administer and amend zoning application fees.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
Section 1.    RECITALS. The foregoing recitals are hereby incorporated as
though full set forth in this Section 1.
Section 2.    SECTION AMENDED. The following amendments are made to the Zoning
Code Section 5-2-6 (additions underlined, deletions struck through):
5-2-6: APPLICATIONS AND FEES:
 
*         *         *
 
D. Application Fee Schedule: In addition to the fees authorized by subsection F
of this section, a fee payable to the village clerk by certified check shall
accompany an application form for an appeal, variation, amendment, special use,
zoning certificate, or occupancy permit as provided in the Village of Worth
Zoning Fee Schedule. follows:

     a. Fence variation                          10.00
     b. Garage variation                         15.00
 
E.   Intent Of Application Fees: The application fees established by this
section and the Village of Worth Zoning Fee Schedule are intended to cover the
expenses that may be incurred due to initial staff time required to process
such application, and other expenses such as printing and publication of
notices, postage, and other administrative costs. The applicable
application fee is payable at the time of filing of an application.
 
*         *         *
 
J.  Intentionally left blank.  Court Reporter Fee: Prior to any hearing, an
applicant must pay a minimum fee of one hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00)
payable to the village clerk by certified check to secure the services and
appearance of a court reporter. The village clerk shall then procure the
services of a court reporter for the hearing. An applicant shall pay any
additional appearance fee required of the court reporter that is based upon the
length of the hearing. An applicant shall also be responsible for costs of
transcribing the hearing if a transcript is so desired and shall pay the court
reporter directly for such costs.
 
K.   Liability For Fees: The owner of the property that is the subject of an
application and the applicant, if different, shall be jointly and severally
liable for the payment of any fees required by this section and the Village of
Worth Zoning Fee Schedule. By signing an application, the owner shall be deemed
to have agreed to pay such fees and to consent to the filing and foreclosure of
a lien on the subject property to ensure collection of any such fees, plus the
costs of collection, in the event such fees have not been properly paid as
required. Any lien filed pursuant to this subsection may be foreclosed in the
manner provided by statute for mortgages or mechanics' liens.
 
L.   Condition Of All Applications, Approvals, And Permits; Time Periods: No
application filed pursuant to this code shall be considered complete unless and
until all fees due pursuant to this section and the Village of Worth Zoning Fee
Schedule are paid. Every approval granted and every permit issued pursuant to
this code, whether or not expressly so conditioned, shall be deemed to be
conditioned upon payment of the fees required by this section and the Village
of Worth Zoning Fee Schedule.
 
*         *         *
 
Q.   Withdrawal Of Application: An applicant may withdraw an application at any
time prior to a final decision having been rendered with respect thereto,
provided that the applicant shall have paid all applicable fees pursuant to
this section and the Village of Worth Zoning Fee Schedule. Such withdrawal
shall be without prejudice to the applicant's right to refile such application,
but any such refiling shall be treated as an entirely new filing and shall be
subject to the procedures and fees of this code in the same manner as any other
new application.
 
   R.   Copy Of The Village Zoning Map: An applicant requesting a zoning map
shall pay a fee as provided in the Village of Worth Zoning Fee Schedule of five
dollars ($5.00) for black and white, ten dollars ($10.00) for color .
 
Section 3.   SUPERSEDER. In the event a conflict exists between the terms of
this Ordinance and any other ordinance or resolution of the Village, the terms
of this Ordinance shall govern.
   Section 4.    EFFECTIVE DATE. This Ordinance shall be in full force and
effect from and after its passage and publication in pamphlet form, in
accordance with law, and the provisions of the Zoning Code amended herein shall
be reprinted with the changes.
Passed by the Village President and Village Trustees this 17 day of June, 2025,
on a roll call vote as follows:
PASSED this 17 day of June, 2025

EXHIBIT A
 
VILLAGE OF WORTH REAL ESTATE DEVELOPMENT BOARD
FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATION FOR A TEXT AMENDMENT TO VILLAGE OF THE WORTH
MUNICIPAL CODE TITLE 5, CHAPTER 2 CONCERNING ZONING APPLICATION FEES
 
On June 2, 2025, the Village of Worth Real Estate Development Board (“REDB”)
conducted a public hearing to consider amending Village of Worth Municipal Code
Title 5, Chapter 2 to relocate the zoning application fee schedule outside of
the Village Zoning Code. Notice of the public hearing was published in the
Daily Southtown on May 11, 2025. The Village of Worth (“Applicant”) initiated
the proposed amendment.
 
At the public hearing, the Village Attorney on behalf of the Applicant. The
Applicant explained that the Village of Worth’s (“ Village ”) zoning
application fees are currently located within the Village Zoning Code.
Therefore, every time the Village desires to amend its zoning application fees,
the Village must pay for the publication of a notice of a public hearing and
the REDB must convene a public hearing to adopt the new application fees. The
current procedure to amend zoning application fees is a burden on Village
resources. By relocating the zoning application fees outside of the Village
Zoning Code, the Village can increase its administrative efficiency to amend
such fees.
 
The REDB considered all evidence presented and all other relevant information
before closing the public hearing and discussing the proposed amendment.
 
I.    Findings
 
Based on the evidence presented at the public hearing, the REDB’s discussion,
and all other relevant information, the REDB made the following findings
concerning the proposed text amendment:
 
1)   The proposed amendment is in the public interest. The Village’s zoning
application fees are currently in the Village Zoning Code, which requires any
proposed amendment first be approved by the REDB. The Village must expend its
funds to publish notice of the REDB hearing, and the REDB must convene a public
hearing for the proposed amendment. The current process is inefficient and is a
burden on Village resources. Revising the zoning application fees to be located
outside of the Village Zoning Code will increase Village efficiency and will
decrease administrative burdens.
 
2)   The proposed amendment promotes the public health, safety, and welfare by
allowing the Village to dedicate its funds and resources to services beneficial
for the public rather than dedicating Village resources to REDB hearings for
amendments to the Village’s zoning application fees. Further, relocating the
zoning application fees permits the Village to update such fees more
efficiently to reflect current best practices.
 
 
 
II.   Recommendation
 
Based on the foregoing findings and all evidence entered into the record at the
public hearing held on June 2, 2025, the Real Estate Development Board (7 - 0)
recommends the Village Board approve the proposed amendments to Zoning Code.
ORDINANCE NO. 2025 -25
AN ORDINANCE APPROVING A SPECIAL USE PERMIT TO ESTABLISH AND OPERATE A
FINANCIAL SERVICES OFFICE AT 11403 S. HARLEM AVENUE, WORTH, ILLINOIS
 
   WHEREAS, the Village of Worth (“Village”) is an Illinois municipal
corporation organized and operating under the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS
5/1, et seq.; and
   WHEREAS, 11401-07 S Harlem Ave LLC, an Illinois limited liability company
with offices located at 30 Orland Square Drive, Orland Park, Illinois
(“Owner”), owns the property commonly known as 11403 S. Harlem Avenue, Worth,
Illinois, legally described in Exhibit A (“Property”); and
   WHEREAS, the Owner and Senan Shaqdeh (collectively, “Applicant”), submitted
an application seeking special use permit approval to establish a financial
services office on the Property (“Proposed Use”); and
WHEREAS, Worth Village Code Section 5-6A-3 allows business offices as a special
use in the B1 Restricted Retail Business Zoning District, and the Property is
located in the B1 Zoning District; and
   WHEREAS, the Village published notice in the Daily Southtown on May 11,
2025, and the Real Estate Development Board (“REDB”) conducted a public hearing
on June 2, 2025; and
   WHEREAS, at the conclusion of the public hearing, the REDB made findings
pursuant to Section 5-2-10(D) of the Village Code, attached to this Ordinance
as Exhibit B, and recommended by a vote of 7-0 that the President and Village
Board approve the Applicant’s special use permit request for the Proposed Use;
and
   WHEREAS, the President and Village Board received and reviewed the REDB’s
findings and recommendation, concur with and adopt the REDB’s findings, and
find that the Proposed Use satisfies the special use criteria found in Section
5-2-10(D) of the Worth Municipal Code;
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
   Section 1. RECITALS. The foregoing recitals and all exhibits attached to
this Ordinance are incorporated as though fully set forth herein.
Section 2. SPECIAL USE PERMIT GRANTED. The Applicant’s special use permit
request to establish a financial services office on the Property is granted,
subject to this Ordinance’s terms and conditions.
Section 3. COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAWS AND CONDITIONS.  The establishment,
development, use, operation, and maintenance of the Proposed Use will strictly
conform to all applicable Village, county, state and federal codes, statutes,
ordinances, rules and regulations, as amended.
Section 4. BUILDING PERMITS AND PLANS. The Applicant must submit all permit
applications, building plans, construction drawings, and revisions thereto as
required by the Village before making any improvements, modifications, or
changes to the Property. Any modifications to the Property that are
inconsistent with the plans presented to the Village at the time this Ordinance
was approved shall require the Village’s approval of an amendment to the
special use permit.
Section 5. OCCUPANCY PERMIT. The Applicant may not establish or operate the
Proposed Use until applying for and receiving an occupancy permit from the
Village in accordance with the Village’s ordinances, rules, and regulations, as
amended.
Section 6. SIGN PERMIT. Before erecting or posting any sign on the Property,
the Applicant must file an application for a sign permit in accordance with the
Village’s ordinances, rules, and regulations, as amended, and receive the
Village’s approval of the same.
Section 7. COMMENCEMENT OF SPECIAL USE. By no later than June 16, 2026, the
Applicant shall: (i) obtain all necessary Village, local and state permits and
approvals required to improve the Property to accommodate the Proposed Use;
(ii) complete all necessary improvements to the Property; and (iii) obtain all
Village, local and state certificates, licenses and permissions necessary to
establish, operate and maintain the Proposed Use on the Property.
Section 8. COMPLIANCE WITH CONDITIONS. Upon failure or refusal of the Applicant
to comply with the conditions, restrictions, or provisions of this Ordinance,
the special use permit granted in Section 2 of this Ordinance will, at the sole
discretion of the Board of Trustees, by ordinance duly adopted, be revoked and
become null and void; provided, however, that the Board of Trustees will not
revoke the special use permit unless it first provides the Applicant with 60
days advance written notice of the reasons for revocation and an opportunity to
be heard at a regular meeting of the Board of Trustees. In the event of
revocation, the development and use of the Property will be governed solely by
the regulations of the B1 Zoning District, as amended. Further, in the event of
revocation, the Village Attorney is authorized and directed to bring all zoning
enforcement action as may be appropriate under the circumstances. The Applicant
acknowledges that public notices and hearings have been held with respect to
the adoption of this Ordinance, has considered the possibility of the
revocation provided for in this Section 8, and agrees not to challenge any
revocation on the grounds of any procedural infirmity or any denial of any
procedural right, provided that the notice to the Applicant required by this
Section is given.
Section 9. BINDING EFFECT; NON-TRANSFERABILITY. The privileges, obligations,
and provisions of each and every section of this Ordinance are for the sole
benefit of, and will be binding on, the Applicant, except as otherwise
expressly provided in this Ordinance. Nothing in this Ordinance will be deemed
to allow this Ordinance to be transferred to any person or entity without that
person or entity first applying for and receiving the Village’s approval of a
new application for a special use permit.
Section 10. EFFECTIVE DATE.
A.   This Ordinance will be effective upon occurrence of the following events:
   i.   Passage by the Board of Trustees in the manner required by law;
 
ii.   Publication of this Ordinance in pamphlet form in the manner required by
law;
 
iii.   The Applicant filing with the Village Clerk the Unconditional Agreement
and Consent attached to this Ordinance as Exhibit C and, by this reference,
made a part of this Ordinance; and
 
iv.   The recording of this Ordinance in the Office of the Cook County Clerk,
Recordings Division. The Applicant will bear the full cost of recording.
 
   B.   In the event the Applicant does not file with the Village Clerk a fully
executed copy of the Unconditional Agreement and Consent identified in Section
10(A)(iii) of this Ordinance within 90 days of the date of passage of this
Ordinance by the Board of Trustees, the Board of Trustees will have the right,
in their sole discretion, to declare this Ordinance null and void and of no
force or effect.
Section 11. SUPERSEDER. In the event a conflict exists between the terms of
this Ordinance and any other ordinance or resolution of the Village, the terms
of this Ordinance shall govern.
   
 
on a roll call vote as follows:

Exhibit B
 
VILLAGE OF WORTH REAL ESTATE DEVELOPMENT BOARD
FINDINGS FOR A SPECIAL USE PERMIT FOR
A FINANCIAL SERVICES OFFICE
LOCATED AT 11403 S. HARLEM AVENUE, WORTH, ILLINOIS
 
On Monday, June 2, 2025, the Village of Worth Real Estate Development Board (“
REDB ”) conducted a public hearing to consider a request for a special use
permit to establish a financial services office on the property located at
11403 S. Harlem Avenue, Worth, Illinois (“ Property ”). The Property is located
in the B1 Restricted Retail Business Zoning District. Notice of the public
hearing was published in the Daily Southtown on May 11, 2025. The special use
permit was proposed by Senan Shaqdeh with the consent of the Property’s owner,
11401-07 S Harlem Ave LLC (collectively, “ Applicant ”).
 
At the public hearing, Senan Shaqdeh spoke on behalf of the Applicant. The
Applicant proposes to open and operate a financial services office in a tenant
space containing 810 square feet. No more than 2 employees will work at the
Property at any one time. The proposed hours of operation are from 9 a.m. to 10
p.m. daily, with peak hours between 9 a.m. and 6 p.m. The Property was
previously occupied by a travel agency.
 
REDB members heard testimony concerning the proposed use and questioned the
Applicant about his plans. The REDB considered all evidence presented and all
other relevant information before closing the public hearing and discussing the
proposed special use.
 
I.    Findings
 
Based on the evidence presented at the public hearing, the REDB’s discussion,
and all other relevant information, the REDB makes the following findings
concerning the proposed special use in accordance with Section 5-2-10 of the
Worth Village Code:
 
   a.   The establishment, maintenance, or operation of the special use will
not be detrimental to or endanger the public health, safety, morals, comfort,
or general welfare.
 
The Applicant proposes to occupy the tenant space with a business that is
consistent with the previous business that occupied the space. The Property was
occupied by a business office (travel agency) for the last +/-4 years. The
Applicant proposes to continue to offer a service use in a location that is
convenient for those living and working in the Village. Harlem Avenue is one of
the Village’s primary commercial thoroughfares.
 
   b.   The special use will not be injurious to the use and enjoyment of other
property in the immediate vicinity for the purposes already permitted, nor
substantially diminish and impair property values within the neighborhood.
 
The proposed office will be located in an existing multitenant structure. The
structure is occupied by a variety of other uses, including a restaurant, a
barber, and a beauty salon. The proposed use is low intensity; no more than 2
employees are anticipated to work at the property at any time. Traffic,
parking, and other potential impacts are expected to be minor. Establishing a
viable business office on the Property will increase the Property’s
productivity and attract potential customers to other businesses located in the
Harlem Avenue corridor.
 
   c.   The establishment of the special use will not impede the normal and
orderly development and improvement of the surrounding property for uses
permitted in the district.
 
The proposed business office will occupy what would otherwise be a vacant
tenant space in a multitenant structure. The tenant space was previously
occupied by a travel agency, and office and commercial uses currently occupy
nearby tenant spaces and much of the Harlem Avenue corridor. The proposed use
is consistent with and complimentary to existing uses located in the area.
 
   d.   Adequate utilities, access roads, drainage and/or necessary facilities
have been or are being provided.
 
The Property’s existing facilities are sufficient to serve the proposed use.
The Property is improved with a mixed-use structure and a parking lot. Vehicles
can access the Property from 114th Street. The Applicant does not propose any
substantive changes to the Property’s exterior.
 
   e.   Adequate measures have been or will be taken to provide ingress and
egress so designed as to minimize traffic congestion in the public streets.
 
The Property has frontage on Harlem Avenue. Vehicles seeking to access the
Property will rely primarily on 114th Street, and the proposed office is not
expected to generate extraordinary traffic congestion. The proposed office use
is comparable in intensity to other low intensity offices occupying other
tenant spaces in the area.
 
   f.   The special use shall, in all other respects, conform to the applicable
regulations of the district in which it is located, except as such regulations
may, in each instance, be modified by the president and village board pursuant
to the recommendations of the real estate development board, or as allowed for
planned developments.
 
The Applicant proposes to comply with all Village requirements applicable to
the Property and the proposed use, other than the Village’s off-street parking
requirement. The findings from the ordinance approving a parking variance for
the proposed use are incorporated by reference into this section.
 
 
 
 
II.   Recommendation
 
Based on the foregoing findings and all evidence entered into the record at the
June 2, 2025 public hearing, the Real Estate Development Board considered a
motion to recommend approval of the special use permit to operate a financial
services office on the Property. The motion carried (7-0).
 
 
Exhibit C
 
UNCONDITIONAL AGREEMENT AND CONSENT
 
TO:   The Village of Worth, Illinois (“Village”)
 
WHEREAS, 11401-07 S Harlem Ave LLC, an Illinois limited liability company with
offices located at 30 Orland Square Drive, Orland Park, Illinois (“Owner”) owns
certain property commonly known as 11403 S. Harlem Avenue, Worth, Illinois,
legally described on Exhibit 1 (“Property”); and
 
WHEREAS, the Owner and Senan Shaqdeh (collectively, “Applicant”), have sought
approval of a special use permit to develop, operate, and maintain the Property
as a financial services office (“Zoning Relief”); and
 
WHEREAS, Ordinance No. 2025 - 25, adopted by Board of Trustees of the Village
on July 1, 2025, grants approval of such Zoning Relief, subject to certain
conditions (“Ordinance”); and
 
   WHEREAS, the Applicant desires to evidence to the Village its unconditional
agreement and consent to accept and abide by each of the terms, conditions, and
limitations set forth in the Ordinance.
 
   NOW THEREFORE, the Applicant does hereby agree and covenant as follows:
 
1.   The Applicant hereby unconditionally agrees to accept, consent to and
abide by all terms, conditions, restrictions, and provisions of the Ordinance.
 
2.   The Applicant acknowledges and agrees that the Village will not be, in any
way, liable for any damages or injuries that may be sustained as a result of
the Village’s review and approval of any plans for the Property, or the
issuance of any permits for the use and development of the Property, and that
the Village’s review and approval of any such plans and issuance of any such
permits does not, and will not, in any way, be deemed to insure the Applicant
against any damage or injury of any kind and at any time.
 
3.   The Applicant acknowledges that the public notices and hearings have been
properly given and held with respect to the adoption of the Ordinance, has
considered the possibility of the revocation provided for in the Ordinance, and
agrees not to challenge any such revocation on the grounds of any procedural
infirmity or any denial of any procedural right, provided that the notice to
the Applicant required by Section 8 of the Ordinance is given.
 
4.   The Applicant agrees to and does hereby hold harmless and indemnify the
Village, the Village’s elected and appointed officials, officers, employees,
contractors, agents, representatives, volunteers, and attorneys, from any and
all claims that may, at any time, be asserted against any of such parties in
connection with (a) the Village’s review and approval of any plans and issuance
of any permits, (b) the procedures followed in connection with the adoption of
the Ordinance, (c) the development, construction, maintenance, and use of the
Property, and (d) the performance of the Applicant of their obligations under
this Unconditional Agreement and Consent.
 
5.   The Applicant hereby agrees to pay all expenses incurred by the Village in
defending itself with regard to any and all claims, demands, investigations,
and suits related to, associated with, or arising from the Property, the Zoning
Relief, the Ordinance, or this Unconditional Agreement and Consent. These
expenses will include all out of pocket expenses, such as attorneys’ and
experts’ fees, and will also include the reasonable value of any services
rendered by any employee of the Village.
 
6.   The restrictions imposed by this Unconditional Agreement and Consent shall
be restrictions running with the land and shall be binding upon and inure to
the benefit of the Applicant and its heirs, successors, assigns, agents,
licensees, lessees, invitees, and representatives, including, without
limitation, all subsequent owners of the Property, or any portion thereof, and
all persons claiming under them to the extent provided in this Unconditional
Agreement and Consent. If any of the privileges or rights created by this
Unconditional Agreement and Consent would otherwise be unlawful or void for
violation of (1) the rule against perpetuities or some analogous statutory
provision, (2) the rule restricting restraints on alienation, or (3) any other
statutory or common law rules imposing time limits, then the affected privilege
or right shall continue only until 21 years after the death of the last
survivor of the now living lawful descendants of the Joseph R. Biden, Jr.,
President of the United States of America, or for any shorter period that may
be required to sustain the validity of the affected privilege or right.
 
7.    This Unconditional Agreement and Consent may not be amended, modified,
released or annulled except upon the express, prior written approval of the
Village of Worth.
 
8.   The parties comprising the Applicant are jointly and severally liable for
all obligations and duties imposed upon the Applicant by this Unconditional
Agreement and Consent.

ORDINANCE NO. 2025-26
AN ORDINANCE GRANTING A VARIANCE TO VILLAGE OF WORTH MUNICIPAL CODE SECTION 5-
9-6(K)(3) TO REDUCE THE REQUIRED NUMBER OF VEHICLE PARKING SPACES FOR A
FINANCIAL SERVICES OFFICE LOCATED AT
11403 S. HARLEM AVENUE, WORTH, ILLINOIS
 
   WHEREAS, 11401-07 S Harlem Ave LLC, an Illinois limited liability company
with offices located at 30 Orland Square Drive, Orland Park, Illinois
(“Owner”), owns the property commonly known as 11403 S. Harlem Avenue, Worth,
Illinois, legally described in Exhibit A (“Property”); and
WHEREAS, the Property has long been occupied by a multi-tenant commercial
structure; and
WHEREAS, Senan Shaqdeh and the Owner (collectively, “Applicant”) have
petitioned the Village of Worth (“Village”) for approval of a variance to
Section 5-9-6 of the Worth Municipal Code (“Zoning Code”) to reduce the
required number of vehicle parking spaces for a financial services office that
wishes to occupy an 810 square foot tenant space located on the Property
(“Proposed Use”); and
WHEREAS, Zoning Code Section 5-9-6(K)(3) requires business offices to provide 1
parking space for each 400 gross square feet of floor area; and
WHEREAS, the Zoning Code requires the Proposed Use to provide 2 off-street
parking spaces; and
WHEREAS, the Property contains 17 parking spaces, 16 of which are required to
serve other tenants currently occupying the Property; and
WHEREAS, after publishing notice in the Daily Southtown on May 11, 2025, the
Village of Worth Real Estate Development Board (“REDB”) conducted a public
hearing on June 2, 2025 to consider the Applicant’s variance request; and
WHEREAS, at the conclusion of the hearing, the REDB recommended that the
Village Board approve the Applicant’s variance request by a vote of 7 – 0; and
WHEREAS, Worth Municipal Code Section 5-2-8(D) authorizes the Village Board to
approve variances to the Worth Municipal Code; and
WHEREAS, the Village Board finds that it is in the best interests of the
Village to approve the requested variance;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
Section 1. RECITALS. The foregoing recitals and all exhibits attached to this
Ordinance are incorporated as though fully set forth herein.
Section 2.   FINDINGS OF FACT. The REDB’s findings from the June 2, 2025
meeting attached as Exhibit B are approved and adopted
Section 3. VARIANCE APPROVED. Subject to the conditions set forth in Section 4,
the Village Board approves a variance to Code Section 5-9-6(K)(3) to reduce the
required number of parking spaces for a jewelry store located on the Property
from 2 parking spaces to 1 parking space.
Section 4. CONDITIONS. The approval granted in Ordinance Section 3 shall be and
is hereby expressly subject to and contingent upon each of the following terms,
conditions, and restrictions, the violation of any of which shall, in the sole
discretion of the Village Board, invalidate the approvals granted in this
Ordinance.
A.   No Authorization of Work. This Ordinance does not authorize commencement
of any work on the Property. Except as otherwise specifically approved in
writing in advance by the Village, no work of any kind shall be commenced on
the Property pursuant to the approvals granted in this Ordinance unless and
until all conditions of this Ordinance precedent to such work have been
fulfilled, including, without limitation, after all permits, approvals, and
other authorizations for such work have been properly applied for, paid for,
and granted in accordance with applicable law.
B.   Compliance with Laws. The Code and all other applicable Village
ordinances, rules, and regulations shall continue to apply to the Property, and
the development and use of the Property must comply with all laws, rules, and
regulations of all federal, state, and other governmental bodies and agencies
having jurisdiction over the Property.
C.   Compliance with Plans. The development, maintenance, and operation of the
Property will be in substantial conformance with the plans presented to the
Village Board during consideration of this Ordinance.
D.   Recording. The Applicant consents to and agrees, upon demand, to pay the
full cost of recording a certified copy of this Ordinance with the Cook County
Clerk, Recordings Division.
Section 5. BINDING EFFECT. This Ordinance and the privileges, obligations, and
provisions contained herein shall inure solely to the benefit of and be binding
upon the Applicant and any and all of its heirs, successors, and assigns, and
upon any and all current and successor legal or beneficial owners of all or any
portion of the Property.
Section 6. SUPERSEDER. All ordinances, resolutions, motions, or orders in
conflict herewith are repealed to the extent of such conflict.
   Section 7. SEVERABILITY. Every section and provision of this Ordinance shall
be severable, and the invalidity of any portion of this Ordinance shall not
affect the validity of any other portion of this Ordinance. If any part of this
Ordinance is found to be invalid in any one or more of its several
applications, all valid applications shall remain in effect.
Section 8. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect
from and after its passage and publication in pamphlet form, in accordance with
law; provided, however, this Ordinance shall be of no force or effect unless
and until the Applicant has executed and filed with the Village its
unconditional agreement and consent, in the form attached to this Ordinance as
Exhibit C, within 30 days following the passage of this Ordinance. Upon this
Ordinance having full force and effect, the Village Clerk shall cause it to be
recorded with the Cook County Clerk, Recordings Division.

LOTS 72, 73, AND 74 IN ARTHUR DUNAS’ HARLEM AVENUE ADDITION UNIT NO. 3, BEING A

Exhibit B
 
Real Estate Development Board’s Findings from June 2, 2025 Meeting
 
A.   Reasonable Return: The Property cannot yield a reasonable return if
permitted to be used only under the conditions allowed by the zoning
regulations. The Property’s parking lot contains insufficient capacity to
accommodate most new tenants. The Zoning Code requires the Property to provide
16 parking spaces to accommodate the existing uses, leaving only 1 parking
space remaining to serve the tenant space at issue. Accordingly, the Village
must approve a parking variance before nearly any tenant could occupy the
Property. The Property also lacks room to construct additional parking spaces.
The cost of retrofitting the Property to comply with the current parking
standards would be significant, if such a retrofit is even feasible.
 
B.   Essential Character: Granting the variance will not alter the essential
character of the surrounding neighborhood. The Property is located on Harlem
Avenue, the Village's primary north-south commercial corridor. Many service
uses and retailers operate in the same area. The proposed office is consistent
with the corridor’s existing service-oriented character. Typically no more than
2 employees work at the store at any time, and the size of the tenant space is
limited – only 810 square feet.
 
C.   Unique Circumstances: The Applicant's plight is attributable to unique
circumstances not present elsewhere in the community. The structure located on
the Property was constructed long ago when different parking and code
requirements applied. The Applicant is simply attempting to occupy an existing
building with an economically viable use. Absent variance approval, the tenant
space would likely remain vacant and unproductive. The limited size of the
proposed retail use distinguish the Applicant's variance request from other
such requests.

Unconditional Agreement and Consent

ORDINANCE NO. 2025 - 27
AN ORDINANCE AUTHORIZING THE DISPOSAL OF PERSONAL PROPERTY
 
   WHEREAS, the Village of Worth (“Village”) is an Illinois municipal
corporation organized and operating under the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS
5/1-1-1, et seq.) (“Code”); and
   WHEREAS, the Code (65 ILCS 5/11-76-4) authorizes the Village to dispose of
personal property that the Village determines by a simple majority of the
corporate authorities to be no longer useful and necessary; and
   WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Worth find
that Village ownership of the property described in Exhibit A is no longer
useful or necessary and shall be disposed of as set forth herein;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
   Section 1. RECITALS. The foregoing recitals are incorporated as though fully
set forth herein.
Section 2. DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY. The Village President is authorized to
dispose of the personal property described on Exhibit A in such manner as the
Village President determines to be in the best interests of the Village, with
or without advertising the sale. The Village President may reject any and all
proposals if believed by her to be below the fair market value of the property.
All proposals received by the Village President shall be kept on file with the
Village Clerk, and the Village President is authorized to execute any and all
documents to effectuate the property transfer.
Section 3. SUPERSEDER. In the event a conflict exists between the terms of this
Ordinance and any other ordinance or resolution of the Village, the terms of
this Ordinance shall govern.
   Section 4.  EFFECTIVE DATE. This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect
from and after its passage and publication in pamphlet form, in accordance with
law.

Published in pamphlet form by authority of the Village Board of the Village of
Worth, Cook County, Illinois, this 1 day of July , 2025.
VILLAGE OF WORTH
COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
ORDINANCE NO. 2025- 29
 
AN ORDINANCE IMPLEMENTING A MUNICIPAL GROCERY RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX AND A
MUNIICPAL GROCERY SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX
 
   WHEREAS, the Village of Worth (“Village”) is an Illinois municipal
corporation  organized and existing under the Constitution and laws of the
State of Illinois; and
   WHEREAS, the Illinois Municipal Code (“Code”) authorizes all Illinois
municipalities beginning on January 1, 2026 to impose a tax upon all persons
engaged in the business of selling groceries at retail in the municipality (“
(65 ILCS 5/8-11-24); and
   WHEREAS, the Code requires any municipality imposing the Municipal Grocery
Retailers’ Occupation Tax under 65 ILCS 5/8-11-24 to also impose a service
occupation tax at the same rate upon all all persons engaged, in the
municipality, in the business of making sales of service, who, as an incident
to making those sales of service, transfer groceries (“Municipal Grocery
Service Occupation Tax”) (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24); and
   WHEREAS, the Municipal Grocery Retailers’ Occupation Tax and Municipal
Grocery Service Occupation Tax (collectively, “Municipal Grocery Taxes”) are
administered, collected, and enforced by the Illinois Department of Revenue;
and
   WHEREAS, the Village finds that approving this Ordinance levying the
Municipal Grocery Taxes as authorized by Section 8-11-24 of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24) is desirable and in the best interests of
the public health, safety, and welfare of the Village and its residents.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
   Section 1.    RECITALS. The foregoing recitals are incorporated into this
Section 1 as though fully set forth herein.
Section 2.    SECTION AMENDED.  Title 3, Chapter 2 of the Village of Worth
Municipal Code is hereby amended with the addition of Section 3-2-7 “Municipal
Grocery Retailers' Occupation Tax and Municipal Grocery Service Occupation Tax”
as follows (additions double-underlined):
3-2-7: MUNICIPAL GROCERY RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX AND
MUNICIPAL GROCERY SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
 
A. Tax imposed: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the
business of selling groceries, as defined in the Municipal Grocery Occupation
Tax Law, at retail in the village at the rate of 1% of the gross receipts from
such sales made in the course of such business while this Ordinance is in
effect; and a tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the village in
the business of making sales of service, at the rate of 1% of the selling price
of all groceries, as defined in the Municipal Grocery Occupation Tax Law,
transferred by such serviceman as an incident to a sale of service. The
imposition of these taxes is in accordance with and subject to the provisions
of the Municipal Grocery Occupation Tax Law (65 ILCS 5/8-11-24).
 
B. The taxes imposed by this section, and all civil penalties that may be
assessed as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the
Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois. The Department of Revenue shall
have full power to administer and enforce the provisions of this Ordinance.
 
Section 3.    AUTHORIZATION. The Village Clerk is hereby authorized and
directed to file a certified copy of this Ordinance with the Illinois
Department of Revenue on or before October 1, 2025.
 
Section 4.    CONFLICT. All ordinances, resolutions, or parts thereof in
conflict with this Ordinance are hereby repealed to the extent necessary to
give effect to the provisions of this Ordinance.
Section 5.    SUPERSEDER. In the event a conflict exists between the terms of
this Ordinance and any other ordinance or resolution of the Village, the terms
of this Ordinance shall govern.
Section 6.    SEVERABILITY. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause,
phrase, or portion of this Ordinance is for any reason held invalid or
unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be
deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall
not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof.
   Section 7.   EFFECTIVE DATE. The taxes imposed by this Ordinance shall take
effect on January 1, 2026, following the adoption and filing of this Ordinance
with the Department of Revenue, if filed on or before October 1, 2025. The
provisions of the Village of Worth Municipal Code amended herein shall be
reprinted with the changes.
 
 
 
[signature page follows]
 
 
 
 
 
Passed by the Village President and Village Trustees, this 1 day of July 2025,
by the following roll-call vote:
AYES: Ryan, Kats, Muersch Jr., Urban, Dziedzic, & Packwood (6)
NAYS: (0)
ABSENT: (0)
 
Approved by the Village President on July 1, 2025.
 
 
 
____________________________
Mary Werner, Village President               
 
 
ATTEST:
 
 
 
____________________________
Bonnie Price, Village Clerk

VILLAGE OF WORTH,
COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
ORDINANCE NO. 2025 - 33
 
AN ORDINANCE APPROVING A PROFESSIONAL SERVICES AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE VILLAGE OF
WORTH AND RATHS, RATHS, & JOHNSON, INC. TO PERFORM PROFESSIONAL STRUCTURAL
ENGINEERING SERVICES AT THE VILLAGE OF WORTH FIRE STATION LOCATED AT 7112 W.
111TH STREET, WORTH, ILLINOIS
 
   WHEREAS, the Village of Worth (“ Village ”) is a municipal corporation
lawfully organized and existing under the Constitution and laws of the State of
Illinois, including, without limitation, the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS
5/1, et seq.) (“ Code ”); and
   WHEREAS, Raths, Raths, & Johnson, Inc. (“ RRJ ”) is an Illinois corporation
providing professional engineering services; and
   WHEREAS, the Village is authorized to enter into contracts, and pass
ordinances pertaining to its governments and affairs (65 ILCS 5/2-3-8; 65 ILCS
5/1-2-1); and
   WHEREAS, the Village owns and operates a fire station located at 7112 W.
111th Street, Worth, Illinois 60482 (“ Property ”); and
   WHEREAS, the Village desires to contract with RRJ to provide professional
structural engineering services for the Village at the Property, subject to the
terms and conditions of the Professional Services Agreement (“ Agreement ”)
between the Village and RRJ, which is attached and incorporated into this
Ordinances as Exhibit 1 ; and
   WHEREAS, the Village wishes to waive the Village purchasing policy requiring
that the Village competitively bid; and
   WHEREAS, the corporate authorities of the Village find that it is necessary
and in the best interests of the health, welfare and safety of the Village and
its residents to approve the Agreement with RRJ.
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
   Section 1.   RECITALS. The foregoing recitals and all exhibits attached to
this Ordinance are incorporated as though fully set forth in this Section 1.
   Section 2.    APPROVAL.   The Agreement, which is attached and incorporated
into this Ordinance as Exhibit 1 is hereby approved, subject to Village
Attorney review.
   Section 3.     AUTHORIZATION.   The Village President and Village Clerk are
authorized and directed to execute the Agreement on the Village’s behalf, and
the Village President is authorized to take all actions necessary to implement
and enforce the Agreement’s terms.
   Section 4.   BIDDING WAIVED.   The Village hereby waives the need to
competitively bid for the services authorized by the Agreement and finds that
doing so is in the Village’s best interest.    
   Section 5.   SUPERSEDER. All ordinances, resolutions, and parts thereof in
conflict with this Ordinance are hereby repealed only to the extent they
conflict with this Ordinance.
Section 6.   SEVERABILITY. If any part, subsection or clause of this Ordinance
is deemed unconstitutional, invalid or otherwise unenforceable by a court of
competent jurisdiction, the remaining sections, subsections, and clauses not
affected thereby shall remain fully valid and enforceable.
   Section 7.   EFFECTIVE DATE. This Ordinance shall be in full force and
effect from and after its passage and approval as provided by law.
   Passed by the Village President and Village Trustees this 6 day of August,
2025, on a roll call vote as follows:
AYES:    Ryan, Kats, Dziedzic, & Packwood (4)
NAYS: (0)
ABSENT: Muersch Jr., and Urban (2)
 
ABSTAIN: (0)
         
Approved by the Village President on August 6, 2025
 
 
 
____________________________
Mary Werner, Village President
 
ATTEST:
                              
 
 
_____________________________
Bonnie Price, Village Clerk

ORDINANCE NO. 2025 - 34
 
AN ORDINANCE APPOINTING A FINANCE DIRECTOR AND APPROVING AN AGREEMENT WITH
WONDERFUL WATSON CONCERNING PROFESSIONAL FINANCIAL SERVICES
 
   WHEREAS, the Village of Worth (“Village”) is a municipal corporation
lawfully organized and existing under the Constitution and laws of the State of
Illinois, including, without limitation, the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS
5/1, et seq.) (“Code”); and
   WHEREAS, the Code (65 ILCS 5/2-2-12) authorizes the Village to enter into
agreements and to take other acts necessary to exercise its statutory powers;
and
   WHEREAS, the Village Code Section 1-9-1 creates the Office of Village
Finance Director and authorizes the Village to appoint an independent
contractor to that office; and
   WHEREAS, in furtherance of its statutory powers, it is necessary for the
Village to contract for various services from time to time; and
   WHEREAS, the Village’s Finance Director position was recently vacated, and
the Village wishes to fill the position with an independent contractor; and
   WHEREAS, Wonderful Watson (“Watson”) submitted a proposal to serve as
Finance Director, and the Village has determined that Watson is suited to serve
in that capacity; and
   WHEREAS, the Village wishes to appoint Watson to the Office of Village
Finance Director and enter into the agreement attached as Exhibit A
(“Agreement”) detailing the terms and conditions of the Village’s relationship
with Watson; and
   WHEREAS, the Village Board finds that approving the Agreement will benefit
and promote the public health, safety, and welfare; and
   WHEREAS, Watson and the Village have reviewed the Agreement and wish to
approve it; and
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
   Section 1.   RECITALS. The foregoing recitals and all exhibits attached to
this Ordinance are incorporated as though fully set forth herein.
   Section 2.    AGREEMENT APPROVED. The Agreement attached as Exhibit A is
hereby approved, subject to Village Attorney review, the Village President and
Village Clerk are authorized and directed to execute the Agreement on the
Village’s behalf, and the Village President is authorized to take all actions
necessary to implement and enforce the Agreement’s terms.
   Section 3.   APPOINTMENT APPROVED. The Village hereby appoints Watson to the
Office of Village Finance Director pursuant to and in accordance with the
Agreement’s terms.
   Section 4.   BIDDING WAIVED. The Village hereby waives the need to obtain
other written quotes for the services Watson proposes to provide and finds that
doing so is in the Village’s best interest, based upon Watson’s relevant
experience and past performance in comparable roles.    
   Section 5.   SUPERSEDER. All ordinances, resolutions, and parts thereof in
conflict with this Ordinance are hereby repealed to the extent and only to the
extent they conflict with this Ordinance.
Section 6.   SEVERABILITY. If any part, subsection or clause of this Ordinance
shall be deemed to be unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, the remaining
sections, subsections and clauses shall not be affected thereby.
   Section 7.   EFFECTIVE DATE. This Ordinance shall be in full force and
effect from and after its passage and approval as provided by law.
   Passed by the Village President and Village Trustees this 6 day of August,
2025, on a roll call vote as follows:

ORDINANCE NO. 2025-31
 
“AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 8-3-6 AND SECTION 10-4-20 OF THE VILLAGE OF
WORTH MUNICIPAL CODE TO MODIFY THE VILLAGE’S NOISE REGULATIONS”
 
______________________________________________________________________________
 
 
 
 
 
PASSED AND APPROVED BY THE
 
PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE
 
VILLAGE OF WORTH
 
THIS 19 DAY OF AUGUST, 2025
 
 
 
 
 
______________________________________________________________________________
Published in pamphlet form by authority of the Village Board of the Village of
Worth, Cook
County, Illinois, this 19 day of August, 2025.
VILLAGE OF WORTH
COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
ORDINANCE NO. 2025-31
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 8-3-6 AND SECTION 10-4-20 OF THE VILLAGE OF WORTH
MUNICIPAL CODE TO MODIFY THE VILLAGE’S NOISE REGULATIONS
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Worth (the “Village”) is an Illinois municipal
corporation organized and operating under the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS
5/1, et seq.) (the “Code”); and
WHEREAS, the Code (65 ILCS 5/11-5-2; 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2) authorizes the Village
to prevent and suppress noises, disturbances, and disorderly assemblies, and to
define, prevent and abate nuisances; and
WHEREAS, the Village’s noise regulations are currently found in Worth Municipal
Code Title 8, Chapter 3 and Title 10, Chapter 4; and
WHEREAS, the Village wishes to consolidate its noise regulations within Title
8, Chapter 3 and amend its noise regulations to improve compliance with such
regulations and to remain consistent with best regulatory practices; and
WHEREAS, the Village President and Board of Trustees find that amending the
Worth Municipal Code in accordance with this Ordinance will promote the public
health, safety, and welfare by establishing regulations to more effectively
regulate and limit noise in the Village;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
Section 1. RECITALS. The foregoing recitals are incorporated as though fully
set forth herein.
Section 2. SECTION DELETED. Worth Municipal Code Section 10-4-20 is deleted in
its entirety and replaced with the following (additions in bold underline and
deletions struck through):
10-4-20: RESERVED  EXCESSIVE NOISE PROHIBITED:
 
A.   It shall be unlawful for any person or any licensee to operate or permit
the operation of any equipment or device that amplifies, creates, or produces
sound so as to generate sound having a sound pressure level greater than fifty
five (55) decibels when measured from within any dwelling unit during the hours
of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
    B.   It shall be unlawful for any person or any licensee to operate or
permit the operation of any equipment or device that amplifies, creates, or
produces sound so as to generate sound having a sound pressure level greater
than eighty (80) decibels when measured at the property line of any property
during the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
    C.   It shall be unlawful for any person or any licensee to operate or
permit the operation of any equipment or device that amplifies, creates, or
produces sound so as to generate sound having a sound pressure level greater
than seventy (70) decibels when measured from within any dwelling unit during
the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
    D.   It shall be unlawful for any person or any licensee to operate or
permit the operation of any equipment or device that amplifies, creates, or
produces sound so as to generate sound having a sound pressure level greater
than ninety five (95) decibels when measured at the property line of any
property during the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00)
P.M.
    E.   The measurement of sound shall be made on a sound level meter and
shall be conducted over a period of not less than two (2) minutes. If there are
at least two (2) readings above the allowed decibel levels, this constitutes a
violation of the applicable subsection above.
Section 3. SECTION AMENDED. The following amendments are made to Section 8-3-
6 of the Worth Municipal Code (additions in bold underline ):
  A.   No person owning or in possession, charge or control of any building or
premises shall use the same, or permit the use of the same, or rent the same to
be used, for any business or employment, or for any purpose of pleasure or
recreation, if such use shall, from its noise or its boisterous nature, disturb
or destroy the peace of the neighborhood in which such building or premises is
situated, or be dangerous or detrimental to health. Such use of any building or
premises is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
    B.   No person shall make or cause, permit or allow to be made any noise of
any kind by crying, calling or shouting or by means of any device for the
purpose of advertising any goods, wares or merchandise, or as part of any
political campaign or for the purpose of attracting the attention or inviting
the patronage of any person to any business whatsoever.
    C.   Except in cases of emergencies or as otherwise provided in this
section, it shall constitute a nuisance for any person to conduct building
construction operations between seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:
00) A.M. (8:00 A.M. on Sundays), or to operate or use any pile drivers, steam
shovels, pneumatic hammers, derricks, steam or electric hoists or other
apparatus, the use of which is attended with loud or unusual noise, in any
block in which more than half of the buildings on either side of the street are
used exclusively for residence purposes. Exceptions to the above time
restrictions are allowed for the maintenance and operation of utilities, public
works projects or mail deliveries authorized by a governmental body, traffic
control systems, the operation of police, emergency, or snow removal vehicles,
the operation of mass transit system, the maintenance and operation of
railways.
  D. It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made any
unreasonably loud, disturbing or raucous noise which annoys, injures, or
endangers the comfort, health, peace or safety of a prudent person under the
circumstances. The regulations set forth in this subsection shall apply in the
Village every day between ten o’clock (10:00) P.M. and seven o’clock (7:00)
A.M. (8:00 A.M. on Sundays). For purposes of this subsection, noise is
unreasonably loud and raucous when it generates sound that is clearly audible
to a person with normal hearing at a distance greater than fifty feet (50').
Loud disturbing or raucous noise may include but is not limited to:
1. Sounding of any vehicle horn or signaling device except as reasonably
necessary to warn of any impending danger;
2. Playing, using, operating, or permitting to be played any sound amplifying
device producing or reproducing a loud and raucous sound to be plainly audible
at a distance of fifty (50') feet from the location of such device. As used
herein sound amplifying device means any device utilizing electric current
which amplifies a musical instrument, tuner, phonograph, magnet tape, any
electronically synthesized sound or the human voice;
3. Any non-amplified disagreeable or annoying sound that unreasonably disturbs
the peace and comfort of occupants of adjacent properties.
Section 4. SUPERSEDER. In the event a conflict exists between the terms of this
Ordinance and any other ordinance or resolution of the Village, the terms of
this Ordinance shall govern.
Section 5. SEVERABILITY. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase,
or portion of this Ordinance is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional
by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a
separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect
the validity of the remaining portions hereof.
Section 6.  EFFECTIVE DATE. This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect
from and after its passage and publication in pamphlet form, in accordance with
law, and the provisions of the Village of Worth Municipal Code amended herein
shall be reprinted with the changes.
Passed by the Village President and Village Trustees this 19 day of August,
2025, on a roll call vote as follows:
PASSED this 19 day of August, 2025
 
AYES: Ryan, Muersch Jr., Kats, Dziedzic, and Packwood (5)
NAYS: (0)
ABSENT: Urban (1)
 
Approved by the Village President on August 19, 2025

Mary Werner, Village President

VILLAGE OF WORTH
COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
ORDINANCE NO. 2025 -36
 
AN ORDINANCE APPROVING AN AMENDMENT TO THE SPECIAL
USE PERMIT APPROVED BY ORDINANCE NO. 2017-47 CONCERNING A RETAIL TOBACCO STORE
LOCATED AT 7011 W. 111TH STREET, WORTH, ILLINOIS
 
   WHEREAS, the Village of Worth (“Village”) is an Illinois municipal
corporation organized and operating under the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS
5/1, et seq.; and
   WHEREAS, on December 19, 2017, the Village Board of Trustees passed
Ordinance No. 2017-47 (“Special Use Ordinance”) approving a special use permit
to allow a retail tobacco store to occupy the property commonly known as 7011
W. 111th Street, Worth, Illinois, which property is legally described in
Exhibit A (“Property”); and
   WHEREAS, among other things, the Special Use Ordinance identified the
Property’s owner as YRR Properties LLC (“Owner”) and the applicant as Tarek
Obaid (“Obaid”) (collectively, Owner and Obaid are the “Applicant”) and
provided that the Special Use Ordinance could not be transferred to another
entity without Village approval of an amendment to the Special Use Ordinance;
and
   WHEREAS, Asam Jaber and Husama Samara (collectively, “Petitioner”) wish to
operate the retail tobacco store authorized by the Special Use Ordinance; and
   WHEREAS, the Village Board has determined that certain requirements in the
Special Use Ordinance are not necessary or beneficial; and
   WHEREAS, notice was published in the Daily Southtown on June 15, 2025, and a
public hearing was convened before the Real Estate Development Board (“REDB”)
on July 7, 2025; and
   WHEREAS, at the conclusion of the public hearing, the REDB made findings
pursuant to Section 5-2-10(D) of the Village Code and recommended denial of the
Petitioner’s request to amend the Special Use Ordinance; and
   WHEREAS, the Village Board received, reviewed, and considered the REDB’s
findings duirng meetings held on July 15, August 6, and August 19, 2025, and
made their own findings concerning the proposed amendment to the Special Use
Oridnance, attached hereto as Exhibit B; and
   WHEREAS, the President and Village Board find that the Petitioner has
satisfied the special use criteria found in Section 5-2-10(D) of the Worth
Municipal Code;
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
   Section 1.   RECITALS. The foregoing recitals and all exhibits attached to
this Ordinance are incorporated as though fully set forth herein.
Section 2.   SPECIAL USE PERMIT TRANSFERRED. Pursuant to Special Use Ordinance
Section 10, the special use is transferred from the Applicant to the
Petitioner, and the Petitioner shall enjoy all rights, duties, and obligations
assigned to the Applicant in the Special Use Ordinance.
Section 3.   VALET PARKING NOT REQUIRED.   Section 7 of the Special Use
Ordinance entitled “Off-Street Parking” is hereby amended as follows (additions
underlined and deletions struck through):
Section 7. OFF-STREET PARKING .
 
A.   The Applicant, at its sole cost, must offer valet parking services on the
Property during all hours of operation for the Proposed Use. Applicant is
solely responsible for securing secure off-site parking facilities to store the
vehicles associated with the Proposed Use being parked by valet. Upon the
Village’s reasonable request, the Applicant shall immediately provide the
Village with a written off-site parking facility agreement executed by the
Applicant and the owner of the property on which the off-site parking facility
is located authorizing the Applicant to use the off-site parking facility for
valet parking purposes consistent with the terms and conditions of this
Ordinance. The off-site parking facility agreement shall provide, in the
Village’s sole discretion, sufficient parking capacity to accommodate the
parking demand generated by the Proposed Use. Failure to provide proof of
sufficient off-site parking capacity shall constitute a violation of this
Ordinance.
 
B.   The Applicant shall post a sign in a location visible to patrons as they
enter the building located on the Property advising patrons of the parking
restrictions in place on 111th Street, Depot Street, Worth Avenue, and the
alley located immediately south of the Property (collectively, the
“Neighborhood”). The Applicant shall be jointly and severally liable for any
violation of a Village code, ordinance, rule, or regulation, as amended,
concerning parking in the Neighborhood by the Proposed Use’s employees,
patrons, or visitors, including, without limitation, any fines or liability
imposed as a result of such violation.
 
  Section 4.   SPECIAL USE ORDINANCE RESTATED. All provisions of the Special
Use Ordinance not expressly amended by this Ordinance shall remain in full
force and effect.
Section 5.   COMPLIANCE WITH CONDITIONS. Upon failure or refusal of the
Petitioner to comply with the conditions, restrictions, or provisions of this
Ordinance, the approvals granted by the Special Use Ordinance and the approvals
granted by this Ordinance (collectively, the “Approvals”) will, at the sole
discretion of the Board of Trustees, by ordinance duly adopted, be revoked and
become null and void; provided, however, that the Board of Trustees will not
revoke the Approvals unless it first provides the Petitioner with sixty (60)
days advance written notice of the reasons for revocation and an opportunity to
be heard at a regular meeting of the Board of Trustees. In the event of
revocation, the development and use of the Property will be governed solely by
the regulations of the B1 Zoning District, as amended. Further, in the event of
revocation, the Village Attorney is authorized and directed to bring all zoning
enforcement action as may be appropriate under the circumstances. The
Petitioner acknowledges that public notices and hearings have been held with
respect to the adoption of this Ordinance, have considered the possibility of
the revocation provided for in this Section 5, and agrees not to challenge any
revocation on the grounds of any procedural infirmity or any denial of any
procedural right, provided that the notice to the Petitioner required by this
Section is given.
Section 6. BINDING EFFECT; NON-TRANSFERABILITY. The privileges, obligations,
and provisions of each and every section of this Ordinance are for the sole
benefit of, and will be binding on the Petitioner except as otherwise expressly
provided in this Ordinance. Nothing in this Ordinance will be deemed to allow
this Ordinance to be transferred to any person or entity without a new
application for special use approval.
Section 7. EFFECTIVE DATE.
A.   This Ordinance will be effective upon occurrence of the following events:
   i.   Passage by the Board of Trustees in the manner required by law;
 
ii.   Publication of this Ordinance in pamphlet form in the manner required by
law;
 
iii.   Petitioner filing with the Village Clerk the Unconditional Agreement and
Consent attached to this Ordinance as Exhibit C and, by this reference, made a
part of this Ordinance; and
 
iv.   The recording of this Ordinance in the Office of the Cook County Cler,
Recordings Division. The Petitioner will bear the full cost of recording.
 
   B.   In the event the Petitioner does not file with the Village Clerk a
fully executed copy of the Unconditional Agreement and Consent identified in
Section 7(A)(iii) of this Ordinance within ninety (90) days of the date of
passage of this Ordinance by the Board of Trustees, the Board of Trustees will
have the right, in their sole discretion, to declare this Ordinance null and
void and of no force or effect.
Section 8. SUPERSEDER. In the event a conflict exists between the terms of this
Ordinance and any other ordinance of the Village, the terms of this Ordinance
shall govern.
PASSED this 19 Day of August, 2025
 
AYES: Ryan, Kats, Muersch Jr., Dziedzic, and Packwood (5)
NAYS: (0)

VILLAGE OF WORTH BOARD OF TRUSTEES
FINDINGS FOR AN AMENDMENT TO A SPECIAL USE PERMIT FOR
A RETAIL TOBACCO STORE LOCATED AT
7011 W. 111TH STREET, WORTH, ILLINOIS
 
On July 15, August 6, and August 19, 2025, the Village Board considered a
request for an amendment to a previously-approved special use permit allowing a
retail tobacco store to locate on the property commonly known as 7011 W. 111th
Street, Worth, Illinois (collectively, the “ Property ”). The special use was
proposed by Asem Jaber with the consent of the Property’s Owner, Husama Samara
(collectively, the “ Applicant ”).
 
I.    Findings
 
Based on the evidence presented, the Village Board’s discussion, and all other
relevant information, the Village Board makes the following findings concerning
the proposed special use in accordance with Section 5-2-10 of the Worth Village
Code:
 
   a.   The establishment, maintenance, or operation of the special use will
not be detrimental to or endanger the public health, safety, morals, comfort,
or general welfare.
 
The Applicant proposes to continue to operate an existing business in much the
same manner as the business has been operated for nearly the last decade. The
Applicant is obligated to comply with all terms of the original special use
ordinance as well as all generally-applicable Village laws and regulations.
 
   b.   The special use will not be injurious to the use and enjoyment of other
property in the immediate vicinity for the purposes already permitted, nor
substantially diminish and impair property values within the neighborhood.
 
The continued use of the Property as a retail tobacco facility is complimentary
to other service uses located in the 111th Street corridor. The business has
established a clientele over the last 8 years and the new operator plans to
continue serving those customers and others.
 
   c.   The establishment of the special use will not impede the normal and
orderly development and improvement of the surrounding property for uses
permitted in the district.
 
The surrounding area has seen little recent development. The B1 Zoning District
accommodates a wide variety of business and commercial uses, many of which
would benefit from being located near successful businesses. Promoting the
productive use on the Property may encourage further reinvestment in the
surrounding area.
 
   d.   Adequate utilities, access roads, drainage and/or necessary facilities
have been or are being provided.
 
The Property’s existing facilities are sufficient to serve the proposed use.
The Property currently has 2 curb cuts – 1 accessing 111th Street, and other
providing access to Worth Avenue. The Applicant plans to preserve 2 vehicle
access points.
 
   e.   Adequate measures have been or will be taken to provide ingress and
egress so designed as to minimize traffic congestion in the public streets.
 
The Property has direct access onto both 111th Street and Worth Avenue. This
access arrangement has existed for many years without apparent issue.
 
   f.   The special use shall, in all other respects, conform to the applicable
regulations of the district in which it is located, except as such regulations
may, in each instance, be modified by the president and village board pursuant
to the recommendations of the real estate development board, or as allowed for
planned developments.
 
The Applicant does not propose to deviate from any village rules or
regulations, other than a previously-approved variance to reduce the number of
required parking spaces on the Property by 1 parking space (See Ordinance No.
2017-48). The Applicant’s amendment proposal has no impact on the proposal’s
compliance with the applicable zoning regulations. The findings from Ordinance
No. 2017-47 are incorporated into this finding by reference.
 
 
 
 
 
 
EXHIBIT C
 
UNCONDITIONAL AGREEMENT AND CONSENT
 
TO:   The Village of Worth, Illinois (“Village”)
 
WHEREAS, Husama Samara (“Owner”) owns certain property commonly known as 7011
W. 111th Street, Worth, Illinois, Illinois, legally described on Exhibit 1
(“Property”); and
 
WHEREAS, the Owner and Asem Jaber (collectively, “Applicant”) have sought
approval of an amendment to a special use permit to develop, operate, and
maintain the Property as a retail tobacco store (the “Zoning Relief”); and
 
WHEREAS, Ordinance No. 2025-36, adopted by Board of Trustees of the Village on
August 19, 2025, grants approval of such Zoning Relief, subject to certain
conditions (“Ordinance”); and
 
   WHEREAS, the Applicant desires to evidence to the Village its unconditional
agreement and consent to accept and abide by each of the terms, conditions, and
limitations set forth in the Ordinance.
 
   NOW THEREFORE, the Applicant does hereby agree and covenant as follows:
 
1.   The Applicant hereby unconditionally agrees to accept, consent to and
abide by all terms, conditions, restrictions, and provisions of the Ordinance.
 
2.   The Applicant acknowledges and agrees that the Village will not be, in any
way, liable for any damages or injuries that may be sustained as a result of
the Village’s review and approval of any plans for the Property, or the
issuance of any permits for the use and development of the Property, and that
the Village’s review and approval of any such plans and issuance of any such
permits does not, and will not, in any way, be deemed to insure the Applicant
against any damage or injury of any kind and at any time.
 
3.   The Applicant acknowledges that the public notices and hearings have been
properly given and held with respect to the adoption of the Ordinance, has
considered the possibility of the revocation provided for in the Ordinance, and
agrees not to challenge any such revocation on the grounds of any procedural
infirmity or any denial of any procedural right, provided that the notice to
the Applicant required by Section 5 of the Ordinance is given.
 
4.   The Applicant agrees to and does hereby hold harmless and indemnify the
Village, the Village’s corporate authorities, and all Village elected and
appointed officials, officers, employees, agents, representatives, volunteers,
and attorneys, from any and all claims that may, at any time, be asserted
against any of such parties in connection with (a) the Village’s review and
approval of any plans and issuance of any permits, (b) the procedures followed
in connection with the adoption of the Ordinance, (c) the development,
construction, maintenance, and use of the Property, and (d) the performance of
the Applicant of their obligations under this Unconditional Agreement and
Consent.
 
5.   The Applicant hereby agrees to pay all expenses incurred by the Village in
defending itself with regard to any and all claims, demands, investigations,
and suits related to, associated with, or arising from the Property, the Zoning
Relief, the Ordinance, or this Unconditional Agreement and Consent. These
expenses will include all out of pocket expenses, such as attorneys’ and
experts’ fees, and will also include the reasonable value of any services
rendered by any employee of the Village.
 
6.   The restrictions imposed by this Unconditional Agreement and Consent shall
be restrictions running with the land and shall be binding upon and inure to
the benefit of the Applicant and its heirs, successors, assigns, agents,
licensees, lessees, invitees, and representatives, including, without
limitation, all subsequent owners of the Property, or any portion thereof, and
all persons claiming under them to the extent provided in this Unconditional
Agreement and Consent. If any of the privileges or rights created by this
Unconditional Agreement and Consent would otherwise be unlawful or void for
violation of (1) the rule against perpetuities or some analogous statutory
provision, (2) the rule restricting restraints on alienation, or (3) any other
statutory or common law rules imposing time limits, then the affected privilege
or right shall continue only until 21 years after the death of the last
survivor of the now living lawful descendants of the current President of the
United States, or for any shorter period that may be required to sustain the
validity of the affected privilege or right.
 
7.    This Unconditional Agreement and Consent may not be amended, modified,
released or annulled except upon the express, prior written approval of the
Village of Worth.
 
8.   The parties comprising the Applicant are jointly and severally liable for
all obligations and duties imposed upon the Applicant by this Unconditional
Agreement and Consent.

VILLAGE OF WORTH
COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
ORDINANCE NO. 2025-37
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING SECTION 3-6-6 OF THE VILLAGE OF WORTH MUNICIPAL CODE TO
MODIFY THE NUMBER OF AVAILABLE LIQUOR LICENSES
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Worth (“Village”) is an Illinois municipal corporation
organized and operating under the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1, et
seq.) (“Code”); and
WHEREAS, the Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/1-1, et seq.) (“Act”)
establishes a framework for regulating the retail sale of alcohol liquor
throughout Illinois; and
WHEREAS, the Village is authorized by the Act (235 ILCS 5/4-1) and the Code (65
ILCS 5/11-42-10.1) to determine the number, kind, and classification of liquor
licenses; and
WHEREAS, the Village wishes to modify the number of available liquor licenses
in Class A-1; and
WHEREAS, the Village Board finds that amending the Worth Municipal Code in
accordance with this Ordinance will promote the public health, safety, and
welfare by establishing regulations necessary to ensure the safe sale and
consumption of alcohol in the Village;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
Section 1. RECITALS. The foregoing recitals are hereby incorporated as though
full set forth in this Section 1.
Section 2. SECTION AMENDED . The following changes are hereby made to the Worth
Municipal Code Section 3-6-6(B) (additions underlined and deletions struck
through):
3-6-6: LICENSE CLASSIFICATIONS, FEES, NUMBER ISSUED:
 
*         *         *
 
B.    Number Of Licenses Issued: The total number of licenses available for the
various classes of licenses shall not exceed the number set forth below:
 
License Class Maximum
Class A-1     6  5
Class A-2     0
Class B-1     4
Class B-2     3
Class C       1
Class D-1     0
Class D-2     0
Class E       3
Class F       0
Class G       1
Class H       5
Class I       0
Class J       2
Class K       1
Class L       1
 
Section 3. SUPERSEDER. In the event a conflict exists between the terms of this
Ordinance and any other ordinance or resolution of the Village, the terms of
this Ordinance shall govern.
   Section 4. EFFECTIVE DATE.  This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect
from and after its passage and publication in pamphlet form, in accordance with
law, and the provisions of the Worth Municipal Code amended herein shall be
reprinted with the changes.
