      3.   The execution of the bond shall be acknowledged by the officer and
his surety before some person authorized to take acknowledgment of deeds and a
certificate of acknowledgment made thereon. After approval of the bond by the
President and Board of Trustees, the Clerk shall endorse thereon the date of
approval and file the same.
      4.   The premium on such bond shall be paid by the Village. (1970 Code
§2.2)
   C.   Bond Schedule: The amounts of the official bonds required by this
section shall be as follows:
 
President of Board of Trustees $ 4,000.00
Village Treasurer              40,000.00  1
Village Clerk                  4,000.00
Village Collector              4,000.00
Building Commissioner          4,000.00
 
Provided, however, that if the same individual serves as Village Clerk and
Village Collector 2 , a bond in the amount provided for either office shall be
sufficient in amount for both offices. (Ord. 2017-38, 12-5-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30.
2 2. See section
  1-7-4 of this title.
1-6-2: MONIES PAID TO FINANCE DIRECTOR:
Any or all officers or employees of the Village who have collected monies which
are rightfully the property of the Village shall, on Friday of each week, or
more frequently when so directed by the President and Trustees, deliver to the
Village Finance Director all such monies collected for the preceding week and
shall obtain from the Village Finance Director a receipt therefor. At the time
of delivery of said monies, the officer or employee making such delivery shall
make a written report to the Village Finance Director showing in detail the
source and amount of the monies received. (Ord. 06-44, 6-20-2006)
1-6-3: COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS:
   A.   Salaries Established: Salaries for Village officers and employees shall
be as established in the Village's annual salary ordinance.
   B.   Salary Increases; Setting Certain Salaries:
      1.   The President and Board of Trustees may increase the salaries as
stated in subsection A of this section, but by no more than ten percent (10%)
for particular employees based on outstanding performance, qualifications,
experience or similar factors.
      2.   All nonunion employees in a position whose salary is set in annual
steps and whose longevity is past the last step will receive a 4.0 percent
increase over their current salary.
   C.   Effective Date: Any increases herein shall only apply to those
employees employed by the Village of Worth on the effective date hereof. The
increases herein shall be retroactive to May 1, 2008. No retroactive increase
shall be provided to retired, resigned or terminated employees.
Employees who convert from full time or part time positions shall not lose
their step ranking.
   D.   Holiday, Vacation And Sick Leave: Provisions governing holidays, sick
leave and personal days as found in this subsection shall control in the
absence of superseding provisions in (i) an applicable union contract; or (ii)
the Village's personnel policy manual.
      1.   Vacations Are Not Accumulative: All vacations must be used in the
calendar year in which they are granted and cannot be accumulated from one
calendar year to the next calendar year.
      2.   Waiving Vacation:
         a.   Any employee who fails or refuses to take a vacation in the
calendar year shall waive his or her privilege of vacation granted for that
particular calendar year.
         b.   Employees are not entitled to extra pay if their vacation is
waived. An employee who works throughout the calendar year without a vacation
will not be entitled to extra pay or salary.
      3.   Periods Of Vacation Granted:
         a.   The village hereby grants a vacation to all employees who have
been in the service of the village for more than one year, with the exception
of department heads not subject to a collective bargaining agreement who shall
be entitled to vacation immediately upon hire upon accrual. The period of
vacation is to be determined by the applicable union contract. For those
employees not subject to a union contract who have more than one year but less
than six (6) years of continuous full time service, the period of vacation
shall be ten (10) prorated days subject to the remaining provisions of this
subsection. For those employees not subject to a union contract who have six
(6) or more years but less than twelve (12) years of continuous full time
service, the period of vacation shall be fifteen (15) prorated days subject to
the remaining provisions of this subsection. For those employees not subject to
a union contract who have completed twelve (12) or more years of continuous
full time service, the period of vacation shall be twenty (20) prorated days
subject to the remaining provisions of this subsection.
         b.   If an employee takes an advance on vacation (i.e., vacation that
is taken before it is earned or accrued), and then quits or is discharged
before all the advanced vacation is earned or accrued, the repayment of any
vacation advances will be withheld from the employee's final paycheck.
      4.   No Vacation Period Longer Than Two Weeks: All employees who are
hereby granted more than two (2) weeks of vacation shall divide their vacation
into two (2) periods of time. No one period of vacation shall be longer than
two (2) weeks. The second part of vacation shall not start until after four (4)
weeks from the close of the first period of vacation.
      5.   Head Of The Department To Establish Vacation Schedule: The head of
each department shall establish a vacation schedule for his department so that
the department may operate effectively. The head of the department shall have
first choice as to the periods of vacation so established. His assistant has
second choice, and where two (2) or more employees desire the same choice of
vacation, the oldest employee in service to the village shall have the first
choice.
      6.   Holidays In Vacation Period: Where one of the holidays in subsection
G of this section falls in any vacation period, the employee having such a
vacation period is hereby granted an extra day of vacation.
      7.   Not Applicable To The Police And Fire Departments: The vacation
periods herein provided shall apply to all departments of the village except
that the provisions shall not apply to the police department and to the fire
department. Employees of these two (2) departments, the fire and police
departments, work under a system of hours that is especially established for
each department on a twenty four (24) hour a day, every day of the year basis
with total disregard to Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. Because of their hours
of employment and the various dangers and hazards of their occupation, a
different schedule of vacation for them has been established and this section,
in regard to vacations, shall not apply to employees of either the fire or
police department.
      8.   Schedule Of Vacations Deposited With President: The heads of the
various departments shall deposit their schedule of vacations with the
president for approval before said schedule becomes effective.
   E.   Sick Leave And Personal Days:
      1.   Earnings And Maximum Accrual: A full time employee shall earn eight
(8) hours of sick leave per month, provided he/she has actually worked a
minimum of one hundred (100) hours that month. The maximum accrual of sick
leave shall be limited to four hundred (400) hours. Any full time employee who
shall have accrued more than four hundred (400) hours of sick leave as of the
effective date hereof shall not lose those hours. However, he/she shall not
accrue any further sick leave until his/her sick leave accumulation falls below
four hundred (400) hours.
      2.   Vacation, Effect On Sick Time Earned: Each full time employee, while
on vacation, shall be credited with the hours ordinarily scheduled for him/her
during his/her vacation only for the purpose of meeting the one hundred (100)
hours per calendar month required to earn a sick day under this section.
      3.   OJI And Sick Leave: Sick leave shall not be used for work related
accident, injury, illness or conditions of ill health. An employee who is
absent from work due to an OJI shall not accrue sick leave unless he/she
actually works one hundred (100) hours that month.
      4.   Personal And Bereavement Days:
         a.   Each full time employee not subject to a union contract shall be
entitled to use three (3) nonconcurrent personal days per fiscal year. The
employee's use of a personal day shall not be chargeable against his/her
accumulated sick days. Personal days may not be used the day before or the day
after a holiday or vacation without prior consent of the village president or
village clerk. Unused personal days cannot be carried over from year to year.
         b.   An employee shall be entitled to three (3) days' bereavement
leave in the event of the death of a parent, child, brother or sister, spouse,
grandparent, grandchild, mother-in-law or father-in-law. These are meant to be
concurrent and will not be charged against sick leave.
   F.   Reserved.
   G.   Holidays: All full-time non- represented personnel shall receive the
following paid holidays each year:
New Year's Day (January 1)
Good Friday
Memorial Day
Independence Day (July 4)
Labor Day
Thanksgiving
Day after Thanksgiving
Christmas Eve (December 24)
Christmas Day (December 25)
New Year's Eve (December 31)
Employee's birthday
      1.   All full-time non-represented personnel must be in pay status the
day before the holiday and the first scheduled work day after the holiday to be
eligible to receive compensation for the holiday.
      2.   A full-time non-represented employee on an approved leave of absence
without pay on the day before or the first scheduled work day after the holiday
is considered to be in pay status and is eligible for the holiday pay.
      3.   A full-time non-represented employee who has been suspended for
disciplinary reasons for a period that includes or immediately precedes or
follows a holiday is not eligible for holiday pay for that holiday.
      4.   A full-time non-represented employee who has an unauthorized absence
immediately preceding or following a holiday is also not eligible for holiday
pay for that holiday.
   H.   Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund (IMRF) And Credit For Military
Service:
      1.   Early Retirement Incentive Program:
         a.   The Village of Worth does hereby adopt the Illinois Municipal
Retirement Fund Early Retirement Incentive Program as provided in section 7-
141.1 of the Illinois Pension Code. The Early Retirement Incentive Program
shall take effect on December 1, 1997.
         b.   To help achieve a true cost savings, a person who retires under
the Early Retirement Incentive Program shall lose those incentives if he or she
later accepts employment with any IMRF employer in a position for which
participation in IMRF is required or is elected by the employee.
         c.   To utilize an early retirement incentive as a budgeting tool, the
Village of Worth will use its best efforts either to limit the number of
employees who replace the employees who retire under the Early Retirement
Program or to limit the salaries paid to the employees who replace the
employees who retire under the Early Retirement Program.
         d.   The effective date of each employee's retirement under this Early
Retirement Program shall be set by the Village of Worth and shall be no earlier
than the effective date of the program and no later than one year after that
effective date; except that the employee may require that the retirement date
set by the employer be no later than the June 30 next occurring after the
effective date of the program and no earlier than the date upon which the
employee qualifies for retirement.
         e.   To be eligible for the early retirement incentive under this
section, the employee must have attained age fifty (50) and have at least
twenty (20) years of creditable service by his or her retirement date.
      2.   Service Credit For Military Service:
         a.   Service Credit Granted: Service credit is granted to members who
served in the armed forces of the United States for up to two (2) years of
service, prior to their participation in the Illinois Municipal Retirement
Fund.
         b.   Effective Date: The Village Clerk shall be directed to file a
certified copy of this ordinance with the Board of Trustees of the Illinois
Municipal Retirement Fund. This subsection H2 shall remain in full force and
effect until modified or rescinded, and notice of such modification or
rescission will be filed with the Board of Trustees of the Illinois Municipal
Retirement Fund. This subsection H2 is not limited to a specific military
operation.
   I.   Insurance Program:
      1.   Definition: "Full time employee" and "full time official" means for
the purposes of this subsection and the Village's Insurance Program those
employees and elected officials of the Village of Worth who work an average of
thirty (30) hours per week and aggregate one thousand five hundred sixty
(1,560) hours of work within a consecutive twelve (12) month period. Both
hourly requirements of this definition must be met in order for the employee or
official to be considered full time.
      2.   Application: The Village of Worth Insurance Program shall only apply
to all full time employees and full time elected officials.
      3.   Stipend: For each full time department head who elects not to
participate in and forego the health insurance coverage provided by the Village
shall receive an annual stipend of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) upon health
benefits renewal.
   J.   Probationary Period: All employees shall be probationary employees for
the first twelve (12) months after hiring. During such time, the employee may
be discharged without cause and without notice. However, all employees may be
suspended or removed from office by the President and Board of Trustees in the
manner provided by law. (Ord. 97-37, 11-18-1997; amd. Ord. 97-38, 11-18-1997;
Ord. 99-25, 1-4-2000; Ord. 02-10, 8-6-2002; Ord. 05-04, 1-18-2005; Ord. 08-18,
10-7-2008; Ord. 13-16, 7-16-2013; Ord. 13-21, 11-19-2013; Ord. 2017-28, 10-3-
2017; Ord. 23-03, 1-17-2023)
1-6-4: PREMIUMS PAID BY VILLAGE:
For those full time employees not subject to union contracts, the Village shall
pay one hundred percent (100%) of the cost of hospitalization insurance
premiums. (Ord. 05-04, 1-18-2005)
1-6-5: AUTOMOBILE ALLOWANCE:
All employees and elected or appointed officials of the Village shall be
reimbursed at the current IRS rate per mile for the use of their own vehicles
when on official Village business. (Ord. 05-04, 1-18-2005)
1-6-6: VILLAGE INSPECTORS, IDENTIFICATION:
   A.   Every inspector representing any department of the Village shall carry
with him and produce, upon demand of the occupant of any building such
inspector may desire to enter, an identification card giving such inspector's
name. (1970 Code §2.54)
   B.   No inspector provided for in this Code, meter reader or repairmen shall
have the right to enter any residence, store or other building without, upon
the request of the proprietor, tenant or any occupant of any such building,
exhibiting his identification card for inspection. (1970 Code §2.55)
1-6-7: CERTAIN EMPLOYEES NOT OFFICERS:
Crossing guards and clerical workers shall be considered employees of the
Village, rather than officers, and shall not be subject to annual appointment
and reappointment by the Village President. (Ord. 01-05, 5-15-2001)
1-6-8: CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER:
   A.   Position Created: There is hereby created the position of Code
Enforcement Officer. The Code Enforcement Officer shall be a full time employee
of the Village. The Code Enforcement Officer shall be subordinate to, and work
under the general supervision and direction of, the Chief of Police, but will
also work with department heads and administrative staff. (Ord. 15-28, 8-18-
2015)
   B.   Compensation: The Code Enforcement Officer shall receive a salary in an
amount determined by the Village Board. (Ord. 2015-37, 10-6-2015)
   C.   Duties: The duties of Code Enforcement Officer shall be:
      1.   To cite defendants for violation of Village ordinances and to issue
citations for those violations, both for administrative adjudication and
Circuit Court;
      2.   To appear at court or administrative hearings as needed with respect
to citations issued;
      3.   To collect and tally fees for parking at the metra lot and boat
launch;
      4.   To provide reports on his/her activities to the President and Board
of Trustees through computer generated reports;
      5.   To issue warning tickets to persons who violate Village ordinances;
      6.   To inspect properties for ordinance violations which are in plain
view, which are open to the public generally, or for which permission to enter
has been given by the owner or other authorized person, or for which entry is
authorized by law;
      7.   To maintain all records necessary and appropriate to carrying out
his/her official functions;
      8.   To inform citizens relative to the enforcement and provisions of
Village ordinances;
      9.   To respond and investigate complaints made regarding Code
violations.
   D.   Wear Identifying Clothing, Carry Identification: The Code Enforcement
Officer shall wear appropriate identifying clothing distinctive from that worn
by police officers, and shall carry Village identification. (Ord. 03-26, 8-5-
2003)
CHAPTER 7
VILLAGE CLERK 1
SECTION:
1-7-1: Appointment Of Deputy Clerk
1-7-2: Duties Generally
1-7-3: Specific Duties
1-7-4: Serve As Village Collector
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  1-6-1C of this title.
1-7-1: APPOINTMENT OF DEPUTY CLERK:
The village clerk is hereby authorized to appoint one deputy clerk to have the
powers and duties specified in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-30-10. (1970
Code §2.25A)
1-7-2: DUTIES GENERALLY:
The village clerk shall attend all meetings of the president and board of
trustees and keep a full record of its proceedings in the journal; keep all
records, receive, mark and properly file all papers coming into his office
belonging to the village; grant certified copies from the records or papers of
the village, and execute such orders as he may receive from the president and
board of trustees. (1970 Code §2.13)
1-7-3: SPECIFIC DUTIES:
   A.   Corporate Seal; Records:
      1.   In addition to the duties now imposed upon the village clerk by
state law, he shall affix the corporate seal to all papers which shall require
it. He shall also sign and issue all licenses and permits, in compliance with
the provisions of this code or any other ordinance of the village, or as so
ordered by the president and board of trustees or other proper officer of the
village. (1970 Code §2.14)
      2.   The village clerk shall be the custodian and keeper of the corporate
seal and of all the books, records, ordinances and papers of the village except
as otherwise provided by state law or any provisions of this code or any other
ordinance of the village. (1970 Code §2.20)
   B.   Record Licenses: The clerk shall keep a full record of all licenses
granted, transferred or revoked by the board of trustees or the president, or
under their authority, with the date that the same were granted, transferred or
revoked, and if revoked, the cause therefor, with the number thereof, and the
full name and residence of applicants for such licenses, in a book to be kept
by him for that purpose, and where bonds are required, the names of the
bondsmen or sureties. (1970 Code §2.15)
   C.   Petitions, Bids, Communications, Documents:
      1.   Receive And Read: All petitions, remonstrances, bids, bills or other
communications addressed to the president and board of trustees shall be
received by the village clerk and transmitted to the president and board of
trustees. (1970 Code §2.16; amd. 1995 Code)
      2.   Numbering And Issuing Receipts: Any and all documents required by
the laws of the state, the provisions of this code or any other ordinance of
the village to be filed with the village clerk, or in his office, consisting of
petitions, remonstrances, bills or other communications, as provided in
subsection C1 of this section, and including all petitions for any and all
purposes, bids, resolutions and communications requiring official action by
village officers or departments, and special and general ordinances approved by
the president and board of trustees, shall be received by the village clerk in
his office, in the village hall and immediately stamped with the hour, date and
year and duly numbered in order of the receipt thereof, and only during the
hours prescribed by the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the
village for the office of the village clerk to be open for business, in the
manner and form as set forth and in no other manner whatsoever. (1970 Code
§2.22; amd. 1995 Code)
      3.   Compliance Required: No document, petition, remonstrance, bid, bill
or communication required to be filed by subsection C1 of this section, or any
petition, notice or other document required to be filed by the laws of the
state, the provisions of this code or any other ordinance of the village,
including proposed resolutions or ordinances, or for the consideration of the
president and board of trustees or board of local improvements, of official
business, or for seeking, requiring or requesting official action of any
village board, department or officer, shall be filed and received except in the
manner and form as required and set forth in subsection C2 of this section, and
not otherwise, to be effective and to comply and be in accordance with the
provisions of such subsection. (1970 Code §2.23)
   D.   Deliver Resolutions And Ordinances:
      1.   The village clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the officers of
the village, and to all committees of the board of trustees, all resolutions
and communications referred to such officers or committees by the president and
board of trustees. (1970 Code §2.17)
      2.   The village clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the president of
the board of trustees all ordinances or resolutions under his charge which may
require approval or other action by the president, with all the papers on which
the same were founded. (1970 Code §2.18)
   E.   Notification Of Election Or Appointment: It shall be the duty of the
village clerk, within five (5) days after the result of any election is
declared or appointment made, to notify all persons elected or appointed to any
office, of such election or appointment. (1970 Code §2.19)
   F.   Providing For Official Register And Official Receipts: The village
clerk shall prepare and keep a book of entry to be known as the village clerk's
register, in which the village clerk shall regularly enter, in order of the
receipt thereof, any and all documents required by the laws of the state,
provisions of this code or any other ordinance of the village to be filed with
the village clerk, or his office, including all petitions for any and all
purposes, bids, resolutions, communications requiring official action by the
village officers or departments, special and general ordinances approved by the
president and board of trustees, as above enumerated, noting or stamping
thereon the hour, date and year each document is so received and the
corresponding number placed thereon as filed; and the village clerk shall
simultaneously immediately issue a receipt over his official signature for each
and every document filed, as herein required, which shall likewise show the
number, the hour, date and year of the filing or presenting of the same and the
name of the person, or whomsoever shall file and present the same. (1970 Code
§2.21)
   G.   Record And Proof Of Ordinance: The clerk shall record, in a book used
exclusively for that purpose, all ordinances passed by the president and board
of trustees. Immediately following each ordinance, the village clerk shall make
a memorandum of the date of passage and of the publication and posting, where
required, of the ordinance. This record and memorandum, or a certified copy
thereof shall be prima facie evidence of the contents, passage and of the
publication or posting of ordinances. (1970 Code §2.25)
   H.   Freedom Of Information 1 : (Rep. by Ord. 12-22, 12-4-2012)
   I.   Other Duties: The village clerk shall generally do and perform such
other duties as may be required of him by the president and board of trustees
and the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the village. (1970 Code
§2.24; amd. Ord. 97-8, 4-7-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 18 of this title.
1-7-4: SERVE AS VILLAGE COLLECTOR:
The village clerk shall also serve as the village collector 1  and shall
receive the compensation attaching to such offices. (Ord. 91-8, 4-23-1991)

CHAPTER 8
VILLAGE COLLECTOR
SECTION:
1-8-1: Establishment Of Office, Term, Appointment
1-8-2: Duties
1-8-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE, TERM, APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby established the office of village collector in and for the
village. Said collector shall be appointed by the president and board of
trustees and shall hold office for a term of one year from May 1 of each year.
The village clerk shall serve also as village collector 1 . (1970 Code §2.26;
amd. 1995 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  1-6-3A of this title.
1-8-2: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the village collector to collect all license and permit
fees and other monies payable to the village. He shall generally do and perform
such other duties as may be required of him by the president and board of
trustees and the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the village.
The village collector shall charge a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) to the
presenter of each check which is presented to the village and subsequently
returned to the village for insufficient funds, account closed, refer to maker,
or similar reasons. (Ord. 03-05, 3-18-2003)
CHAPTER 9
VILLAGE FINANCE DIRECTOR/VILLAGE TREASURER
SECTION:
1-9-1: Office Created; Appointment
1-9-2: Oath Of Office
1-9-3: Compensation
1-9-4: Powers And Duties
1-9-5: Assistant Treasurer
1-9-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT:
The office of the village finance director is hereby created. The finance
director shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees and shall be a part time position. The finance
director may be an independent contractor. (Ord. 13-15, 7-16-2013)
1-9-2: OATH OF OFFICE:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the village finance director
shall take and subscribe the oath provided by law. (Ord. 06-44, 6-20-2006)
1-9-3: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the finance director shall be as set by the village board.
(Ord. 13-15, 7-16-2013)
1-9-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The finance director shall serve as ex officio village treasurer and
shall have all powers and duties of village treasurer as set by law. The
finance director shall also direct, coordinate and be responsible for the
collection, investment, budgeting and disbursement of all village funds. The
finance director shall also exercise and perform such further duties as
assigned relating to village finances, accounting, payroll, risk management,
and purchasing.
   B.   The finance director shall follow practices and procedures which are
customary in the sound management of the fiscal affairs of a municipality.
   C.   The finance director shall generally perform such other duties as may
be required by the village president and board of trustees, this code and state
law. (Ord. 06-44, 6-20-2006)
1-9-5: ASSISTANT TREASURER:
There is established the position of assistant treasurer. The assistant
treasurer shall take and subscribe the oath provided by 5/3.1-10-25 of the
Illinois municipal code, as amended 1 . The compensation of the assistant
treasurer shall be as set forth in the applicable union contract. (Ord. 05-04,
1-18-2005)

CHAPTER 10
VILLAGE CONTRACTS
SECTION:
1-10-1: Equal Employment Opportunity Clause
1-10-2: Sale Of Personal Property
1-10-1: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY CLAUSE:
There is hereby adopted and made a part of the policy and purchasing
regulations of the village, the equal employment opportunity clause, as
required by the Illinois fair employment practices commission, and said clause
is hereby incorporated by reference in all contracts made by the village. (Res.
75-1, 1-7-1975)
1-10-2: SALE OF PERSONAL PROPERTY:
The village president and board of trustees by motion action may authorize the
sale of personal property that is no longer necessary or useful to, or for the
best interest of the village. The sale may be with or without advertisement; or
may authorize any municipal officer to convert that personal property into some
other form that is useful to the village by using the material in the personal
property; or may authorize any municipal officer to trade in the personal
property as part payment on a new purchase of a similar article; or may
authorize the sale at a public sale with other participants. In the event that
an item of personal property has no value or the cost of selling the same would
exceed the sale price, the village president and board of trustees by motion
action may authorize the donation or junking of such personal property. No
personal property may be sold or transferred to any officer or employee of the
village without advertisement and the acceptance of public bids. (Ord. 09-01,
1-20-2009)
CHAPTER 11
MASS TRANSIT DISTRICT
SECTION:
1-11-1: Participation In Mass Transit District
1-11-1: PARTICIPATION IN MASS TRANSIT DISTRICT:
   A.   Creation: The village hereby agrees to participate in the creation of
the Southwest Suburban Mass Transit District.
   B.   Appointment Of Trustee: The village is hereby authorized to appoint one
trustee to the board of trustees of the Southwest Suburban Mass Transit
District on behalf of the village of Worth. (Ord. 75-1, 1-2-1975)
   C.   Monetary Appropriation: Participation of the village in said Southwest
Suburban Mass Transit District shall be limited to a monetary appropriation by
the village of a sum not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per year, and
in the event there shall be a further request for monies to be contributed by
the village, said future appropriation shall not be made by the village without
further resolution by the president and board of trustees of the village. (Ord.
75-1, 1-2-1975; amd. 1995 Code)
   D.   Recording: A certified copy of the provisions of this section, together
with a certified copy of each ordinance adopted by each participating
municipality creating the district, and the names of the persons appointed as
trustees by each participating municipality shall be filed by the clerks of the
several participating municipalities with the County Clerk of Cook County,
Illinois, for recording as certificates of incorporation. (Ord. 75-1, 1-2-1975)
CHAPTER 12
VILLAGE PROPERTY USE; LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS
SECTION:
1-12-1: Requirements For Use Of Facilities
1-12-2: Reservations
1-12-3: Fees, Hours
1-12-4: Minors
1-12-5: Boat Launches; Fees
1-12-1: REQUIREMENTS FOR USE OF FACILITIES:
Organizations which meet the following requirements and have obtained approval
of the board of trustees shall have use of village owned rooms or other
facilities for which reservations are made in accordance with these rules:
   A.   Organization must be nonprofit.
   B.   Organization must be open to everyone who wishes to become a member.
   C.   All applications shall be made in writing. (1970 Code §2.66; amd. 1995
Code)
1-12-2: RESERVATIONS:
No person or organization shall be permitted to make more than six (6) advance
reservations falling within the same number of weeks, without application to
the board of trustees. Reservations for monthly meetings of organizations
approved by the board of trustees may be made for one year in advance. (1970
Code §2.69)
1-12-3: FEES, HOURS:
   A.   Fees: Persons making reservations in accordance with these rules for
use of the facilities prior to using shall pay the minimum fee of three dollars
fifty cents ($3.50) per hour. (1970 Code §2.67)
   B.   Hours: The regular hours for the buildings shall be:
10:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. (buildings to be closed by 5:00 P.M.)
7:00 P.M. to 11:30 P.M. (buildings to be closed by 12:00 midnight). (1970 Code
§2.68)
1-12-4: MINORS:
   A.   Meetings or parties sponsored by minors must be chaperoned by a person
thirty (30) years of age or over. This person's name will appear on the permit
and he will be held responsible for the conduct of the group. One chaperon will
be required for each twenty five (25) people, but never less than two (2).
(1970 Code §2.70)
   B.   Beer or other intoxicating beverages are not permitted. (Ord. 74-26,
12-26-1974)
1-12-5: BOAT LAUNCHES; FEES:
   A.   Permit Required: A person seeking to use the boat launch on the
Calumet-Sag channel owned and maintained by the village of Worth shall apply in
person at the village hall and request a permit for operation.
   B.   Applications: The village clerk shall maintain applications for permits
or operation in the village hall.
   C.   Information Required: The applicant shall provide the village clerk the
following information on the application for permit:
      1.   The name, address, and phone number of the applicant. For purposes
of this section, the applicant shall be the same as the authorized operator of
the boat.
      2.   The current registration number of his boat as it is registered with
the Illinois secretary of state, and the name of the authorized operator of the
boat.
      3.   Indicate whether the applicant is seeking a single use permit or is
seeking a seasonal permit. A “single use permit” shall be defined as a onetime
only launch of a boat. Except as provided below, a “seasonal permit” shall be
defined as a permit authorizing boat launches over a period of one year
beginning on July 1 of the year the seasonal permit is issued and concluding on
the following June 30. A seasonal permit issued between December 1, 2021 and
December 31, 2022 shall authorize use of the boat launch through June 30, 2023.
   D.   Schedule Of Fees: The schedule of fees for permits is as follows:
      1.   Single use: Ten dollars ($10.00).
      2.   Seasonal: Sixty dollars ($60.00).
Payment by the applicant of the fee to the clerk shall be by cash or check made
payable to the "Village of Worth".
   E.   Permit Issuance: The village clerk shall review the application for
permit. Upon satisfactory review, and payment of the applicable fee by the
applicant, the clerk shall issue a permit. The permit shall be a laminated card
indicating the name of the operator of the boat, and the registration number of
the boat. Each permit shall be designated as either a single use permit, or a
seasonal permit.
   F.   Furnish Permit Upon Demand: Upon issuance of the permit, the permittee
shall carry the permit upon his person before and during the launch of his
boat. If the permittee wishes to remove his boat from the channel at the
village of Worth's boat launch, the permittee shall carry the permit upon his
person. The permittee shall furnish the permit upon demand by police officers
or public employees of the village of Worth. (Ord. 01-10, 6-19-2001; amd. Ord.
10-07, 2-3-2010; Ord. 2022-09, 2-1-2022)

1-13-1: DESCRIPTION:
The corporate seal of the village shall be circular in form and be so
constructed as to impress upon paper the words "Village Seal" within a circle
formed by the words "The Village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois". (1970 Code
§1.8; amd. 1995 Code)
1-13-2: USE AND CUSTODY:
The corporate seal of the village shall be and remain in the custody of the
village clerk and his successor in office, to be used by him in all cases
provided for by any provisions of this code or other ordinance of the village
or the laws of the state, and in all such other cases whereby the laws and
customs of any state or nation, the use of the corporate seal of the village
becomes necessary 1 . (1970 Code §1.9)

CHAPTER 14
OFFICIAL TIME
SECTION:
1-14-1: Official Time Designated
1-14-1: OFFICIAL TIME DESIGNATED:
   A.   Central standard time shall be the official time within the village for
the transaction of all village business; except that from two o'clock (2:00)
A.M. on the last Sunday in April of each year, official time for the village
shall be advanced one hour, and at two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on the last Sunday
in October of each year such official time shall be returned to central
standard time by the deduction or retarding of one hour. All legal or official
proceedings of the president and board of trustees of the village and all
official business of the village shall be regulated by the time herein
established, and when by ordinance, resolution or action of any municipal
officer or body an act must be performed at or within a prescribed time, it
shall be performed according to the official time herein prescribed. All clocks
or other timepieces in or upon public buildings or other premises maintained or
controlled by the village shall be set and run according to the official time
as provided in this section, and it is hereby made the duty of the officer or
other person having control and charge of such buildings and premises to see
that the clocks or other timepieces are set and run in accordance with the
official time as provided by this section.
   B.   All persons residing within the village and all persons doing business
within the village are hereby requested to set and run any and all clocks or
other timepieces under their control within the village in accordance with the
official time as provided by this section.
   C.   When the words "daylight saving" or "daylight-saving time" are used in
any official documents or contracts they shall be understood to have reference
to the time herein fixed for the period from the last Sunday in April to the
last Sunday in October in each calendar year. (1970 Code §1.11)
