  1-5-1B of this Code.
3-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms as used in this
chapter shall be construed according to the definitions given below:
   ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Any spirits, wine, beer, ale or other liquid containing
more than one-half of one percent (0.5%) of alcohol by volume, which is fit for
beverage purposes.
   CLUB: A corporation organized under the laws of this State, not for
pecuniary profit, solely for the promotion of some common object other than the
sale and consumption of alcoholic liquors which conforms to the definition of a
club, as provided by statute.
   HOTEL: Every building or other structure, kept, used, maintained, advertised
and held out to the public to be a place where food is actually served and
consumed and sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers
and guests, whether transient, permanent or residential, in which twenty five
(25) or more rooms are used for the sleeping accommodations and dining rooms
being conducted in the same building or buildings in connection therewith and
such building or buildings, structure or structures being provided with
adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity.
   PUBLIC ACCOMMODATION: A refreshment, food service, entertainment, or
recreation facility of any kind whose goods, services, facilities, privileges,
or advantages are extended, offered, sold, or otherwise made available to the
public. Such definition includes any restaurant, bar, banquet facility, or
other business licensed or required to be licensed by the Village.
   RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out
to the public as a place where meals are served, and where meals actually are
served and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being
provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and
capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees
to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests. Provided, further,
that no restaurant licensed as such shall sell alcoholic liquor except with
meals.
   RETAIL SALE: The sale for use or consumption and not for resale. (Ord. 09-
07, 5-19-2009)
3-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED, TERM, RENEWAL, FEE:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, give, deliver or serve at
retail any alcoholic liquor without possessing a liquor license for the
specific premises.
   B.   Except as provided in this chapter, each license issued hereunder shall
terminate on December 31 next following the issuance thereof.
   C.   Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof, provided
that he is then qualified and eligible to receive a license and the premises
for which such renewal license is sought is suitable for such purpose; provided
further, that the renewal privilege herein provided for shall not be construed
as a vested right which shall in any case prevent the President from decreasing
the number of licenses to be issued within his jurisdiction. (Ord. 2018-18, 9-
18-2018)
   D.   A valid liquor license which is not renewed by the existing licensee
within fifteen (15) days of the date of expiration shall be considered null and
void thereby necessitating a new application at a cost of three thousand
dollars ($3,000.00). (Ord. 90-9, 5-15-1990)
3-6-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Application: Every person desiring to engage in the business of selling
or serving alcoholic liquor at retail shall make application in writing on
forms furnished by the Village. Such written application shall be verified and
shall be filed with the Local Liquor Control Commissioner 1 . All fees shall be
paid at the time of application.
Except for applications for new licenses during the course of the license year,
every application for renewal of a license shall be completed and in the hands
of the Local Liquor Control Commissioner at least fifteen (15) days prior to
the beginning of the license year. No application will be accepted or approved
unless the application is fully completed, the questions answered, properly
signed and verified. Failure to complete the application and to file the same
within the time limit prescribed herein shall be deemed grounds for refusal of
the Local Liquor Control Commissioner to renew such license.
The application shall contain such queries as shall intelligently inform the
Local Liquor Control Commissioner as to whether or not the applicant is
eligible for a license and complies with the applicable requirements of the
Liquor Control Act of 1934 2  for a retail liquor license.
Applicants may be required to submit information as to sources of funds for the
purchase or operation of their businesses. The Local Liquor Control
Commissioner may require such other information in writing or an oral
examination.
Misstatements in the application shall be deemed grounds for refusal to issue
or renew the license and, if a license is issued, grounds for revocation. (Ord.
07-29, 8-21-2007)
   B.   Publication: An application for a Village retailer's license for the
sale of alcoholic liquor shall be made in conformity with the general
requirements of this Code relating to applications for licenses. The Village
Clerk shall forward the application to the President, as the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner, for such action as the President may see fit to take
pursuant to the law.
When an application for license is received by the Village Clerk, the Village
Clerk shall, within ten (10) days thereafter, cause to be published in the
current legal publication for the Village, a notice that application has been
made for such license stating the name of the applicant, the residence address
of the applicant, and the street number and location of the premises covered by
said application, and notifying all persons that any objection to the granting
of said license shall be made to the President, as the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner, in writing, signed by the objector, within five (5) days
thereafter, and stating specifically the grounds of his objection. Said
publication may contain notice of more than one application for a license by
different persons for different premises. The cost of publication of said
notice shall be paid by the applicant, and the Village Clerk shall require the
deposit of sufficient sum to cover the cost of said publication in addition to
the required license fee, at the time of the filing of the application for a
license. No license shall be issued prior to the expiration of six (6) days
after the publication of said notice. (1970 Code §4.5)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  1-5-1B of this Code.
2 2. 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
3-6-4: PERSONS PROHIBITED FROM HOLDING LIQUOR LICENSE:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall not issue a license to any person
who is prohibited from holding a license under the provisions of 235 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/6-2 as amended. (Ord. 07-29, 8-21-2007)
3-6-5: EXAMINATION OF APPLICANT FOR LOCAL LICENSE:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall have the right to examine, or cause
to be examined, under oath, any application for a local license or for a
renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or suspension
has been served as provided by statute, and to examine or cause to be examined
the books and records of any such applicant or licensee; to hear testimony and
take proof for his information in the performance of his duties, and for such
purpose to issue subpoenas which shall be effective in any part of this State.
For the purpose of obtaining any of the information desired by the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner under this chapter he may authorize his agent to act on
his behalf, as provided by statute. (1970 Code §4.7)
3-6-6: LICENSE CLASSIFICATIONS, FEES, NUMBER ISSUED:
   A.   Classification, Fees: Liquor licenses shall be and are hereby divided
into the following classes:
      1.   Class A-1 and A-2 Tavern:
         a.   Class A-1 Tavern: Licenses which shall authorize the retail sale
on the premises specified of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises
where sold. The fee for such license shall be three thousand dollars
($3,000.00) per year for the first year of issuance and one thousand two
hundred fifty dollars ($1,250.00) per year for each subsequent year that the
license is renewed by the original licensee.
         b.   Class A-2 Tavern: Licenses which shall authorize the retail sale
on the premises specified of (1) alcohol liquor for consumption on the premises
where sold; and (2) beer and wine only, at retail, for consumption off the
premises where sold, subject to compliance with this chapter, including,
without limitation, the following provisions:
            (1)   The premises for which a license is issued must: (a) have
possessed a valid Class A-1 liquor license on August 3, 2022; and (b)
continuously possess a valid liquor license for the premises on and after
August 3, 2022.
            (2)   The premises for which a license is issued shall not sell or
serve food for consumption on or off the premises.
            (3)   The fee for such license shall be one thousand two hundred
fifty dollars ($1,250.00) per year.
      2.   Class B-1 and B-2 Package Goods:
         a.   Class B-1 Package Goods: Licenses which shall authorize the
retail sale on the premises specified of alcoholic liquor but not for
consumption on the premises where sold. The fee for such license shall be three
thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per year for the first year of issuance and one
thousand two hundred fifty dollars ($1,250.00) per year for each subsequent
year that the license is renewed by the original licensee.
         b.   Class B-2 Package Goods: Licenses which shall authorize the
retail sale on the premises specified of beer and wine only, at retail, for
consumption on the premises where sold, and alcoholic liquor, at retail, for
consumption off the premises where sold, subject to compliance with this
chapter, including, without limitation, the following provisions:
            (1)   The premises for which a license is issued must: a) have
possessed a valid Class B liquor license on April 1, 2020; and b) continuously
possess a valid liquor license for the premises on and after April 1, 2020.
            (2)   The premises for which a license is issued must provide one
parking space for each video gaming terminal, as that term is defined in
section
3-24-1  of this title, located on the property, in addition to all other
parking spaces required by section
5-9-6  of this Code.
            (3)   The retail sale of beer and wine for consumption on the
premises is only authorized in conjunction with the lawful operation of video
gaming terminal(s), as that term is defined in Section
3-24-1  of this title, on the premises. No retail sale of beer or wine for
consumption on the premises shall be authorized or occur if video gaming
terminal(s) are not present and lawfully operating on the premises.
            (4)   The fee for such license shall be one thousand two hundred
fifty dollars ($1,250.00) per year.
      3.   Class C Club: Licenses which shall authorize the retail sale on the
premises specified of alcoholic liquor (for consumption on said premises) by a
club or other special or charitable organization incorporated and operating as
a corporation not for pecuniary profit. The fee for such license shall be one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per year.
      4.   Class D-1 And D-2 Restaurant:
         a.   Class D-1 Restaurant: Licenses which shall authorize the retail
sale on the premises specified of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the
premises only, said sales to be restricted to sales that are made incidental to
the operation of a restaurant. If the restaurant is equipped with a bar, the
operation of the bar shall be solely incidental to the operation of the
restaurant. The fee for such license shall be three thousand dollars
($3,000.00) for the first year of issuance and one thousand three hundred fifty
dollars ($1,350.00) per year for each subsequent year that the license is
renewed by the original licensee.
         b.   Class D-2 Restaurant: Class D-2 licenses shall have the same
requirements and fees as Class D-1 licenses, except that liquor shall not be
sold after the hour of one o’clock (1:00) A.M. on any day until the reopening
of the establishment for liquor sales later that day at the time permitted by
this chapter.
      5.   Class E Restaurant: Licenses which shall authorize the retail sale
of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the specified premises, indoors only;
said sales to be restricted to sales that are made incidental to and in
conjunction with the service of food on the premises. Class E liquor licenses
shall be issued only to restaurants having a seating capacity of sixty (60) or
more persons at tables or booths. For the purposes of this subsection, a
“restaurant” shall be defined as a retail establishment deriving more than
sixty percent (60%) of its gross sales receipts directly from food and
nonalcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.
      6.   Class F Food Catering Service: Licenses which shall authorize the
retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises where catering
occurs    anywhere in the State, provided the sale or the order of catered food
and alcoholic liquor is made or taken in the Village. Said sales shall be
restricted to sales that are made incidental to and in conjunction with the
service of food on the premises. For the purposes of this chapter, a “food
catering service” shall be defined as a retail business deriving more than
sixty percent (60%) of its gross sales receipts directly from the sale of food
and nonalcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises of the consumer or
at a location leased by the consumer. The fee for such license shall be four
hundred dollars ($400.00) per year for the first year of issuance and two
hundred dollars ($200.00) per year for each subsequent year that the license is
renewed by the original licensee. The license period shall be from January 1 to
December 31 of each year. The term “in conjunction with the service of food on
the premises” means that the sale of alcoholic liquor must be accompanied by
the sale of food.
      7.   Class G Golf Course License: For any golf course constructed within
the Municipal limits of the Village of Worth, licensor shall authorize the
retail sale on the premises specified of alcoholic liquor (for consumption on
said premises) by a golf club within the confines of the course. No retail sale
of packaged goods not for consumption on the premises shall be allowed. For
purposes of this Class G liquor license only, and in conformance with section
5/4-1 of the Liquor Control Act. 235 ILCS 5/4-1., no employee under the age of
eighteen (18) of the licensee shall be allowed to sell or serve in a closed
container any alcoholic beverage at either the halfway house, beverage cart, or
any other similar temporary facility set up on the golf course. Further, for
purposes of this Class G liquor license only, employees who serve alcoholic
liquor may be at least eighteen (18) years of age or older rather than twenty
one (21) years of age if the liquor is dispensed by a bartender or other
employee who is twenty one (21) years of age or older. No employee of the
licensee under the age of twenty one (21) shall open, draw, mix, or serve
alcoholic beverages to anyone sitting at the bar located in the clubhouse. No
minor under the age of twenty one (21) shall be allowed to sit at the bar at
the clubhouse. Minors under the age of twenty one (21) may be allowed to sit at
tables where food and alcoholic beverages are served. For purposes of this
classification only, the licensee shall be allowed to dispense alcoholic liquor
for consumption on the premises in a plastic, styrofoam, paper or cardboard
container or any other container with a cover. No person (except purveyors or
delivery men) shall be allowed to bring alcoholic beverages of any nature onto
the golf course from an outside source. Any person who is found on the golf
course, having brought liquor or any other kind of alcoholic beverages on the
course from an outside source, may be immediately ejected from the golf course
by a course ranger, or any other person under the direction of the manager or
professional of the golf course. The person or persons ejected from the golf
course shall not be entitled to any refund of any monies paid to the golf
course. No person shall remove an open container of alcohol, either in its
original packaging or in any other kind of container, with or without a cover,
from the golf course.
      8.   Class H License: License which shall authorize the retail sale on
the premises specified of beer and wine only for consumption on the premises
only. If the premises is equipped with a bar, the bar may only serve beer and
wine. The fee for such license shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for
the first year of issuance and six hundred twenty five dollars ($625.00) for
each subsequent year that the license is renewed by the original licensee.
      9.   Class I Temporary License: Licenses which shall authorize the sale,
dispensing, and consumption of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises
during temporary events in accordance with section 3-6-20 of this chapter. The
fee for such license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
      10.   Class J Gas Station License: Licenses which shall authorize a gas
station, as the licensee, to sell beer and wine only, at retail, for
consumption on the premises, and alcoholic liquor, at retail, for consumption
off the premises where sold in the original package, subject to compliance with
this chapter, including, without limitation, the following provisions:
         a.   The property for which a license is issued must contain at least
1.25 acres.
         b.   The property for which a license is issued must provide one
parking space for each video gaming terminal, as that term is defined in
section
3-24-1  of this title, located on the property, in addition to all other
parking spaces required by section
5-9-6  of this Code.
         c.   The property for which a license is issued shall provide an
indoor area on the premises dedicated exclusively to food consumption,
including, without limitation, tables and chairs for patron use while consuming
food, and serve food during all hours that beer and wine are made available for
consumption on the premises. For the purpose of this section, “food” shall
include consumables prepared on site and shall exclude pre- packaged goods.
         d.   The fee for a Class J license shall be three thousand dollars
($3,000.00) per year for the first year of issuance and one thousand two
hundred fifty dollars ($1,250.00) per year for each subsequent year that the
license is renewed by the original licensee.
      11.   Class K Public Recreation Center License: Licenses which shall
authorize the owner and operator of a public recreation center, as the
licensee, to sell alcoholic liquor at retail on the premises specified for
consumption on the premises. For the purposes of this section, "public
recreation center" shall mean an indoor facility containing at least twenty-two
thousand (22,000) square feet of classroom, meeting, exercise, and gymnasium
space that is generally open to the public. The fee for such license shall be
one hundred ($100.00) dollars per year.
      12.   Class L Park Event BYOB License: Licenses which shall authorize the
consumption of alcoholic liquor which has been brought onto the licensed
premises by a park district patron for personal consumption, subject to the
following conditions:
         a.   The licensed premises shall be land owned or leased and
controlled by the park district.
         b.   The patron bringing alcoholic liquor onto the licensed premises
shall obtain the park district's prior written approval.
         c.   The licensee shall not allow any person under the age of twenty-
one (21) to consume any alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises.
         d.   The licensee shall only permit the consumption of alcoholic
liquor on the licensed premises in conjunction with the purchase of services or
the rental of space offered by the licensee to the public.
         e.   The licensee shall not permit any patron to leave the licensed
premises with an open container of alcoholic liquor except when resealed in
accordance with State law.
         f.   The licensee shall maintain dram shop insurance as required and
approved by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner.
         g.   The licensee may not charge a corkage fee to uncork, pour, or
provide glasses to patrons.
         h.   The licensee shall be liable for violations of this Chapter in
the same manner as the holder of any other classification of liquor license,
including, but not limited to, violations for service to minors and the over-
serving of patrons.
         i.   All employees of the licensee performing corkage duties shall be
BASSET trained.
         j.   Packaged and on-premises sales of alcoholic liquor are
prohibited, unless authorized by another license currently held by the
licensee.
         k.   The licensee may not store any alcoholic liquor on the licensed
premises, unless authorized by another license currently held by the licensee.
         l.   The fee for such license shall be one hundred ($100.00) dollars
per year.
      13.   Combined License:
         a.   The holder of a Class E liquor license may request that the
license also permit the sale of package goods in the manner permitted by a
Class B license. The holder shall submit an application as though applying for
a new license. Its issuance shall be discretionary with the Liquor
Commissioner.
         b.   The sale of package goods shall be permitted by an endorsement on
the original license that it is a Class E and package goods combined license.
The combined license shall be considered as a license of the stated basic Class
E for the purpose of including it in the number of licenses issued under
subsection B of this section. However, the hours of sale for package goods
shall be as provided for Class B licenses. The additional fee for the combined
endorsement on the basic license shall be one-half (½) of the last fee paid for
the basic license.
         c.   The holder of a Class A-1, A-2, B-1, B-2, C, D-1, D-2, E, F, G,
H, J, or K license may apply for a Class I license.
      14.   Payment Of Fee: No license shall be issued or renewed until the
annual license fee required herein and by this section is fully paid.
      15.   Proration Of Initial Fee: Whenever a fee for the first year of a
license is listed herein as three thousand dollars ($3,000.00), that fee shall
be reduced by one hundred twelve dollars fifty cents ($112.50) for each full
month during the licensing period from January 1 to December 31 for which the
license will not be effective.
   B.   Number Of Licenses Issued: The total number of licenses available for
the various classes of licenses shall not exceed the number set forth below:

3-6-7: CLOSING HOURS:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale, at retail, or to give away in
or upon any licensed premises, any alcoholic liquor except at the following
times. Liquor may be consumed on the licensed premises only during the hours
set forth below. Thirty (30) minutes prior to the liquor closing time, the
licensee shall take orders for the last round of alcoholic drinks. The licensee
must remove any alcoholic drinks from the patron area before the designated
liquor closing time.

2024-33, 6-18-2024)
3-6-8: TRANSFER OF LICENSE, CHANGE OF LOCATION:
   A.   A license shall be a purely personal privilege, good for not to exceed
one year after issuance unless sooner revoked as in this chapter provided, or
unless specified by this chapter, and shall not constitute property, nor shall
it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be
alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being
encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall cease upon the death of the
licensee and shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution,
provided that executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased
licensee, and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such
estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the
sale or manufacture of alcoholic liquor under the order of the appropriate
court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt
licensee after the death of such decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy,
until the expiration of such license, but not longer than six (6) months after
the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. A refund shall be made of
that portion of the license fee paid for any period in which the licensee shall
be prevented from operating under the license in accordance with the provisions
of this section. (Ord. 2018-18, 9-18-2018)
   B.   A license issued hereunder shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor
only in the premises described in the application and license. Such location
may be changed only when and upon the written permit to make such change being
issued by the President. No change of location shall be permitted unless the
proposed new location is in compliance with the provisions and regulations of
this chapter. (1970 Code §4.12)
   C.   When the licensee is a corporation, the license shall terminate
whenever fifty percent (50%) or more of the ownership interest therein changes
from that shown on the original license application. In such event, the
corporation, through its officers, must make application for the issuance of a
new license as provided herein. (Ord. 78-13, 5-2-1978)
3-6-9: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Unless an exemption is granted by the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner, no license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any
alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any church, school, other
than an institution of higher learning, hospital, home for the aged or indigent
persons or for veterans, their spouses or children, or any military or naval
station; provided, that this prohibition shall not apply to hotels offering
restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to restaurants, food shops,
or other places where the sale of alcoholic liquors is not the principal
business carried on, if such place of business so exempted shall have been
established for such purposes prior to the effective date hereof.
   B.   No person shall hereafter engage in the business as a retailer of any
alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any undertaking
establishment or mortuary. (Ord. 2019-26, 5-7-2019)
3-6-10: PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES, DEALERS:
   A.   General Prohibitions:
      1.   Minimum Age To Be Served: No employee of the licensee shall be
allowed to sell or serve any alcoholic beverage unless he or she is at least
twenty one (21) years of age. However, employees of Class E or Class G liquor
licensees who serve alcoholic liquor may be at least eighteen (18) years of age
or older rather than twenty one (21) years of age if the liquor is dispensed by
a bartender or other employee who is twenty one (21) years of age or older.
      2.   Container Restrictions: No liquor licensee shall dispense alcoholic
liquor for consumption on the premises in a plastic, styrofoam, paper or
cardboard container or any other container with a cover, unless authorized by a
Glass G or Class I license.
      3.   Sales To Intoxicated Persons: It shall be unlawful for any holder of
a retail liquor dealer’s license to sell, deliver or give any alcoholic liquor
to any intoxicated person or to any person known to him to be a habitual
drunkard, spendthrift or insane, feeble minded or distracted person.
      4.   Gambling On Premises Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to permit any
gambling on any premises licensed to sell alcoholic liquor unless otherwise
authorized by law.
      5.   Transportation Of Alcohol Off Premises; Restrictions: It shall be
unlawful for any holder of a retail liquor license to permit alcohol in any
type of container to be transported from the interior premises of the licensed
establishment, except the holder of a Class F liquor license in a manner as
provided for pursuant to subsection
3-6-6A6 of this chapter or the holder of a Class A-2, B-1, or B-2 liquor
license where the goods are packaged in the original container with the seal
unbroken.
      6.   Consumption On Premises: It shall be unlawful for any holder of a
retail liquor license (except Class F or Class L) to permit, allow, or suffer
the consumption of alcohol anywhere except the interior of the licensed
premises, unless authorized by a Class I license.
      7.   Original Package Restrictions: It shall be unlawful for any person
to transport from the interior premises of a liquor establishment alcohol in
any type of container, except packaged goods from a holder of a Class A-2, B-1,
or B-2 liquor license where the goods are packaged in the original container
and with the seal unbroken.
      8.   Penalty: In addition to the penalties as provided in section
3-6-16 of this chapter, any person who violates any of the provisions of
subsections A5 through A8 of this section may be fined pursuant to the Village
Fine Schedule, Appendix A.
   B    Consumption On Premises: It shall be unlawful for anyone not having a
license authorizing the sale and consumption of alcoholic liquor on the
premises where sold to sell or offer for sale any alcoholic liquor for
consumption on such premises, or to permit the same to be consumed on the
premises where sold, unless authorized by a Class I license.
   C.   Class B License: No person to whom a Class B-1 or Class B-2 license is
issued shall sell alcoholic liquor, except in the original packages or
containers, excluding sales by a Class B-2 license holder for on-premises
consumption in accordance with this Code. If the holder of a Class B-1 or Class
B-2 license shall, on the same premises, sell other items of merchandise not
incidental to the sale of alcoholic liquor, then the display of said liquor
shall be restricted to a portion of the store set off by partitions.
Notwithstanding the aforementioned restriction, the licensee shall be allowed
to erect promotional displays containing beer or wine in other parts of the
premises. The sale of all alcoholic liquor shall be allowed at any checkout
location, so long as the cashier is an employee at least twenty one (21) years
of age.
   D.   Class E License: No person to whom a Class E license has been issued
shall sell alcoholic liquor at a counter or a bar. (1970 Code § 4.22; amd. Ord.
78-13, 5-2-1978; Ord. 81-2, 1-20-1981; Ord. 98-18, 11-17-1998; Ord. 05-36, 9-
20-2005; Ord. 12-06, 5-1-2012; Ord. 2014-16, 3-4-2014; Ord. 2018-18, 9-18-2018;
Ord. 2019-07, 1-15-2019; Ord. 2020-14, 4-21-2020; Ord. 2022-37, 8-16-2022; Ord.
2023-48, 11-7-2023; Ord. 2025-10, 3-18-2025)
3-6-11: SPECIAL EVENTS:
   A.   Any liquor licensee may host a special event on the premises on any
given day for persons under the age of twenty one (21) years; provided, that no
alcoholic beverages are sold or served to anyone, regardless of age, on that
day.
   B.   The liquor licensee must notify the Police Department, in writing, of
any such special event at least twenty four (24) hours prior to the day of the
special event. (Ord. 84-19, 8-28-1984)
3-6-12: SANITARY CONDITIONS; EMPLOYEES:
   A.   All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, or for the
storage of such liquor for sale, shall be kept in full compliance with the
ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of
food for human consumption. (1970 Code §4.15)
   B.   It shall be unlawful to employ in any premises used for the retail sale
of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with, or who is a carrier of,
any contagious, infectious or venereal disease; and it shall be unlawful for
any person who is afflicted with or is a carrier of any such disease to work in
or about any premises or to engage in any way in the handling, preparation or
distribution of such liquor. (1970 Code §4.16)
3-6-13: VIEW FROM STREET:
   A.   In premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on
the premises is licensed (other than as a restaurant, hotel, or club, or public
recreation center) no screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall
be permitted in the windows or upon the doors of such licensed premises nor
inside such premises, which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of
such licensed premises from the street, road or sidewalk at all times, and no
booth, screen, partition or other obstruction nor any arrangement of lights or
lighting shall be permitted in or about the interior of such premises which
shall prevent a clear view of the entire interior from the street, road or
sidewalk. All rooms where liquor is sold forconsumption on the premises shall
be continuously lighted during business hours by natural light or artificial
white light so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly
visible.
   B.   In case the view into any such licensed premises required by the
foregoing provisions shall be wilfully obscured by the licensee or by him
wilfully permitted to be obscured or in any manner obstructed, then such
license shall be subject to revocation in the manner herein provided. In order
to enforce the provisions of this section, the president shall have the right
to require the filing with him of plans, drawings and photographs showing the
clearance of the view as above required. (1970 Code § 4.20) (Ord. 2023-48, 11-
7-2023)
3-6-14: PERSONS UNDER LEGAL AGE:
   A.   No licensee nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent
or employee of such licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to
any person under the age of twenty one (21) years or to any intoxicated person
or to any person known by him to be a habitual drunkard, spendthrift, insane,
mentally ill, mentally deficient or in need of medical treatment. No person,
after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor, shall sell, give or
deliver such alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of twenty one
(21) years except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service.
   B.   Whoever violates this section shall, in addition to other penalties
provided for in this chapter, be guilty of a misdemeanor.
   C.   Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic liquor
is prohibited because of age shall not purchase, or accept a gift of such
alcoholic liquor or have such alcoholic liquor in his possession.
   D.   If a licensee or his agents or employees believes or has reason to
believe that a sale or delivery of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because
of the nonage of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such sale
or delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification,
containing proof of age, issued by a public officer in the performance of his
official duties.
   E.   No person shall transfer, alter or deface such an identification card;
use the identification card of another; carry or use a false or forged
identification card; or obtain an identification card by means of false
information. No person shall purchase, accept delivery or have possession of
alcoholic liquor in violation of this section. The consumption of alcoholic
liquor by any person under twenty one (21) years of age is forbidden. Whoever
violates any provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
   F.   The possession and dispensing, or consumption by a minor of alcoholic
liquor in the performance of a religious service or ceremony, or the
consumption by a minor under the direct supervision and approval of the parents
or parent of such minor in the privacy of a home, is not prohibited by this
chapter. (Ord. 73-16, 10-16-1973; amd. 1995 Code)
   G.   Any person who manufactures, imports for distribution or use, or
distributes or sells alcoholic liquor at any place within the village without
having first obtained a valid license so to do under the provisions of this
chapter, or shall make a false statement or otherwise violate any of the
provisions of this chapter in obtaining any license hereunder, or who having
obtained a license hereunder shall violate any of the provisions of this
chapter with respect to the manufacture, possession, distribution or sale of
alcoholic liquor, or with respect to the maintenance of the licensed premises,
or shall violate any other provision of this chapter, shall for a first offense
be guilty of a petty offense and fined not more than the amount pursuant to the
Village Fine Schedule, Appendix A, and for a second and subsequent offense
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
   H.   Any person under the age of twenty one (21) years who, for the purposes
of buying, accepting or receiving alcoholic liquor from a licensee, represents
that he is twenty one (21) years of age or over shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. (Ord. 73-16, 10-16-1973; amd. 1995 Code; Ord. 2014-16, 3-4-2014;
Ord. 2025-10, 3-18-2025)
3-6-15: PEDDLING:
It shall be unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor in the village. (1970 Code
§4.14)
3-6-16: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE; FINES:
   A.   The local liquor control commissioner may revoke or suspend any license
if he determines that the licensee has violated any provisions of the liquor
control act of 1934, any ordinance or resolution of the village, any applicable
rule or regulation established by the local liquor control commissioner, or any
rule or regulation of the state commission.
   B.   No license shall be revoked or suspended and no licensee shall be fined
except after a public hearing by the local liquor control commissioner with not
less than a three (3) day written notice to the licensee affording the licensee
an opportunity to appear and defend.
   C.   The local liquor control commissioner shall within five (5) days after
a hearing issue an order determining whether the license should be revoked or
suspended and whether the licensee should be fined. The local liquor control
commissioner shall state the reason or reasons for such determination in a
written order which shall be served within five (5) days upon the licensee.
   D.   If the local liquor control commissioner has reason to believe that any
continued operation of a particular licensed premises will immediately threaten
the welfare of the community he may, upon the issuance of a written order
stating the reason for such conclusion and without notice or hearing order the
licensed premises closed for not more than seven (7) days, giving the licensee
an opportunity to be heard during that period, except that if such licensee
shall also be engaged in the conduct of another business or businesses on the
licensed premises such order shall not be applicable to such other business or
businesses.
   E.   In addition to a suspension, the local liquor control commissioner may
levy a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the first
violation within a twelve (12) month period, one thousand five hundred dollars
($1,500.00) for a second violation within a twelve (12) month period, and two
thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for a third or subsequent violation
within a twelve (12) month period. Each day on which a violation continues
shall constitute a separate violation. Not more than fifteen thousand dollars
($15,000.00) in fines may be imposed against any licensee during the twelve
(12) month period of his license. (Ord. 07-29, 8-21-2007)
3-6-17: APPEAL OF ORDER:
All hearings before the local liquor control commissioner shall be taken and
prepared by a certified court reporter. The appeal of any decision of the local
liquor control commissioner shall be limited to a review of the official record
of the proceedings. The only evidence which may be considered in the review
shall be evidence found in the certified official record of the proceedings of
the local liquor control commissioner. No new or additional evidence shall be
admitted or considered by the state commission. (Ord. 07-29, 8-21-2007)
3-6-18: OUTDOOR SERVICE AREA:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to drink, consume, transport, carry
or possess any alcoholic liquor, except in the original package and with the
seal unbroken, from any liquor licensed establishment except into a licensed
outdoor service area.
   B.   The consumption and possession of alcoholic liquor shall be permitted
in licensed outdoor service areas during the same hours of operation for which
the premises are licensed unless the outdoor service area license is issued for
different hours of operation. (Ord. 08-15A, 9-16-2008)
   C.   Application shall be made for an outdoor service area license upon such
forms and with such attachments as required by the local liquor control
commissioner. Except for outdoor service areas established before July 1, 2013,
outdoor service area licenses may only be issued to applicants for a premises
already holding a class C, D-1, D-2, E, or G liquor license. Outdoor service
areas established after September 16, 2008, shall receive the prior approval of
the mayor and board of trustees. (Ord. 2015-10, 3-17-2015)
   D.   The application shall be reviewed by the local liquor control
commissioner for compliance with ordinances of the village. No outdoor service
area license shall be granted to the detriment of the public health, safety,
welfare and quiet enjoyment of persons residing or working within vicinity of
the premises. The local liquor control commissioner shall have the right and
authority to place limitations or conditions upon any outdoor service area
license, which limitations and conditions may be changed on an annual basis by
the local liquor control commissioner. (Ord. 08-15A, 9-16-2008)
   E.   Unless otherwise permitted by the local liquor control commissioner to
promote the public health, safety, and welfare, outdoor service areas shall
comply with the conditions below:
      1.   No outdoor storage of food or beverages is permitted.
      2.   Trash containers shall be self-closing.
      3.   Except for outdoor service areas established before July 1, 2013,
access to the outdoor service area shall only be through the main structure on
the premises.
      4.   Fencing with a minimum height of four feet (4') shall be constructed
to prevent entry into the outdoor service area except through the main
structure.
      5.   No animals shall be allowed (except for handicapped service
animals).
      6.   No alcoholic beverages may be removed from the outdoor service area
except into the main structure on the premises.
      7.   Some seating shall be handicapped accessible.
      8.   Fire exits shall not be blocked by the outdoor service area.
      9.   Required parking areas shall not be used for the outdoor service
area.
      10.   Occupancy limitations shall not be exceeded.
      11.   Music, either electronically reproduced or live in person, shall be
permitted provided that such noise does not violate the provisions of section
8-3-6 of this code.
      12.   The public right of way shall not be used for the outdoor service
area.
      13.   Outdoor service areas established after March 17, 2015, shall not
be located within ten feet (10') of the public right of way unless a lesser
setback is approved by the local liquor control commissioner. The local liquor
control commissioner shall consider the following factors when evaluating
reduced setback requests:
         a.   The proximity of the outdoor service area to residential uses;
         b.   The volume of pedestrian traffic using the public right of way;
         c.   Potential visual obstructions caused by the outdoor service area;
         d.   The potential for conflicts between vehicles and pedestrians due
to the outdoor service area's location and operation; and
         e.   The protection of the public health, safety, and welfare.
      14.   Irrespective of the closing hour of the establishment, outdoor
service areas may not remain open after two o'clock (2:00) A.M. (Ord. 2015-10,
3-17-2015)
   F.   The local liquor control commissioner shall have the right to suspend,
revoke, or place additional conditions upon any outdoor service area license in
the event that any provision of this section is violated. Any hearing shall be
held before the local liquor control commissioner using the same procedures set
forth in this chapter for the suspension or revocation of a liquor license,
provided that the appeal from any adverse decision shall be to the circuit
court of Cook County. (Ord. 08-15A, 9-16-2008)
3-6-19: BYOB; DELIVERY OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR:
It shall be unlawful for any person not possessing a class F or class K license
issued by the village of Worth to deliver or serve alcoholic liquor or to allow
the delivery or service of alcoholic liquor in any place of public
accommodation. BYOB (bring your own bottle) facilities are prohibited in the
village except for those possessing a class L license. (Ord. 07-29, 8-21-2007;
amd. Ord. 2023-48, 11-7-2023)
3-6-20: TEMPORARY LICENSES:
   A.   The purpose of this section is to provide for the issuance of licenses
for the sale, dispensing, or consumption of alcoholic liquor during temporary
events. It shall be unlawful for any person who holds a valid license issued
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter to sell or dispense alcoholic liquor
in any manner which exceeds the restrictions and limitations of such license
without first having obtained a temporary event license from the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner. A temporary event license does not authorize a licensee
to engage in package liquor sales at a temporary event.
   B.   Applications for a temporary event license shall be filed on forms
provided by the Village Clerk. Only licensees holding a valid and current Class
A-1, A-2, B-1, B-2, C, D-1, D-2, E, F, G, H, J, or K license may apply for a
Class I license. The general application procedures set forth in section
3-6-3  of this chapter shall not apply to licenses issued under this section.
The application shall include such information as the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner determines is necessary to process such application, which
information may include, but shall not be limited to, the estimated number of
persons attending the event, the location and layout of liquor sales at the
event and at the premises, the persons responsible for dispensing of alcoholic
liquor, steps to be taken by the applicant to protect against any violations of
the Village’s ordinances, and information regarding the manner in which liquor
will be dispensed and consumed. Information and material related to applicant’s
qualifications may, at the Local Liquor Control Commissioner’s sole discretion,
be required during the processing of such application, in addition to the
information provided in the original submittal, including attachments. In the
event that the applicant is made aware that any information or document
submitted as part of this application process is inaccurate or incomplete,
applicant shall immediately notify the Local Liquor Control Commissioner and
provide appropriate corrections. Failure to accurately and completely provide,
or as necessary update, required information may delay the processing of such
application or result in its denial.
   C.   The following conditions, in addition to all others deemed necessary by
the Local Liquor Control Commissioner, shall apply to a Class I license:
      1.   A separate Class I license shall be required for each temporary
event. The term of any Class I license shall not exceed four (4) consecutive
days.
      2.   Not more than four (4) Class I licenses shall be granted to any one
applicant during a calendar year, except that applicants currently holding a
Class C license may be issued not more than twelve (12) Class I licenses during
a calendar year. Applicants that currently hold a Class C license, however, may
not be issued more than four (4) Class I licenses for temporary events where
the application indicates the temporary event will include amplified music of
any kind, including live performance or the use of stereo equipment.
      3.   The applicant shall notify the Local Liquor Control Commissioner of
each temporary event to be held no less than thirty (30) days prior to the
event and shall obtain a license to be posted at such event for each such
event. Any applicant who fails to notify the Local Liquor Control Commissioner
within the thirty (30) day period shall be required to pay the Village a
surcharge of fifty dollars ($50.00) for expedited review which shall be in
addition to all other fees required to be paid by the licensee.
      4.   Except as otherwise expressly provided in this section, the
applicant shall comply with all applicable provisions of this Code, including,
but not limited to, zoning, building, and health and safety regulations.
      5.   Applicant shall provide the Local Liquor Control Commissioner a
certificate or policy of insurance as evidence that it has obtained coverage as
follows: general liability insurance with limits of not less than one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit, or one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and per aggregate, naming the Village of Worth
as a party insured. Such insurance coverage shall be issued by an insurance
company licensed to do business in the State and shall have a “Best” rating
acceptable to the Village. The effective period of such insurance coverage
shall coincide with the period during which the Class I license is in effect.
In addition, the applicant shall furnish evidence satisfactory to the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner that it is covered by a policy of liquor liability
insurance by a responsible insurance company authorized and licensed to do
business in the State, insuring such applicant in the amount of not less than
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00).
      6.   The applicant shall have sufficient persons at each entrance and
exit to the premises to prohibit alcoholic beverages from entering or exiting
the premises, check identification, place a nontransferable hand stamp or
tamperproof wristband on any person twenty one (21) years of age or older, and
otherwise verify compliance with this Code.
      7.   Alcohol liquor may only be dispensed and consumed within the
premises identified on the Class I license. The premises shall be enclosed by a
fence, tent, or comparable structure or barrier approved by the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner. (Ord. 2018-18, 9-18-2018; amd. Ord. 2020- 14, 4-21-2020;
Ord. 2022-37, 8-16-2022; Ord. 2023-39, 9-5-2023; Ord. 2023-48, 11-7-2023)
CHAPTER 7
CIGARETTE AND TOBACCO DEALERS
SECTION:
3-7-1: Findings
3-7-2: Definitions
3-7-3: License Required
3-7-4: Application For License; Fee
3-7-5: Location
3-7-6: Persons Under Legal Age
3-7-7: Certain Free Distribution Prohibited
3-7-8: Vending Machines
3-7-9: Responsibility For Agents And Employers
3-7-10: Suspension, Revocation Of License
3-7-11: Violations And Fines
3-7-1: FINDINGS:
The President and Board of Trustees find and declare:
   A.   Cigarette smoking is dangerous to human health.
   B.   There exists substantial scientific evidence that the use of tobacco
products causes cancer, heart disease and various other medical disorders.
   C.   The Surgeon General of the United States has declared that nicotine
addiction from tobacco is similar to addiction to cocaine and is the most
widespread example of drug dependence in this country.
   D.   The Director of the National Institute On Drug Abuse concluded that the
majority of 320,000 Americans who die each year from cigarette smoking became
addicted to nicotine as adolescents before the age of legal consent.
   E.   The National Institute On Drug Abuse found that cigarette smoking
precedes and may be predicative of adolescent illicit drug use.
   F.   The enactment of this chapter directly pertains to and is in
furtherance of the health, welfare and safety of the residents of the Village,
particularly those residents under twenty one (21) years of age. (Ord. 2019-28,
6-18-2019)
3-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
following meanings:
   ADULT-ONLY FACILITY: A facility or restricted area (whether open-air or
enclosed) where the operator ensures or has a reasonable basis to believe (such
as by checking identification as required under State law, or by checking the
identification of any person appearing to be under the age of 30) that no
person under legal age is present. A facility or restricted area need not be
permanently restricted to persons under twenty one (21) years of age to
constitute an adult-only facility, provided that the operator ensures or has a
reasonable basis to believe that no person under twenty one (21) years of age
is present during the event or time period in question.
   ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS: A product or device not consisting of or
containing tobacco that provides for the ingestion into the body of nicotine,
whether by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting,
sniffing or by any other means. Alternative nicotine products exclude
cigarettes, as defined in section 1 of the Cigarette Tax Act, and tobacco
products, as defined in section 10-5 of the Tobacco Products Tax Act of 1995;
tobacco product and electronic cigarette as defined in this section; and any
product approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration as a
nontobacco product for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco
dependence product, or for other medical purposes, and is being marketed and
sold solely for that approved purpose.
   ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE: Any device that employs a battery or other mechanism
to heat a solution or substance to produce a vapor or aerosol intended for
inhalation; any cartridge or container of a solution or substance intended to
be used with or in the device or to refill the device; or any solution or
substance, whether or not it contains nicotine intended for use in the device.
"Electronic cigarette" includes, but is not limited to, any electronic nicotine
delivery system, electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe,
electronic hookah, vape pen, or similar product or device, and any components
or parts that can be used to build the product or device.
"Electronic cigarette" does not include: cigarettes as defined in section 1 of
the Cigarette Tax Act and tobacco products as defined in section 10-5 of the
Tobacco Products Tax Act of 1995; tobacco product and alternative nicotine
product as defined in this section; any product approved by the United States
Food and Drug Administration for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as a
tobacco dependence product, or for other medical purposes, and is being
marketed and sold solely for that approved purpose; any asthma inhaler
prescribed by a physician for that condition and is being marketed and sold
solely for that approved purpose; or any therapeutic product approved for use
under the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Pilot Program Act.
   PERSON: An individual, corporation, partnership, association, or other legal
entity.
   TOBACCO PRODUCT: Any product containing or made from tobacco that is
intended for human consumption, whether smoked, heated, chewed, absorbed,
dissolved, inhaled, snorted, sniffed, or ingested by any other means,
including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, little cigars, chewing
tobacco, pipe tobacco, snuff, snus, and any other smokeless tobacco product
which contains tobacco that is finely cut, ground, powdered, or leaf and
intended to be placed in the oral cavity.
"Tobacco product" includes any component, part, or accessory of a tobacco
product, whether or not sold separately.
"Tobacco product" does not include: an electronic cigarette and alternative
nicotine product as defined in this section; or any product that has been
approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration for sale as a
tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco dependence product, or for other
medical purposes, and is being marketed and sold solely for that approved
purpose.
   VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical, electrical or electronic, self-service
device which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment,
dispenses tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine
products. (Ord. 2019-28, 6-18-2019)
3-7-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling
at retail, or to give away tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, or
alternative nicotine products without having first obtained a tobacco dealer's
license therefor pursuant to this chapter. The license shall be in addition to
any other license required by ordinance. (Ord. 2019-28, 6-18-2019)
3-7-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
Application for a license hereunder shall be made, in writing, to the Village
Clerk and shall be processed in accordance with the provisions of chapter 1 of
this title. The license fee for a tobacco license shall be as set forth in
section
3-1-5 of this title. (Ord. 94-5, 2-1-1994)
3-7-5: LOCATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away or
deliver tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine
products within one hundred feet (100') of any school, childcare facility or
other building used for education or recreational programs for persons under
the age of twenty one (21) years. (Ord. 2019-28, 6-18-2019)
3-7-6: PERSONS UNDER LEGAL AGE:
   A.   Prohibited Sales And Delivery; Signs:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee, to
sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver tobacco products, electronic
cigarettes, or alternative nicotine products to any person under the age of
twenty one (21) years.
      2.   Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for
herein shall be posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco
products, electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine products and on or
upon every vending machine which offers tobacco products, electronic
cigarettes, or alternative nicotine products for sale. Each such sign shall be
plainly visible and shall state:
The Sale of Tobacco Products and Smoking Herbs to Persons Under Twenty One
Years of Age or the Misrepresentation of Age to Procure such a Sale is
Prohibited by Law
The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a white background, said
letters to be at least one-half inch (1/2") high.
   B.   Minimum Age: No person under sixteen (16) years of age may sell any
tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine products in
any licensed premises. This section does not apply to a sales clerk in a
family-owned business which can prove that the sales clerk is in fact a son or
daughter of the owner.
   C.   Purchase By Minors Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person
under the age of twenty one (21) years to purchase any tobacco products,
electronic cigarettes, or alternative nicotine products. No person under twenty
one (21) years of age in the furtherance or facilitation of obtaining any
tobacco product, electronic cigarette, or alternative nicotine product shall
display or use a false or forged identification card or transfer, alter, or
deface an identification card. Before selling, offering for sale, giving, or
furnishing any tobacco product, electronic cigarette, or alternative nicotine
product to another person, the person selling, offering for sale, giving, or
furnishing the product or component shall verify that the person is at least
twenty one (21) years of age by:
      1.   Examining from any person that appears to be under thirty (30) years
of age a government issued photographic identification that establishes the
person is at least twenty one (21) years of age, or
      2.   For sales made through the internet or other remote sales methods,
performing an age verification through an independent, third party age
verification service that compares information available from public records to
the personal information entered by the person during the ordering process that
establishes the person is twenty one (21) years of age or older.
   D.   Possession By Minors Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person
under the age of twenty one (21) years to possess any tobacco product,
electronic cigarette, or alternative nicotine product; provided, that the
possession by a person under the age of twenty one (21) years under the direct
supervision of the parent or guardian of such person in the privacy of the
parent's or guardian's home shall not be prohibited. (Ord. 2019-28, 6-18-2019)
3-7-7: CERTAIN FREE DISTRIBUTION PROHIBITED:
A person shall not distribute without charge samples of any tobacco product to
any other person, regardless of age, except for smokeless tobacco in an adult-
only facility. This subsection does not apply to the distribution of a tobacco
product, electronic cigarette, or alternative nicotine product sample in any
adult-only facility. (Ord. 2019-28, 6-18-2019)
3-7-8: VENDING MACHINES:
   A.   Vending Machines: Tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and
alternative nicotine products may be sold through a vending machine only if
such tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and alternative nicotine products
are not placed together with any non-tobacco product, other than matches, in
the vending machine, and the vending machine is in any of the following
locations:
      1.   Places to which persons under twenty one (21) years of age are not
permitted access at any time; or
      2.   Places where alcoholic beverages are sold and consumed on the
premises and vending machine operation is under the direct supervision of the
owner or manager. (Ord. 2019-28, 6-18-2019)
3-7-9: RESPONSIBILITY FOR AGENTS AND EMPLOYERS:
Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or other agent
or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such
licensee, and such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such
act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally. (Ord. 94-
5, 2-1-1994)
3-7-10: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Licenses issued under this chapter may be suspended or revoked in the manner
set forth in chapter 1 of this title. (Ord. 94-5, 2-1-1994)
3-7-11: VIOLATIONS AND FINES:
Violations with respect to possession and/or purchase of tobacco products or
alternative nicotine products by a person under twenty one (21) years of age
shall be administered as follows:
   A.   A warning citation will be issued for a first offense.
   B.   For a second and subsequent offense, a citation carrying a minimum
twenty five dollar ($25.00) fine will be issued to the minor's parents or
guardian, if the offender is a minor, or to the offender if the offender is not
a minor. Any person found guilty of violating this chapter shall be subject to
a minimum fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00) and a maximum fine of five
hundred dollars ($500.00). A minor's parents or legal guardian shall be jointly
and severally liable for the actions of their minor children. (Ord. 2019-28, 6-
18-2019)
CHAPTER 8
AUCTIONS AND AUCTIONEERS
SECTION:
3-8-1: License Required, Application
3-8-2: License Fees, Bond
3-8-3: Transferability; Change Of Address
3-8-4: Location Restrictions
3-8-5: Prohibitions
3-8-6: Revocation Of License
3-8-7: Failure To Obtain License
3-8-1: LICENSE REQUIRED, APPLICATION:
   A.   All sales of real and personal property at public auction within the
village, except such as are made under and by virtue of legal process, shall be
made by a person who shall have first obtained a license for such purpose, as
provided in this chapter. (1970 Code §7.6)
   B.   Every person desiring to obtain a license for the sale of real and
personal property at public auction within the village shall apply in writing
for the same to the village clerk, setting forth in the application the
location of his proposed place of business, and the names of his sureties.
(1970 Code §7.7)
3-8-2: LICENSE FEES, BOND:
Any person may become an auctioneer and be licensed to sell real and personal
property at public auction, at a place to be named in the license, upon paying
to the village clerk the fees required by section
3-1-5 of this title and executing a bond to the village with two (2) sureties,
to be approved by the village clerk, in the penal sum of five hundred dollars
($500.00), conditioned for the due observance of this code and the other
ordinances of the village. (1970 Code §7.8)
3-8-3: TRANSFERABILITY; CHANGE OF ADDRESS:
In no case shall a license for the sale of real and personal property at public
auction within the village be transferable, or the place of business changed,
without the consent in writing of the village clerk. (1970 Code §7.9)
3-8-4: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
No goods, wares, merchandise or any other thing whatever shall be sold or
exposed for sale in any street, avenue, alley or public place in the village at
auction, but all auctions shall be held or conducted in a store, warehouse or
other proper place, which shall be so arranged that none of the bidders or
bystanders will be compelled or required to stand or remain on the street or
sidewalk in front of such warehouse, store or other place in such a manner as
to obstruct free travel thereon. (1970 Code §7.1)
3-8-5: PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Devices For Attracting Attention: No signal or means of attracting the
attention of passersby other than a sign or flag shall be used, at any place of
sale, or at any auction room or near any auction whatsoever. (1970 Code §7.2;
amd. 1995 Code)
   B.   False Representation: Any auctioneer or person present when any article
is offered for sale who shall knowingly, with the intent to induce any person
to purchase the same or any part thereof, make any false representation or
statement as to the ownership of or the character or quality of the article
offered for sale, or as to the poverty or circumstances of the owner, or
pretended owner of such article shall, upon conviction, be punished pursuant to
the Village Fine Schedule, Appendix A, and his license shall be forfeited.
(1970 Code §7.3)
   C.   Fictitious Bids: Any auctioneer who shall procure any person to make a
fictitious bid at any auction sale of real or personal property, or who shall
conspire with any person to make a fictitious bid at any such auction sale, or
who shall knowingly permit any person to make a fictitious bid at any such
auction sale, or any auctioneer, who shall himself fictitiously raise any bid
at any such auction sale, shall be punished pursuant to the Village Fine
Schedule, Appendix A , and the license of such auctioneer shall be revoked.
(1970 Code §7.4)
   D.   Substitution Of Articles: Any auctioneer who shall exhibit and offer
for sale at auction any article, and induce its purchase by any bidder, and who
shall afterwards substitute any article in lieu of that offered to and
purchased by the bidder, shall forfeit his license and be punished pursuant to
the Village Fine Schedule, Appendix A. (1970 Code §7.5; amd. Ord. 2025-10, 3-
18-2025)
3-8-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
All licenses issued to auctioneers, as provided for in this chapter, shall be
subject to revocation by the president and board of trustees whenever it shall
appear to their satisfaction that the party so licensed shall have violated any
provision of this chapter or of any ordinance of the village relating to
auctions or auction sales or any condition of the bond provided for in section
3-8-2 of this chapter. (1970 Code §7.10)
3-8-7: FAILURE TO OBTAIN LICENSE:
Any person who shall sell or attempt to sell at public auction in the village
any personal or real property whatsoever, except under and by virtue of legal
process or under and by virtue of a mortgage, without having first obtained a
license therefor, as required by this chapter shall, upon conviction be
punished as provided pursuant to the Village Fine Schedule. (1970 Code §7.11;
amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
CHAPTER 9
PRECIOUS METALS DEALERS
SECTION:
3-9-1: Definitions
3-9-2: License Required, Fee And Display
3-9-3: Application
3-9-4: Bond
3-9-5: Records
3-9-6: Resale Or Disposal Of Items Purchased
3-9-7: Purchases From Minors
3-9-8: Report By Renter
3-9-9: Violations Of Precious Metal Dealers Regulations
3-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, as used herein, shall be construed to have the meanings
herein ascribed:
   ITINERANT PURCHASER OF PRECIOUS METALS: Any person, whether as owner, agent
or employee and whether a resident of the village or not, who engages in the
business of purchasing "precious metals" as defined herein within in the
village, but who does not rent a store, loft, warehouse, office space or
showroom by the year or holds less than a year's lease on any such space.
   LOCAL PRECIOUS METALS DEALER: Any person who engages in the business of
purchasing "precious metals" as defined herein within the village and who
maintains a permanent place of business within the village renting space
therein by the year and holding at least a year's lease on such space.
   PRECIOUS METALS: Includes, but is not limited to, gold, silver and platinum,
in such forms as coins, rings, bracelets, necklaces, jewelry of all types,
silverware and any other item containing such precious metals with a retail
value in excess of twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 82-22, 9-28-1982)
3-9-2: LICENSE REQUIRED, FEE AND DISPLAY:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any purchaser of "precious
metals", as defined in section
3-9-1 of this chapter, to engage in such business within the village without
first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this
chapter.
   B.   Fee: The fee for such a license shall be as provided in section
3-1-5 of this title; provided, however, that any "local precious metals dealer"
as defined herein who currently holds a valid regulatory certificate (jewelry
business license) from the village pursuant to the licensing ordinances of the
village and who has paid the current regulatory fee is exempt from payment of
the license fee provided for in section
3-1-5 of this title. (Ord. 82-22, 9-28-1982; amd. 1995 Code)
3-9-3: APPLICATION:
Applicants for license under this chapter, whether a person, firm or
corporation, shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant, if
an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a
corporation, with the village clerk, showing:
   A.   The name or names of the person or persons having the management or
supervision of applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it
will be carried on in the village, the local address or addresses of such
person or persons while engaged in such business; the permanent address or
addresses of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person or
persons will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name
and address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if
any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is
incorporated.
   B.   The place or places in the village where it is proposed to carry on
applicant's business and the length of time during which it is proposed that
said business shall be conducted.
   C.   The place or places, other than the permanent place of business of the
applicant where applicant within the six (6) months next preceding the date of
said application conducted an itinerant business, stating the nature thereof
and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in
which such business was conducted.
   D.   A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done
or proposed to be done in order to attract customers and, if required by the
village clerk, copies of all said advertising whether by handbills, circular,
newspaper advertising or otherwise, shall be attached to said application as
exhibits thereto. (Ord. 82-22, 9-28-1982)
3-9-4: BOND:
Before any license, as provided by this chapter, shall be issued for engaging
in an itinerant business as defined in section
3-9-1 of this chapter, such applicant shall file with the village clerk a bond
running to the village in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), executed
by the applicant, as principal, and two (2) sureties upon whom service of
process may be made in the state of Illinois, conditioned that the said
applicant shall comply fully with all the ordinances of the village and the
statutes of the state. (Ord. 82-22, 9-28-1982)
3-9-5: RECORDS:
   A.   Every licensee hereunder shall keep a book in which shall be legibly
written in ink at the time of each purchase an accurate account and description
in the English language of the goods, articles, items or things purchased, the
amount of money paid for each, the time of purchasing the same, and the name
and address of the person selling said goods, article, item or thing, and the
driver's license and social security number of the seller. In the event the
seller does not have a current driver's license or social security number, two
(2) other items of identification verifying the name, address and identity of
the seller must be used and recorded. No entry made in such book shall be
erased, obliterated or defaced.
   B.   It shall be the duty of every licensee hereunder to make out and
deliver to the chief of police every day, before the hours of twelve o'clock
(12:00) noon, a legible and correct copy of the daily transactions from the
book required in this section to be kept.
   C.   The said book, as well as every article or thing purchased, shall be at
all reasonable times open to the inspection of any member of the village police
department. (Ord. 82-22, 9-28-1982)
3-9-6: RESALE OR DISPOSAL OF ITEMS PURCHASED:
No goods, articles, items or things containing precious metals shall be resold
or changed in any manner for a period of three (3) days after purchase by any
licensee, agent or employee. (Ord. 82-22, 9-28-1982)
3-9-7: PURCHASES FROM MINORS:
No licensee shall purchase any goods, articles, items or things containing
precious metals from any person under the age of eighteen (18) years. (Ord. 82-
22, 9-28-1982)
3-9-8: REPORT BY RENTER:
The owner, proprietor or manager of any hotel, motel, store or building of any
type shall report, within eight (8) hours after renting, to the chief of
police, the name of any person who shall rent a room or other space for the
purchase of precious metals, giving the location of the room or space so
rented. (Ord. 82-22, 9-28-1982)
3-9-9: VIOLATIONS OF PRECIOUS METAL DEALERS REGULATIONS:
Any person who violates any section of this chapter shall be fined the amount
set forth in the Village Fine Schedule. Each day that a violation continues
shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2014-16, 3-4-2014; amd. Ord. 2025-
11, 3-18-2025)
CHAPTER 10
PAWNBROKERS
SECTION:
3-10-1: Definitions
3-10-2: License Required
3-10-3: License Application; Investigation
3-10-4: License Fee
3-10-5: Interest Charges; Posting Requirements
3-10-6: Maintenance Of Records
3-10-7: Reserved
3-10-8: Inspection Of Records
3-10-9: Memorandum To Pledger
3-10-10: Exhibition Of Pledged Article
3-10-11: Display Of Weapons Restricted
3-10-12: Removal Of Identifying Marks Prohibited
3-10-13: Hours Of Business
3-10-14: Sales And Redemptions Regulated
3-10-15: Prohibited Pledges Or Purchases
3-10-16: Employees Under Sixteen
3-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
   AUTHORIZED ONLINE DATABASE: An online reporting system, such as LeadsOnline,
designated by the chief of police for reporting transactions under this
chapter.
   PAWNBROKER: Every person engaged in the business of receiving property in
pledge or as security for money or other things advanced to the pawner or
pledger.
   SECONDHAND PROPERTY: Any previously owned audiovisual equipment, camera,
computer hardware, jewelry made of precious metal, precious stone or gem,
sporting or athletic gear or equipment, including bicycles, watches or
currency.
   TRANSACTION: The receipt of secondhand property or any other goods,
articles, items, or things through pawn, purchase, barter, consignment, or
trade. (Ord. 2015-21, 5-19-2015)
3-10-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall engage in the business of a pawnbroker within the
village without a license. No junk peddler, junk facility or secondhand dealer
shall, during the period for which he shall have been licensed or permitted as
such, receive or hold any license to engage in the business of a pawnbroker.
   B.   No license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be
transferable to any person except upon the written consent of the president and
board of trustees endorsed therein. (Ord. 04-29, 6-1-2004)
3-10-3: LICENSE APPLICATION; INVESTIGATION:
An application for said licenses shall be made in conformity with the general
requirements of this code relating to applications for licenses. The chief of
police, or his designee, shall investigate the applicant to determine whether
said applicant is of good moral character. (Ord. 04-29, 6-1-2004)
3-10-4: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for a pawnshop license shall be as provided in section
3-1-5 of this title. (Ord. 04-29, 6-1-2004)
3-10-5: INTEREST CHARGES; POSTING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to charge or collect a greater
benefit or percentage upon money advanced and for the use and forbearance
thereof than the rate of three percent (3%) per month. Nothing in this section
shall be construed so as to conflict with the law pertaining to usury; and the
person receiving money so advanced may hold such monies to pay any fees in
addition to interest as herein provided.
   B.   Each pawnbroker may contract for and receive such fees in addition to
interest authorized by this section, as set forth herein, for investigating
title, storage, and insuring the collateral, closing the loan, making daily
reports to local law enforcement officers, and for other expenses and losses of
every nature whatsoever and for all other services. Such fees, when made and
collected, shall not be deemed interest for any purpose of law.
   C.   Every pawnbroker, when making a loan under this section, shall be
entitled to charge and collect onetime fees in the amounts authorized by state
law.
   D.   Every pawnbroker shall at all times have and keep the above subsections
printed in the English language, framed and posted in a prominent and
conspicuous position in his place of business, so that said provision of this
code shall be plainly legible and visible to all persons depositing or pledging
property with such pawnbrokers. (Ord. 04-29, 6-1-2004)
3-10-6: MAINTENANCE OF RECORDS:
   A.   Every licensee shall report all transactions through the authorized
online database in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The village
will notify licensees of any changes to the authorized online database prior to
any such change.
   B.   All transactions shall be reported to the authorized online database
within twenty four (24) hours of the transaction or the next business day.
Every transaction will be reported separately, and not in aggregate. Secondhand
property brought to a licensee at different times on the same date shall be
considered separate transactions and shall be reported separately.
