      1.   Wall Slopes: To a depth of five feet (5') from the top, the wall
slope shall not be more than one and one-half feet (11/2') horizontal in five
feet (5') vertical.
      2.   Floor Slopes: The slope of the floor in the shallow end shall not
exceed one foot (1') vertical to seven feet (7') horizontal. The transition
point between shallow and deep water shall not be less than four feet (4') deep
and not more than five feet (5') deep. (1970 Code §36.11)
   I.   Electrical Requirements:
      1.   No overhead current-carrying electrical conductors shall cross
private residential swimming pools, or be located within ten feet (10') of such
pools.
      2.   All metal fences, enclosures or railings near or adjacent to private
residential swimming pools, which might become electrically alive as a result
of contact with broken overhead conductors, or from any other cause shall be
effectively grounded. No underwater lighting shall be allowed. (1970 Code
§36.12)
   J.   Operation And Maintenance:
      1.   All private residential swimming pools shall be maintained in a
clean and sanitary condition, and all equipment shall be maintained in a
satisfactory operating condition during periods the pools are in use.
      2.   No private residential swimming pool shall be used, kept, maintained
or operated in the village, if such use, keeping, maintaining or operating
shall be the occasion of any nuisance or shall be dangerous to life or
detrimental to health. (1970 Code §36.13)
4-6-6: INSPECTION:
The health department shall periodically inspect all private residential
swimming pools to determine whether or not the provisions of this code
regarding health, sanitation and safety applicable thereto are being complied
with. (1970 Code §36.14)
4-6-7: PORTABLE SWIMMING POOLS:
All portable pools, as previously defined, shall in addition to the following
enumerated sections and subsections of this chapter, namely:
4-6-1;
 4-6-2A, B and C;
4-6-3A, B, C and D;
4-6-4A, B, C, D and E;
4-6-5A, E, F, G, I and J;
4-6-6 and
4-6-9; also comply with the following subsections:
   A.   Cover: The portable type pool shall have a cover which will support no
less than one hundred thirty (130) pounds when attached to said pool. The cover
shall be used at all times when the pool is not in use and the premises are
unattended.
   B.   Adult In Attendance: An adult shall be in attendance at such times that
any pool is used by a child or children of the age of seven (7) years or
younger.
   C.   Fence: The property owner shall construct or cause to be constructed a
fence around the pool not less than four feet (4') in height from the top of
the deck which is made of nine (9) gauge woven wire mesh, corrosion-resistant
material or approved wooden materials, four feet (4') from the pool, or a fence
around the perimeter of the lot of a height of at least four feet (4') and no
higher than six feet (6').
   D.   Ladders: No permanent ladder shall be used in connection with portable
pools and ladders which are used shall be removed and safely stored when said
pool is not in use.
   E.   Permits: The fees for permits for the erection or construction of a
portable swimming pool shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) for the basic permit,
twenty dollars ($20.00) for each necessary inspection, forty dollars ($40.00)
for electrical permit, if applicable, and a twenty dollar ($20.00) refundable
bond. (1970 Code §36.17; amd. Ord. 94-32, 10-4-1994)
4-6-8: NUISANCE:
Any swimming pool being operated in violation of the terms of this chapter is
hereby declared to be a nuisance and any police officer is empowered to abate
such nuisance forthwith by draining said pool. (1970 Code §36.18)
4-6-9: VIOLATIONS OF SWIMMING POOLS REGULATIONS:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be fined as provided
in the Village Fine Schedule. (1970 Code §36.16; amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
CHAPTER 7
MOVING BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-7-1: Permit Required
4-7-2: Payment For Street Occupancy
4-7-3: Bond Required
4-7-4: Liability Insurance Required
4-7-5: Issuance Of Permit
4-7-6: Compliance With Building, Zoning Regulations
4-7-7: Obstructing Intersections, Railroad Crossings
4-7-8: Lights Required
4-7-9: Driving Stakes In Pavements, Railroad Crossings
4-7-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No building shall be moved on or across any public street, walk, alley or other
public place within the village by any person, except upon a permit duly issued
by the village. (Ord. 77-8, 6-28-1977)
4-7-2: PAYMENT FOR STREET OCCUPANCY:
Before the issuance of such permit, the applicant shall pay to the village a
sum of money in payment for the occupancy of the street or streets through
which the said building is proposed to be moved and said sum to be determined
by estimating the number of days which will be required to move said building,
on the assumption that the building will be moved five hundred feet (500') per
day, at the rate of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day. (Ord. 77-8, 6-28-
1977; amd. 1995 Code)
4-7-3: BOND REQUIRED:
In addition to the payment for street occupancy, there shall be furnished a
bond in the sum of twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) with good and
sufficient sureties to be approved by the president, conditioned, among other
things, that said party will pay any and all damage that may occur to any
public street, alley or public place over which said building may be moved, and
to reimburse the village and any public utility company for the cost of
removing and replacing all overhead wires, cables and appurtenances and for the
making of the necessary repairs thereto. (Ord. 77-8, 6-28-1977; amd. 1995 Code)
4-7-4: LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED:
Before any person to whom a permit has been issued under this chapter shall
enter upon the moving of any building authorized to be moved by the permit, he
shall obtain from some reliable insurance company, policies of liability
insurance indemnifying the village and public for any damage or injury
resulting to any of the workmen or employees of such person engaged in the
moving of such building and also indemnifying the village and public for any
damages or injury suffered by any other person resulting from the moving of
such building. (Ord. 77-8, 6-28-1977)
4-7-5: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
If, upon consideration of such application and such inspection as the building
commissioner may deem necessary, it shall appear to the building commissioner
that the work proposed to be done is in accordance with the ordinances of the
village, the building commissioner, upon the payment to the village of the fees
and approval of the bond and insurance herein provided for, shall grant the
permit sought for such purpose. (Ord. 77-8, 6-28-1977)
4-7-6: COMPLIANCE WITH BUILDING, ZONING REGULATIONS:
No permit to move any building within the village shall be granted unless the
construction and proposed use of such building on the proposed new site shall
conform in every way to requirements of village ordinances 1  and of the zoning
ordinance 2 . (Ord. 77-8, 6-28-1977)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2 of this title.
2 2. See title 5 of this code.
4-7-7: OBSTRUCTING INTERSECTIONS, RAILROAD CROSSINGS:
No building which is authorized to be moved in accordance with the terms of
this chapter shall be permitted to stand or remain in the intersection of any
streets or any street and public alley or upon any railroad or railway crossing
at any time during the course of its moving. (Ord. 77-8, 6-28-1977)
4-7-8: LIGHTS REQUIRED:
On each and every night while a building remains on the public streets or
alleys of the village, from dusk to sunrise, the person to whom the permit was
issued shall place and cause to be maintained at the center and each end of
such building red lights, which lights shall be plainly visible during the
period abovementioned. (Ord. 77-8, 6-28-1977)
4-7-9: DRIVING STAKES IN PAVEMENTS, RAILROAD CROSSINGS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to whom a permit has been issued under this
chapter to drive stakes in any pavement, public alley or at any railroad or
railway crossing. (Ord. 77-8, 6-28-1977)
CHAPTER 8
TOWERS, ANTENNAS AND TELECOMMUNICATION STRUCTURES
SECTION:
4-8-1: Definitions
4-8-2: Permit Required
4-8-3: Application For Permit; Fee
4-8-4: Height Restriction
4-8-5: Construction Requirements
4-8-6: Application Of Provisions
4-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall have the following meanings when used in this
chapter:
   ANTENNA: The arrangement of wires or metal rods used in the sending and
receiving of electromagnetic waves.
   ANTENNA HEIGHT: The overall vertical length of the antenna support structure
above grade or if such system is located on a building, then the overall
vertical length includes the height of the building upon which the structure is
mounted.
   ANTENNA SUPPORT STRUCTURE: Any structure, mast, pole, tripod or tower
utilized for the purpose of supporting an antenna or antennas for the purpose
of transmission or reception of electromagnetic waves. (Ord. 87-43, 1-5-1987)
4-8-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to install, construct or increase the
height of any support structure without first obtaining a building permit from
the village; except, that no permit shall be required if the height of the
antenna support structure is less than twelve feet (12'). In measuring the
height of the antenna support, the height of any building to which the antenna
support structure is attached shall be excluded. (Ord. 87-43, 1-5-1987)
4-8-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEE:
   A.   Application: Application for a permit to install, construct or increase
the height of any antenna or the support therefor shall be made on forms
provided by the village for that purpose. The application shall require the
following information:
      1.   The location plan for the antenna and support structure.
      2.   The manufacturer's specifications for the antenna support structure
and details for footing, guys and supports.
      3.   A copy of the applicant's homeowner or other liability insurance
policy.
   B.   Fee: The application shall be accompanied by an application fee in the
sum of fifty dollars ($50.00). (Ord. 87-43, 1-5-1987)
4-8-4: HEIGHT RESTRICTION:
No antenna support structure shall exceed seventy five feet (75') above the
established grade at the site of such construction and installation. (Ord. 87-
43, 1-5-1987)
4-8-5: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Materials: Antenna support structures must be constructed using one of
the following materials: aluminum, galvanized steel or equally weather-
resistant steel or fiberglass.
   B.   Anchor: All ground-mounted antenna support structures exceeding thirty
five feet (35') in height shall be mounted in concrete or erected in such a
manner so as to be able to withstand a wind velocity of eighty (80) miles per
hour or more and withstand an impact pressure of twenty five (25) pounds per
square foot. Noncommercially manufactured antenna support structures shall be
constructed to withstand these requirements.
   C.   Electrical: All antenna structures and antennas shall be grounded in
accordance with the Chicago Electrical Code 1 . Ground-mounted towers shall
utilize a minimum of one ground rod with a minimum of five-eighths inch (5/8")
in diameter and eight feet (8') in length. The ground conductor shall be a
minimum of #10 GA copper. In all cases, the installation shall be in accordance
with the manufacturer's grounding requirements.
   D.   Location: Ground-mounted antenna support structures may be erected only
in a rear or side yard behind the setback required by the village ordinances.
   E.   Manufacturer's Specifications: The construction and erection of all
structures shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications. (Ord.
87-43, 1-5-1987)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  4-2-1C of this title.
4-8-6: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter shall only apply to structures and antennas erected after the
effective date hereof. (Ord. 87-43, 1-5-1987)
   4-9 ()CHAPTER 9
   RESIDENTIAL CONDOMINIUM CONVERSIONS
SECTION:
4-9-1: Definitions
4-9-2: Building Plans And Subdivision Plats
4-9-3: Condominium Plat And Plan Approval; Recording
4-9-4: Certificate Of Code Compliance And Code Inspections
4-9-5: Building Permits
4-9-6: Property Report
4-9-7: Condominium Requirements
4-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section. Any additional
terms and words not expressly defined in this section shall have the
definitions set forth in the condominium property act of Illinois 1  or the
2003 international building code, published by the International Code Council
and adopted as the village's building code.
   AGENT: Any person, firm, partnership, association, joint venture,
corporation or any other entity or combination of entities that represents or
acts for or on behalf of a developer in selling or offering to sell any
condominium unit.
   ASSOCIATION: The unit owners acting as a group in accordance with the bylaws
of the association and the condominium declaration.
   BLANKET ENCUMBRANCE: A trust, deed, mortgage, judgment or other lien or
encumbrance, including an option or contract to sell, or a trust agreement
affecting a condominium, including any lien or other encumbrance arising as a
result of the imposition of any tax assessment by a public authority.
   CERTIFICATE OF CODE COMPLIANCE: A written instrument issued by the village
as evidence of a condominium project's compliance with the requirements of this
chapter.
   CODE INSPECTION REPORT: A written report issued by the village as evidence
that all units and common elements in a condominium project have been inspected
for compliance with all applicable zoning, building and/or other life safety
code standards of the village.
   COMMON ELEMENTS OR AREAS: All portions of the condominium property, except
the condominium units.
   CONDOMINIUM: The ownership of single units in a multi-unit residential
project with common elements, including, but not limited to:
   A.   The land on which the building stands;
   B.   The foundation, main walls, roofs, corridors or hallways, columns,
girders, beams, supports, fire escapes, lobbies, stairways, and/or means of
entrance or exit;
   C.   The basement, flat roofs, yards and gardens, except as otherwise
provided or stipulated;
   D.   The premises for lodging of janitors or persons in charge of the
building, except as otherwise provided or stipulated;
   E.   The compartments or installations of central services such as power,
light, gas, cold or hot water, heating, central air conditioning or central
refrigeration, swimming pools, reservoirs, water tanks or pumps, and the like;
   F.   The elevators, garbage or trash incinerators, and, in general, all
devices or installations existing for common use; and
   G.   All other elements of the building rationally of common use or
necessary to its existence, upkeep or safety.
   CONDOMINIUM DEVELOPMENT OR PROJECT: The sale of or plan by an owner and/or
developer to sell or offer for sale residential condominium units, commercial
condominium units or business condominium units, or any combination thereof, in
an existing building or any modification or reconstruction of an existing
building.
   CONDOMINIUM OR SUBDIVISION PLAT: The plat of survey of the village
establishing the condominium units, accessory units and/or common elements.
   CONDOMINIUM UNIT: An area identified as such in the declaration and on the
condominium plat and shall include all improvements contained within the area,
except those excluded in the declaration.
   CONVERSION, CONVERT (Or Other Like Words): The offering for sale by an owner
and/or developer or their agent of a condominium unit that was previously a
rental unit or a building containing such units that were previously rental
units.
   DEVELOPER: Any person or entity undertaking to develop a condominium unit or
building by conversion.
   OFFERING: Any inducement, solicitation, advertisement, publication or
announcement to the general public to encourage a person to acquire a
condominium unit in a condominium project.
   OWNER OR UNIT OWNER: The person or persons whose estates or interests,
individually or collectively, aggregate fee simple absolute ownership of a
unit.
   PERSON: A natural individual, corporation, partnership, trustee or other
legal entity capable of holding title to real property.
   PRELIMINARY PROPERTY REPORT AND/OR PROPERTY REPORT: All that information
required by the property reports in accordance with section
4-9-6 of this chapter.
   PROPERTY AND/OR BUILDING: All structures and the lot occupied or utilized by
all structures in or on which any condominium project is proposed.
   PROSPECTIVE PURCHASER: A person who investigates the condominium project
site for the purpose of inspection for possible purchase.
   SITE: Any land unit on which a part of the condominium is located. (Ord. 07-
11, 5-1-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq.
4-9-2: BUILDING PLANS AND SUBDIVISION PLATS:
Building plans for any conversion into condominium units and a subdivision plat
of any conversion into or construction of condominium units shall be submitted
to the village's building commissioner for approval prior to issuance of any
building permits. (Ord. 07-11, 5-1-2007)
4-9-3: CONDOMINIUM PLAT AND PLAN APPROVAL; RECORDING:
No condominium plat shall be recorded without the prior approval of the
building department, and no permits shall be issued for the construction or
conversion of the units without approval of the plat and building plans. (Ord.
07-11, 5-1-2007)
4-9-4: CERTIFICATE OF CODE COMPLIANCE AND CODE INSPECTIONS:
   A.   No unit in any condominium converted, remodeled, refurbished or
upgraded in any manner after the effective date of this chapter may be sold,
offered for sale "as is", transferred or occupied unless a certificate of code
compliance has been issued by the building commissioner stating that said
condominium unit complies with the conversion element provisions of this
chapter and the village's other applicable zoning and building requirements.
   B.   A developer intending to convert property to a condominium development
and/or offer an existing apartment for sale as a proposed condominium unit
shall file with the building commissioner a written notice of intent to
convert. The written notice shall include, but is not limited to:
      1.   A current survey of the subject property;
      2.   The property's address and a description of the subject units;
      3.   Names, addresses and telephone numbers of any developers, architects
and/or contractors involved with the project;
      4.   "As built" drawings and a site development plan certified by a
registered architect and containing details of implementation, including, but
not limited to, phases of renovation, sales and occupancy;
      5.   Any such other information regarding the condition of proposed
development of the property as the building commissioner shall reasonably
request.
   C.   A code inspection of the property, including all projected condominium
units and common elements and facilities, shall be scheduled by agreement
between the developer and the building commissioner when the notice of intent
to convert is received. The inspection shall include compliance with all
applicable zoning, building and/or other life safety codes and an evaluation of
interior common areas to determine the amount of work required, if any, to
bring these areas into compliance with village codes. All items identified as
requiring repair and/or replacement shall be completed by the property owner or
developer prior to submitting the subject property to the provisions of the
condominium property act of Illinois 1 .
   D.   The building commissioner shall issue a written code inspection report
after any inspection or reinspection and immediately mail a copy to the
applicant at the address provided. The inspection fee for each inspection and/
or any reinspection shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per unit.
   E.   No certificate of code compliance shall be issued, no sale of a unit
shall be made, and no condominium plat approved where the requirements of any
village ordinance pertaining to zoning, building or subdivision are not being
complied with for the property being converted.
   F.   The village's issuance of a certificate of code compliance shall not be
deemed a finding that the village has in any way approved the condominium
project or guaranteed the subject property's condition or suitability or
fitness for the purpose for which the property is being sold or transferred.
(Ord. 07-11, 5-1-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq.
4-9-5: BUILDING PERMITS:
Building permits for the individual units and for common areas shall be issued
separately. The fees due for building permits shall be assessed and paid as
prescribed in this title. Fees for building permits shall be assessed
independent of any fees for inspections and/or reinspections of individual
units or common areas. (Ord. 07-11, 5-1-2007)
4-9-6: PROPERTY REPORT:
It shall be unlawful for any developer to offer rental units for sale as
condominium units in any development consisting of more than four (4) units
until such time as all prospective purchasers are provided with a preliminary
property report and, forty five (45) days prior to the closing of the first
unit, a final property report, in accordance with this section.
   A.   A preliminary property report, to be provided to each prospective
purchaser at the same time that letters of intent are issued, shall contain the
following:
      1.   Name of building, address and number of units;
      2.   Developer's name, address and telephone number;
      3.   Prices of condominium units and preliminary declaration;
      4.   Estimated monthly assessment and taxes on each unit, based on the
previous year's tax bill. If the units have not been assessed separately,
estimated taxes on each unit may be stated.
      5.   Proposed financing of each unit (subject to approval by lending
institution at time of closing), including percent of price required for down
payment; number of years required to repay the loan; interest rate; service
charge, if any, payable at closing; and total monthly payment, if financed by
the developer.
      6.   Individual descriptions of personal property that may be included in
the sale, including an estimate of the age of each item. Personal property
shall include, but not be limited to, refrigerators, ovens or ranges, garbage
disposals, dishwashers, washing machines, clothes dryers, unit air conditioners
or unit heaters and/or furnaces, decorating, window treatments and floor
coverings.
      7.   Maintenance and amenity costs covered by monthly assessment.
      8.   Maintenance and amenity costs that are not covered by the monthly
assessment for which optional charges are or may be levied.
      9.   The time and circumstances in which the initial board of managers
shall be established.
      10.   A brief description of rights and obligations retained by the
sellers and the duration of such rights and obligations.
      11.   Rights and obligations of unit purchasers after closing and prior
to election of the initial board of managers.
      12.   Description of the condominium's physical properties, including:
         a.   For buildings being converted, an engineering survey of the
building's operating and other systems, completed within one year of the first
offer of sale.
         b.   Description of the age and operating condition of the heating,
air conditioning, water and water heating, sewer service, elevators, and all
other common elements, including a description of provisions, or lack thereof,
made by the developer for the condominium unit owners' pets.
      13.   Description of existing contracts for management and other
services, including:
         a.   Length and terms of contract;
         b.   Location and availability for review;
         c.   List of all interests of developer, directly or indirectly in all
such service contracts.
      14.   Explanation of the buyer's cancellation rights and the seller's
procedures.
      15.   Statement of all warranties included with the unit.
      16.   The following statement in a type size and style equal to at least
20-point bold type:
THIS INFORMATION IS PROVIDED TO PROSPECTIVE CONDOMINIUM UNIT OWNERS IN ADDITION
TO THE LEGAL DOCUMENTS REQUIRED UNDER VILLAGE AND ILLINOIS LAW. THIS IS NOT
INTENDED TO BE A FULL STATEMENT AS TO [Name of Development].
FULL DETAILS ARE SET FORTH IN THE PROPERTY REPORT AND CONDOMINIUM DECLARATION.
IT IS STRONGLY RECOMMENDED THAT THESE GUIDELINES AND ALL LEGAL DOCUMENTS ARE
REVIEWED BY PROSPECTIVE BUYERS AND THEIR ATTORNEYS AND OTHER ADVISORS PRIOR TO
ENTERING INTO A REAL ESTATE SALES AGREEMENT.
   B.   The property report shall be certified by the developer or his or her
agent and shall contain the following:
      1.   A statement indicating name and address of the developer and owner,
if different, including all partners of a partnership or all officers and
directors of a corporation as well as the following:
         a.   The name and address of the developer and legal and beneficial
owner of the parcel, if different, including all general partners of a
partnership and officers and directors of a corporation.
         b.   All persons with a direct material financial interest in the
property, including interim and permanent mortgage lenders secured by a blanket
encumbrance.
         c.   The principal attorneys, accountants, architect, engineer and
contractor for the property.
      2.   A description of the property and improvements, including the
following:
         a.   Map or plat showing size and dimensions of the condominium
project, together with all improvements, including recreational facilities,
proposed construction and present and planned location of streets and roads.
The share of ownership of each unit in the common elements shall be indicated.
         b.   Description of the condominium units offered and the nature and
extent of individual ownership in such condominium units, including the
percentage of former renters who have purchased or contracted to purchase a
condominium unit when the property is a conversion, if known. If such units are
owned in trust by nominees, the beneficiaries or principals shall be named.
         c.   Description, nature and ownership of all property and facilities
on the site which are not part of the condominium.
         d.   Description of all existing and proposed recreational facilities
and other such facilities within the condominium project, including the
projected dates of their completion.
         e.   Location, nature and ownership of streets and roads on and
contiguous to the site.
         f.   Drawings, architectural plans or other suitable documents setting
forth the necessary information for location, maintenance and repair of all
condominium facilities and equipment to the extent these documents exist. Such
items shall be incorporated in the property report by reference, located at the
sales office site or construction office site and turned over to the board of
managers upon transfer of control by the developer.
         g.   Projected initiation and completion dates for proposed
construction, renovation or conversion.
         h.   Use permitted for individual condominium units by the
declaration, bylaws of the condominium association or organization and
applicable zoning provisions.
         i.   Statement as to whether or not the condominium units may be
rented by the owner.
         j.   Statement of title, listing all restrictions of record and the
condition of title.
      3.   Method and timing of transfer of control over the condominium
project to the board of managers and the nature and extent of an interest
retained by the developer.
      4.   A statement of all financial aspects of the condominium project,
including, but not limited to:
         a.   Name of construction mortgagor or the interim mortgagor;
         b.   Institution offering long term mortgage financing, if available,
and terms and conditions of such mortgage.
      5.   Statement disclosing the existence of penalty if the construction,
renovation, or conversion or completion date is not met and the additional
costs to be imposed if such date is not met.
      6.   Nature and extent of any protection of a purchaser if the developer
defaults on blanket encumbrance, unless the developer shall have furnished to
the purchaser a noncancelable bond executed by a surety company authorized to
do business in the state of Illinois, which has consented to be sued in this
state, indemnifying a prospective purchaser against the loss of the deposit or
deposits against payment for the unit (earnest money) except by reason of the
purchaser's default. If the developer has made no such arrangement, the
following statement must be inserted, in a type size and style equal to at
least 10-point bold type:
THE DEVELOPER HAS MADE NO ARRANGEMENTS TO PROTECT THE PURCHASER OF A
CONDOMINIUM UNIT FROM THE DEVELOPER'S POSSIBLE DEFAULT ON A BLANKET
ENCUMBRANCE. ACCORDINGLY, THERE IS A RISK OF LOSING YOUR FINANCIAL INTEREST IN
THE EVENT OF THE DEVELOPER'S FAILURE OR BANKRUPTCY.
      7.   Statement of any pending litigation which would affect the
condominium or the developer's ability to convey clear title.
      8.   Statement of the current taxes and estimated possible changes in the
tax situation of the condominium project which buyers may encounter during the
first two (2) years.
      9.   Copies of the sales documents and literature, including, but not
limited to:
         a.   Basic purchase contract form being used by developer;
         b.   Forms of conveyance;
         c.   Deed of trust, mortgage and promissory note;
         d.   Statement of sales prices, terms and options;
         e.   Statement of terms and conditions of sale, including estimated
closing and settlement costs, taxes and expected special assessments levied
either by the condominium or a governmental entity.
         f.   Statement of monthly payments, itemized as to principal,
interest, taxes, utilities, and all other payments for a period of one year
from the expected date of closing of the sale.
      10.   Summary of past operating history of the project, if any.
      11.   Copies of all required documents numbered and indexed in such a
manner as the developer may select, so as to permit ready reference thereto:
         a.   The declaration and plat;
         b.   The articles of incorporation or charter of the condominium
association;
         c.   The bylaws and regulations of the condominium association;
         d.   Any leases of real or personal property, applicable to the
condominium, of more than one year in duration;
         e.   Any management contract, employment contract, insurance policy,
or other contract, of more than one year in duration, affecting the use,
maintenance or access to all or part of the condominium;
         f.   Coverage and amounts of condominium insurance policies.
      12.   A statement of management and expected operation costs of
condominium, including:
         a.   Name of management agent, if any, and the services the agent will
perform;
         b.   Length of term of any management contract and charges and
circumstances, if any, under which the charges may be increased;
         c.   The conditions, if any, under which the contract may be canceled
or terminated;
         d.   Statement disclosing any relationship between the developer and
the management firm and their respective corporate officers and controlling
interests.
      13.   Copy of estimated operating budget for the condominium project,
projected for a period of one year from the expected date that control of the
condominium common elements would pass to the board of managers, including
monthly payments to be prorated to each condominium unit for maintenance and/or
management of condominium common elements and charges for use of recreational
and other facilities. In particular, the operating budget shall include, but
not be limited to, the following:
         a.   Operating Costs: Utilities, heating fuels, janitorial services,
trash and garbage disposal, ground and building maintenance, security,
maintenance and operation of recreational and other facilities, building
insurance, elevator maintenance, sidewalks and street maintenance, and other
operating costs.
         b.   Management Costs: Legal and accounting services, bookkeeping
services, and management fees.
         c.   Reserve Costs: Reserve for improvements, reserve for unexpected
repair work, and reserve for replacement and upkeep of common elements and
facilities, including basis upon which reserves are calculated. If no reserve
is provided for any one or more of the costs listed in this subsection B13c,
the following statement must be inserted in the property report in a type size
and style equal to at least 10-point bold type:
THE DEVELOPER HAS NOT PROVIDED A RESERVE IN ITS BUDGET FOR CERTAIN POSSIBLE
FUTURE COSTS ON THE CONDOMINIUM. ACCORDINGLY, IT MAY BE NECESSARY TO PROVIDE
FOR A SPECIAL ASSESSMENT TO ALL CONDOMINIUM UNIT OWNERS TO PAY FOR SUCH COSTS
SHOULD THEY OCCUR.
      14.   Alternative provisions if an insufficient number of units are sold
to cover the proposed operations and maintenance budget.
      15.   In the case of a conversion from rental or other legal status to
condominiums, a report from a qualified licensed structural engineer or
registered architect, not associated with the developer/builder, stating his or
her opinion concerning the condition and the rated life and expected useful
life of the roof, foundation, external and supporting walls, mechanical,
electrical, plumbing and structural elements and all other common facilities,
together with an estimate of repair and replacement costs, at current market
prices, which shall indicate what the cost per category of unit would be if the
unit owners were assessed for the estimated cost. This report shall include the
approximate dates of installation of the facilities listed above and the dates
of major repairs to such facilities. There shall also be attached a list of
violations of the village of Worth's building code, as received from the
village's building commissioner or, if no notice of such violations has been
received, the report shall so state.
      16.   If there are any restrictions upon the free sale, transfer,
conveyance, encumbrance or leasing of a unit, then a statement in bold face
type or capital letters in substantially the following form shall be included.
"THE SALE, LEASE OR TRANSFER OF YOUR UNIT IS RESTRICTED OR CONTROLLED."
Immediately following this statement, there shall appear a reference to the
documents, articles, paragraphs, or pages in the disclosure materials where the
restriction, limitation or control on the sale, lease or transfer of units is
set forth or described in detail.
      17.   Each property report shall contain on the first page the following
warning in capital letters, in a type size and style equal to at least 10-point
bold type:
VILLAGE LAW SPECIFICALLY PROHIBITS ANY REPRESENTATION TO THE EFFECT THAT THE
VILLAGE HAS PASSED UPON THE MERITS OF OR GIVEN APPROVAL TO MAKE OR CAUSE TO BE
MADE TO ANY PROSPECTIVE PURCHASER ANY REPRESENTATIONS THAT DIFFER FROM THE
STATEMENTS IN THIS PROPERTY REPORT. ORAL REPRESENTATIONS CANNOT BE RELIED UPON
AS CORRECTLY STATING THE REPRESENTATIONS OF THE DEVELOPER AND ARE NOT BINDING
ON THE DEVELOPER. PLEASE REFER TO THE PROPERTY REPORT FOR CORRECT
REPRESENTATIONS.
      18.   A senior executive officer of the developer shall sign the property
report and affirm that it and any supplements, modifications and amendments are
true, full, complete and correct. (Ord. 07-11, 5-1-2007)
4-9-7: CONDOMINIUM REQUIREMENTS:
All new condominiums or conversions into condominiums shall follow the
regulations set forth in the condominium property act of Illinois 1  and the
2003 international building code, published by the International Code Council
and adopted as the village's building code, and additionally shall comply with
the following:
   A.   All condominiums shall comply with current regulations, including open
space, landscaping and parking requirements, for the land use for which the
property is zoned. All parking stalls and aisles shall comply with the minimum
dimensions set forth in the zoning provisions of this code. All traffic flow
for common element driveways and parking lots shall be subject to review and
acceptance by the village's building commissioner and fire chief.
   B.   The building to be converted must be inspected for termite infestation,
and termites must be eradicated if necessary. A certificate of compliance with
this subsection must be filed with the village's building commissioner before a
certificate of occupancy is issued.
   C.   At the time the "as built" drawings are submitted for approval, a
certificate issued by a licensed structural engineer or inspector shall be
presented to the village's building commissioner certifying that the building's
structural features, including the foundation, roof or roof coverings, doors,
windows, exterior trim and/or siding, public walks, elevators, fire escapes,
gutters or downspouts, and/or balconies or porches, are sound, in good repair
and can provide at least ten (10) years of remaining serviceable life for the
use intended.
   D.   All mechanical systems, including, but not limited to, heating systems
or furnaces, air conditioning or cooling systems, water heaters, plumbing
systems, and ventilation systems, must be replaced unless they are inspected
and certified by an expert in such systems that they are functioning, in good
repair and can provide adequate service for the use intended by each system.
   E.   The installation of washing machines and clothes dryers in individual
condominium units is prohibited unless said installation complies with all
applicable building codes. Prior to installation, the developer(s) must certify
that renovation of the units will include properly installed ventilation, gas
and electrical systems necessary for the safe operation and function of such
appliances. All laundry room appliances in excess of eight (8) years of age and
located in a central, common laundry room shared by condominium residents,
shall be replaced with new appliances.
   F.   Common garbage and trash disposal containers shall be provided in
accordance with the village's regulations for multi-family developments.
   G.   Any residential rental property undergoing a condominium conversion
shall have fire alarm detection systems with twenty four (24) hour monitoring,
and/or smoke detection systems installed or modified to meet current
regulations in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA)
code for safety to life from fire in buildings and structures, as published by
the NFPA.
      1.   Smoke detectors shall be installed on each level of the condominium
unit, in any room used for sleeping purposes, and within fifteen feet (15') of
any room used for sleeping purposes. The smoke detectors shall be AC powered
with battery backup. The smoke detectors shall be wired together to activate
simultaneously in case of a fire.
      2.   In buildings with less than six (6) units, only the installation of
smoke detectors, as provided in subsection G1 of this section, shall be
required.
      3.   Fire sprinkler systems shall be installed in all mechanical rooms.
The systems shall be approved by the village's fire chief prior to its
installation and shall be designed to alert a twenty four (24) hour watch
location in the event of an emergency.
   H.   Means of egress; fire extinguisher quantities and/or locations; exit
signage; emergency lighting; fire resistance, flame spread and/or smoke
development provisions for doors, door assemblies and/or corridors shall be
evaluated and installed or upgraded to comply with the NFPA life safety code.
   I.   All condominium associations shall be responsible for traffic and
parking control, snow removal, signing, sewers, water lines and lighting. The
village shall have the right to enter such common areas for the purposes of
providing police or fire protection and to enforce its ordinances. Such common
areas shall remain the property of the condominium association and the village
shall not accept a dedication of these elements or be responsible for
maintenance. The association shall maintain the public areas and any parkways
in a clean condition free of debris, leaves or trash. (Ord. 07-11, 5-1-2007)

CHAPTER 10
DANGEROUS BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-10-1: Definitions
4-10-2: Prohibition
4-10-3: Abatement
4-10-4: Lien
4-10-5: Payment
4-10-6: Foreclosure Of Lien
4-10-7: Placarding Of Condemned Premises
4-10-8: Prohibited Use
4-10-9: Service On Occupant
4-10-10: Failure To Comply With Dangerous Building Regulations And Prohibitions
4-10-11: Closing Of Vacant Structures; Temporary Measures
4-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
The term "dangerous building" as used in this chapter is hereby to mean and
include:
   A.   Any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which is
dangerous to the public health because of its condition and which may cause or
aid in the spread of disease or injury to the health of the occupants of its or
neighboring structures;
   B.   Any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which, because of
faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is
especially liable to fire and constitutes or creates a fire hazard;
   C.   Any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which, by reason
of faulty construction or any other cause is liable to cause injury or damage
by collapsing or by a collapse or fall of any part of such structure;
   D.   Any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which, because of
its condition or because of lack of doors or windows is available to and
frequented by malefactors or disorderly persons who are not lawful occupants of
such structure;
   E.   Any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which have been
damaged by fire, wind, or other causes so as to have become dangerous to life,
safety, morals, or the general health and welfare of the occupants or the
people of the village;
   F.   Any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which have become
or are so dilapidated, decayed, unsafe, unsanitary or which so utterly fail to
provide the amenities essential to decent living that they are unfit for human
habitation or are likely to cause sickness or disease, so as to cause injury to
the health, morals, safety or general welfare of those living therein;
   G.   Those which have parts thereof which are so attached that they may fall
and injure members of the public or property;
   H.   Those which, because of their condition, are unsafe, unsanitary, or
dangerous to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of the people of
this village;
   I.   Those buildings existing in violation of any provision of the building
code of this village, or any provision of the fire prevention code, or any
other ordinances of the village;
   J.   Those buildings which are uncompleted or abandoned. (Ord. 09-22, 9-1-
2009)
4-10-2: PROHIBITION:
Any dangerous building in the village is hereby declared to be a nuisance. It
shall be unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any dangerous building
in the village and it shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant, or person in
custody of any dangerous building to permit the same to remain in a dangerous
condition or to occupy such building or permit it to be occupied while it is or
remains in a dangerous condition. (Ord. 09-22, 9-1-2009)
4-10-3: ABATEMENT:
Whenever the building commissioner or designee, shall be of the opinion that
any building or structure in the village is a dangerous building, he shall file
a written statement to this effect with the village clerk. The clerk shall
thereupon cause written notice to be served upon the owner thereof and upon the
occupant thereof, if any, by registered mail or by personal service. Such
notices shall state that the building has been declared to be in a dangerous
condition, and that such dangerous condition must be removed or remedied by
repairing or altering the building or by demolishing it; and that the condition
must be remedied at once. Such notice shall be served upon the proper parties
not less than fifteen (15) days before the village shall file application with
the circuit court for an order authorizing the demolition or repair of said
building.
In the event that the building is not demolished or repaired or altered within
the fifteen (15) day period of time elapsing from the date of the service of
notice, then the village shall institute application before the Cook County
circuit court requesting an order authorizing the demolition, alteration, or
repair of said building premises and the cost of such entailments shall be
recovered from the owner or owners of such real estate and shall be a lien
thereon. (Ord. 09-22, 9-1-2009)
4-10-4: LIEN:
The cost of repair, demolition, vacation, or enclosure shall be recoverable
from the owner or owners of such real estate shall be a lien upon the premises.
A bill representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the services
shall be presented to the owner. If this bill is not paid within thirty (30)
days of submission of the bill, a notice of lien of the cost and expense
thereof incurred by the village shall be a lien thereon, which lien shall be
subordinate to all prior existing liens and encumbrances; provided that within
sixty (60) days after said cost and expense is incurred, the village or person
performing the service by authority of the village, in his or its own names,
shall file notices of lien in the office of the Cook County recorder of deeds.
The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out:
   A.   A description of the real estate sufficient for identification
therefor;
   B.   The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or
payable for the service; and
   C.   The date or dates when said cost and expense was incurred by the
village.
Upon payment of said cost and expense by the owner of or persons interested in
said property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released
by the village or person in whose name(s) the lien has been filed and said
release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. The
lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose. (Ord. 09-22, 9-1-2009)
4-10-5: PAYMENT:
Notice of such lien claim shall be mailed to the owner of the premises if his
address is known. If address is unknown, notice mailed to the person in whose
name the premises was last assessed is sufficient notice. Upon payment of the
cost and expense after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be
released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the
release shall be filed of record in the same manner as filing notice of the
lien. (Ord. 09-22, 9-1-2009)
4-10-6: FORECLOSURE OF LIEN:
Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges shall be sold for nonpayment of
the same, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory
liens. Such foreclosure shall be in the name of the village, after lien is in
effect for sixty (60) days. (Ord. 09-22, 9-1-2009)
4-10-7: PLACARDING OF CONDEMNED PREMISES:
Upon the instance of the initiation of an injunction involving a condemnation
action, the building commissioner shall placard the subject premises of the
condemnation action; the premises shall be posted in a conspicuous place near
the main entrance of such building or structure; and if no such entrance
exists, then at a conspicuous place upon the premises.
The notice of condemnation shall be at least nine inches (9") in height and
fourteen inches (14") in width and at the top thereof in large letters shall
state "Notice Of Violation, Condemned As Unfit For Human Occupancy Or Use By
Order Of The Building Commissioner Of The Village Of Worth, Illinois", and may
contain such other information or instructions as the building commissioner
deems necessary in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare. (Ord.
09-22, 9-1-2009)
4-10-8: PROHIBITED USE:
Any person who shall occupy a condemned and placarded premises or structure or
part thereof, or shall use placarded equipment, and any owner or any person
responsible for the premises who shall let anyone occupy such a placarded
premises shall be liable for the penalties provided by this code. (Ord. 09-22,
9-1-2009)
4-10-9: SERVICE ON OCCUPANT:
Upon the instance of the initiation of a condemnation action, the building
commissioner shall serve written notice of condemnation upon the occupant of
the subject building or part thereof ordering the condemned premises to be
vacated.
   A.   If the occupant is other than the owner or person responsible for
remedying the objectionable condition, a reasonable time to vacate the premises
after noncompliance shall be stated.
   B.   Owners or persons responsible for compliance shall vacate the premises
at the time stated in the notice of violation for correction of the defects if
there is failure to comply. (Ord. 09-22, 9-1-2009)
4-10-10: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH DANGEROUS BUILDING REGULATIONS AND
PROHIBITIONS:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be guilty of a petty offense punishable fine a fine in the amount
set forth in the Village Fine Schedule. If more than one provision, standard or
requirement of this code is violated, then each such provision, standard or
requirement violated shall be considered to be a separate offense, Each day
that a violation occurs or continues, after due notice has been served shall be
considered a separate offense for which the violator shall be liable to the
maximum penalty herein specified for each violation. (Ord. 2014-16, 3-4-2014;
amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
4-10-11: CLOSING OF VACANT STRUCTURES; TEMPORARY MEASURES:
If a structure or a part thereof is vacant and unfit for human habitation,
occupancy or use and is not in danger of structural collapse, upon the instance
of a condemnation action the building commissioner shall proceed to placard the
premises in the manner prescribed above and may order the structure closed up
as a temporary measure so as not to be an attractive nuisance to youngsters.
Upon failure of the owner to so close up the premises within the time specified
in the order, the building commissioner may cause the premises to be so closed
through any available public agency or by contract or arrangement by private
persons and the cost thereof shall be charged against the real estate upon
which the structure is located and shall be a lien upon such real estate, which
lien may be foreclosed in a manner similar to the foreclosure of real estate
liens in real estate mortgage foreclosure actions or actions to foreclose
mechanic's liens in the state of Illinois. (Ord. 09-22, 9-1-2009)
CHAPTER 11
CRIME FREE RENTAL HOUSING
SECTION:
4-11-1: Intent
4-11-2: Definitions
4-11-3: Crime Free Lease Addendum
4-11-4: Chronic Nuisance Property
4-11-5: Procedures
4-11-6: Service
4-11-7: Administrative Hearing
4-11-1: INTENT:
It has been determined to be in the best interests of the residents of the
village to implement a program in order to work with all landlords to eliminate
nuisances in order to safeguard their properties and create a peaceful and safe
environment in the village. It is the responsibility of the landlord to take
any and all actions permitted by law to eliminate nuisances. (Ord. 13-01, 1-15-
2013)
4-11-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   CHIEF OF POLICE: The chief of police of the village of Worth or designee.
   CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTY: Property upon which two (2) or more events of
nuisance activities have occurred within a six (6) month period that have been
independently investigated by any law enforcement agency.
   CONTACT: Any communication made by a tenant, landlord, guest, neighbor,
owner, person in charge, or other person to police or other emergency services.
   CONTROL: The ability to regulate, restrain, dominate, counteract, or govern
conduct that occurs on that property.
   CRIMINAL ACTIVITY: A violation of the criminal code of 2012 1 , the cannabis
control act 2 , the Illinois controlled substances act 3 , or the
methamphetamine control and community protection act 4 .
   DISABILITY: A person:
   A.   With a physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one or
more of such person's major life activities;
   B.   With a record of having such impairment; or
   C.   Being regarded as having such an impairment, but such term does not
include current, illegal use of or addiction to a controlled substance, as
defined in the controlled substances act (21 USC 802).
   DOMESTIC VIOLENCE: Physical abuse, harassment, intimidation of a dependent,
interference with personal liberty or wilful deprivation, excluding reasonable
direction of a minor child by a parent or person in loco parentis, by a "family
or household member" as that term is defined in section 103 of the Illinois
domestic violence act of 1986 5 .
   NUISANCE ACTIVITY: Any one of the following activities, behaviors or
conduct, as defined by federal, state or village ordinance, but excluding
activities, behaviors, or conduct that constitute nuisance activity exceptions
as set forth in this section:
   A.   Disorderly conduct as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/26-1.
   B.   Unlawful use of weapons as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
24-1 et seq.
   C.   Mob action as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/25-1.
   D.   Discharge of a firearm as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
24-1.2 and 1.5.
   E.   Gambling as defined by 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-1.
   F.   Possession, manufacture, or delivery of controlled substances as
defined by 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/401 et seq.
   G.   Public indecency as defined by 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-30.
   H.   Assault or battery or any related offense as defined in 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/12-1 et seq.
   I.   Sexual abuse or related offense as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-1.50 et seq.
   J.   Prostitution as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-14 et
seq.
   K.   Criminal damage to property as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/21-1 et seq.
   L.   Possession, cultivation, manufacture, or delivery of cannabis as
defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq.
   M.   Illegal consumption or possession of alcohol as defined in 235 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1 et seq.
   N.   Criminal housing management as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/12-5.1.
   O.   Structure unfit for human occupancy as defined in the Worth property
maintenance code.
   P.   Unsafe structure as defined in the Worth property maintenance code.
   Q.   Unlawful structure as defined in the Worth property maintenance code.
   R.   Multiple violations of the Worth property maintenance code continuing
after disposition of a complaint for those violations.
   S.   Activity that constitutes a violation of a felony or class A
misdemeanor pursuant to a federal or Illinois statute.
   T.   A violation of section
 8-3-6, "Noise", of this code.
   U.   A violation of section
10-4-4, "Disorderly Houses", of this code.
   V.   A violation of a chapter of this code, adopting class A misdemeanors
under Illinois state statutes.
   NUISANCE ACTIVITY EXCEPTIONS: The following behavior or conduct shall not
constitute a nuisance activity:
   A.   Contacting the police or other emergency services if:
      1.   The contact was made with the intent to prevent or respond to
domestic violence or sexual violence;
      2.   The intervention or emergency assistance was needed to respond to or
prevent domestic violence or sexual violence; or
      3.   The contact was made by, on behalf of, or otherwise concerns an
individual with a disability and the purpose of the contact was related to that
individual's disability.
   B.   An incident or incidents of actual or threatened domestic violence or
sexual violence against a person, person in charge, owner, or guest on the
property; or
   C.   Criminal activity or a violation of this chapter occurring on the
property that is directly related to domestic violence or sexual violence,
engaged in by a person, person in charge, owner, or guest against a person,
person in charge, owner or guest.
   OWNER: Any person, partnership, land trust, or corporation having any legal
or equitable interest in or control of property. Owner includes, but is not
limited to:
A mortgagee in possession in who is vested with all or part of the legal title
to the property or, all or part of the beneficial ownership and the rights to
the present use and enjoyment of the premises.
An occupant who can control what occurs on the property.
Any person acting as an agent of an owner.
   PERMIT: To suffer, allow, consent to, and acquiesce by failure to prevent,
or expressly assent or agree to the doing of an act.
   PERSON: Any natural person, association, partnership, corporation, trust, or
other entity capable of owning, occupying, or using property in the village.
   PERSON IN CHARGE: Any person in actual or constructive possession of a
property, including, but not limited to, an owner, occupant of property under
his or her ownership or control.
   PROPERTY: Any real property, including land and that which is affixed,
incidental, or pertinent to land, including, but not limited to, any premises,
room, house, building, or structure, or any separate part or portion thereof,
whether permitted or not.
   SEXUAL VIOLENCE: Any act of sexual assault, sexual abuse, or stalking of an
adult or minor child, including, but not limited to, nonconsensual sexual
conduct or nonconsensual sexual penetration as defined in the civil no contact
order act 6  and the offenses of stalking, aggravated stalking, criminal sexual
assault, aggravated criminal sexual assault, predatory criminal sexual assault
of a child, criminal sexual abuse, and aggravated criminal sexual abuse as
those offenses are described in the criminal code of 2012 7 .
   SUBSIDIZED HOUSING: The definition provided under subsection (a) of section
9-119 of the Illinois code of civil procedure 8 . (Ord. 2015-46, 10-20-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
2 2. 720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.
3 3. 720 ILCS 570/100 et seq.
4 1. 720 ILCS 646/1 et seq.
5 2. 750 ILCS 60/103(6).
6 1. 740 ILCS 22/101 et seq.
7 2. 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
8 3. 735 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.
4-11-3: CRIME FREE LEASE ADDENDUM:
Any owner, agent, management company or operator of any residential rental
property is required to utilize a crime free lease addendum in the form
provided by the chief of police as a part of every lease executed by an owner,
agent, management company or operator. Said addendum shall state that any
nuisance activity (including criminal activity) facilitated by or permitted by
the renter, member of the renter's household, guest, invitee or any party under
the control of the renter shall constitute a lease violation. The owner, agent
or operator shall have the authority pursuant to said addendum to initiate
eviction proceedings in accordance with the laws of this state regarding
forcible entry and detainer. (Ord. 2015-46, 10-20-2015)
4-11-4: CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTY:
   A.   Unlawful To Remain Chronic Nuisance: It shall be unlawful for any
property within the village to become or remain a chronic nuisance property in
violation of this chapter.
   B.   Owner Responsibilities: It shall be unlawful for any owner, agent,
management company, or operator of any residential property to:
      1.   Permit a property to become a chronic nuisance property; or
      2.   Allow a property to continue as a chronic nuisance property.
   C.   Violation: Each day that a violation of this chapter continues shall be
considered a separate and distinct offense.
   D.   Prohibitions: The village shall not: 1) assess fees or fines; 2)
revoke, suspend or nonrenew any license or permit required for the rental or
occupancy of any dwelling unit; 3) terminate or deny a subsidized housing
contract or housing subsidy; or 4) terminate or nonrenew a residential lease
agreement based on a nuisance activity exception undertaken or committed by a
person in charge or an owner.
   E.   Rights Reserved: Nothing contained in this section: 1) limits the
enforcement of section 15.2 of the emergency telephone system act 1 , article
26 of the criminal code of 2012 2 , or article IX of the Illinois code of civil
procedure 3 ; 2) prohibits the village from enacting or enforcing ordinances to
impose penalties on the basis of the underlying criminal activity or an
ordinance violation that does not qualify as a nuisance activity exception and
to the extent otherwise permitted by state and federal law; or 3) limits or
prohibits the eviction of or imposition of penalties against the perpetrator of
the domestic violence, sexual violence, or other criminal activity. (Ord. 2015-
46, 10-20-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 50 ILCS 750/0.01 et seq.
2 2. 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
3 3. 735 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.
4-11-5: PROCEDURES:
When the chief of police or designee, receives one or more police reports
documenting the occurrence of a nuisance activity on or within a single-family
property or a dwelling unit, the chief of police shall independently review
such reports to determine whether they describe nuisance activities. Upon such
findings the chief of police, or designee, may either request a meeting with
the person in charge of the property or issue a notice of ordinance violation
to the taxpayer of record of such property, which notice shall include the
following:
   A.   The street address or legal description sufficient for identification
of the property.
   B.   A statement that the police department has information that the
property may be a chronic nuisance property, with a list of the nuisance
activities that may exist or that have occurred and a copy of any code
violations which have been adjudicated.
   C.   Date, time and place of the hearing on the alleged ordinance violation
of this chapter as permitting or allowing a chronic nuisance property.
   D.   Nothing in this section shall prohibit, prevent, limit, or inhibit the
village from seeking relief at law, in equity, or otherwise against a chronic
nuisance property, its owner, person in charge, and/or tenant. (Ord. 2015-46,
10-20-2015)
4-11-6: SERVICE:
   A.   Service shall be made either personally or by first class mail, postage
prepaid, return receipt requested, addressed to the person in charge at the
address of the property believed to be a chronic nuisance property, or such a
place which is likely to give notice to the person in charge.
   B.   A copy of the notice shall be either personally served or by first
class mail to the taxpayer of record at such address as shown on the tax rolls
of the county and the occupant, at the address of the property.
   C.   The failure of any person to receive notice that the property may be a
chronic nuisance property shall not invalidate or otherwise affect the
proceedings under this section. (Ord. 13-01, 1-15-2013)
4-11-7: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
   A.   A hearing before the village hearing officer shall be conducted in
accordance with section
1-4-4 of this code and shall show, by a preponderance of evidence, that the
property is a chronic nuisance property.
   B.   The village shall present evidence in support of its claim that the
property is a chronic nuisance property. The person in charge or the person in
charge's local representative shall be permitted to rebut such evidence.
   C.   At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a
determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing, whether or
not a violation exists. The determination shall be in writing and shall be
designated as the findings, decisions and order. The findings, decision and
order shall include the hearing officer's findings of fact, a decision whether
or not a violation exists based upon the finding of fact, and sanctioning the
person in charge or owner as specified in subsection D of this section, or
dismissing the case in the event a violation is not proved.
   D.   If the hearing officer makes a finding that a property was, or is, a
nuisance property, he or she may fine the person in charge of the owner of the
property if the owner is different than the person in charge, a fine according
to the Village Fine Schedule for each violation of this chapter. Each day a
nuisance activity occurs or continues shall be considered a separate and
distinct violation. The hearing officer may, at his or her discretion, impose
such a fine for each day the nuisance activity goes unabated. (Ord. 13-01, 1-
15-2013; amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
CHAPTER 12
RAIN BARRELS
SECTION:
4-12-1: Standards Adopted
4-12-2: Definitions
4-12-3: Type, Size, Number, And Location
4-12-4: Nuisance
4-12-5: Failure To Comply With Type, Size And Number Regulations Of Rain
Barrels
4-12-1: STANDARDS ADOPTED:
The following standards and requirements apply to the placement, use, and
maintenance of rain barrels in the village. (Ord. 2016-16, 6-21-2016)
4-12-2: DEFINITIONS:
   RAIN BARREL: A water receptacle located above ground and used to capture and
store rainwater runoff generated from impervious surfaces, including rooftops,
for landscaping, cleaning, and related household uses.
   ZONING LOT: As defined in section
 5-1-3 of this code. (Ord. 2016-16, 6-21-2016)
4-12-3: TYPE, SIZE, NUMBER, AND LOCATION:
   A.   Rain barrels shall have a secure lid and be located so as to receive
water from a downspout.
   B.   The opening at the top of a rain barrel shall be protected by a screen.
   C.   A rain barrel's capacity or volume shall not exceed sixty five (65)
gallons.
   D.   Rain barrels shall be equipped with an overflow hose allowing for the
release of excess water.
   E.   Water released from a rain barrel either intentionally or
unintentionally, including, without limitation, water released during an
overflow event, shall not adversely impact any property or right of way
adjacent to the lot on which the rain barrel is located.
   F.   A maximum of two (2) rain barrels may be located on a zoning lot. (Ord.
2016-16, 6-21-2016)
4-12-4: NUISANCE:
Rain barrels placed, used, or maintained in violation of this chapter are
declared to be a nuisance. (Ord. 2016-16, 6-21-2016)
4-12-5: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH TYPE, SIZE AND NUMBER REGULATIONS OF RAIN
BARRELS:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter or failing, neglecting, or
refusing to abate any nuisance created hereunder may be prosecuted through the
village's administrative adjudication system and is subject to penalties as
established pursuant to the Village Fine Schedule. The remedies identified in
this section are nonexclusive, and nothing stated herein shall limit, waive or
in any way reduce the remedies available to the village under law, at equity or
otherwise. (Ord. 2016-16, 6-21-2016; amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
