CHAPTER 1
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH
SECTION:
8-1-1: Establishment Of Department, Composition
8-1-2: Right Of Entry, Arrest Powers
8-1-3: Health Officer
8-1-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF DEPARTMENT, COMPOSITION:
There is hereby established an executive department of the village which shall
be known as the department of public health. It shall embrace the health
officer and such clerks and assistants as the president and board of trustees
may, by ordinance, provide. (1970 Code §21.16)
8-1-2: RIGHT OF ENTRY, ARREST POWERS:
For the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this code, in connection with
health and sanitation, the health officer, any inspector and other officers of
the department of public health shall be permitted to enter at any reasonable
hour, any premises, house, store, stable, manufacturing plant or any other
building and shall have the authority to arrest or cause to be arrested any
person who shall violate any of the health or sanitation provisions of this
code. (1970 Code §21.17)
8-1-3: HEALTH OFFICER:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the health officer to enforce all the laws of
the state, provisions of this code and other ordinances of the village in
relation to matters pertaining to the preservation of public health within the
village. He shall have the right to arrest or cause to be arrested any person
who violates any of the health provisions of this code. (1970 Code §21.19)
   B.   The health officer shall have and exercise general supervision over the
sanitary condition of the village. (1970 Code §21.20)
   C.   He shall give to the president and the officers in charge of all other
executive departments all such professional advice and information as they may
require with a view to the preservation of the public health. (1970 Code
§21.21)
CHAPTER 2
HEALTH REGULATIONS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Health Code
8-2-2: Places Of Public Assemblage
8-2-3: Contagious Diseases
8-2-4: Drinking Water
8-2-1: HEALTH CODE:
   A.   State Provisions Adopted: The 1991 Illinois department of public health
food service sanitation code is adopted by reference by the village.
   B.   Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of the code adopted in
subsection A of this section shall be fined pursuant to the Village Fine
Schedule, Appendix A, for each offense. Each day that a violation exists shall
constitute a new offense. (Ord. 92-17, 11-3-1992; amd. Ord. 2014-16, 3-4-2014;
Ord. 2025-10, 3-18-2025)
8-2-2: PLACES OF PUBLIC ASSEMBLAGE:
   A.   Sanitary Inspections: The health officer shall make, as often as
practicable, or cause to be made, a thorough inspection of the sanitary
condition of all hotels, lodging houses, theaters, public halls or other places
where public gatherings of any kind are held, drugstores, gasoline stations,
restaurants, bakeries, livery stables, feed barns and other places of business
located within the village which are licensed to sell milk, food products or
drugs in the village. He shall direct such improvements in the sanitary
conditions as, in his judgment, are necessary. (1970 Code §21.1; amd. 1995
Code)
   B.   Abatement, Failure To Comply: Whenever it shall come to the knowledge
of the department of public health that the condition of any building or
premises is injurious to the health or dangerous to the lives of the occupants
or of the public, the health officer shall make a thorough examination of the
building or premises and he shall direct and instruct the procedure for remedy
of such condition. If said condition is not remedied within a reasonable time,
he may suspend the license for ten (10) days pending final action by the
president and board of trustees as to whether or not to revoke the license.
(1970 Code §21.2)
   C.   Sanitary Premises, Heat And Ventilation: It shall be the duty of the
owner, lessee or manager of every motion picture theater, public hall or other
place of public assemblage to maintain such premises in a thoroughly clean and
sanitary condition at all times and all such places must be adequately heated
and ventilated while in use. (1970 Code §21.3)
   D.   Required Toilet Facilities: Every theater, public hall and other place
of public assemblage in the village must be equipped with toilet facilities as
follows: one water closet for each two hundred (200) females, one water closet
for each three hundred (300) males, and one urinal for each three hundred (300)
males. The number of closets and urinals shall be based upon the maximum
seating capacity of the theater, public hall or other place of public
assemblage in question and it shall be assumed that the audience will be
equally divided between males and females. All toilet rooms must be properly
marked to indicate whether for males or females. (1970 Code §21.4)
   E.   Drinking Facilities 1 : It shall be unlawful for any person having the
management or control of any public or private school, municipal or public
building, hall or other place used for public meetings, hotel, lodging house,
theater, funeral home, factory or public or private park in the village to use
or permit the use of a common drinking cup, glass or other utensil used for
drinking. It shall be the duty of such persons to provide adequate sanitary
equipment for the securing and drinking of water in such place. (1970 Code
§21.5)
   F.   Catch Basins: All catch basins must be maintained in such condition
that there will be no obnoxious odors emanating from the same, and in an
efficient operating condition. They shall be cleaned with sufficient frequency
to ensure efficient working conditions. The contents of all catch basins when
cleaned shall be removed in suitable conveyances in tightly covered containers
to prevent leakage, and to prevent escape of offensive or noxious odors during
transportation, and the contents shall be removed from the village. (1970 Code
§21.6)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  8-2-4 of this chapter.
8-2-3: CONTAGIOUS DISEASES:
   A.   Reports Required Of Physicians: It is hereby declared the duty of every
practicing physician who shall have a patient within the territorial
jurisdiction of the village, sick or afflicted or supposed to be afflicted with
a contagious, infectious or pestilential disease, to forthwith make report
thereof, in writing to the village president or chief of police describing the
locality of such patient, so that he may be readily found. (1970 Code §21.23)
   B.   Duties Of President: The village president shall immediately cause a
suitable notice, with the name of the disease printed or written in large
letters thereon, to be posted in the most conspicuous place on or near the
building or dwelling in which such contagious disease exists and require the
occupants thereof to maintain and so keep up such notice until, in the opinion
of a competent physician, such notice may be safely discontinued. (1970 Code
§21.24)
   C.   Failure To Report: Any physician failing to make report as aforesaid,
any person failing to make report as aforesaid and any person failing or
refusing to maintain or keep up the notice aforesaid shall be fined pursuant to
the Village Fine Schedule, Appendix A. (1970 Code §21.25)
   D.   Movement Of Infected Persons In Public: It shall be unlawful for any
person having had smallpox, scarlet fever or other like malignant or infectious
disease to go about in any public place, while in danger of giving such disease
to others; provided, that this shall not apply to cases where such person shall
have first consulted a licensed physician, and obtained a written statement
that such person is in no danger of giving the disease to others. (1970 Code
§21.26)
   E.   Deliveries To Quarantined Premises: Milk, foodstuffs and other
necessary supplies may be delivered at quarantined premises, but there must be
no contact of any kind between quarantined inmates of the premises and delivery
agents. No milk bottle, basket or any other article whatsoever may be taken out
of or away from the infected premises during the period of quarantine. Before
milk bottles are removed from the premises after quarantine is raised, they
must be released under the direction of the board of health. (1970 Code §21.27)
   F.   Mail Delivery, Removal Of Articles: During the period of quarantine,
mail in contact of any kind with quarantined persons must not be taken from
quarantined premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to buy, sell, give
away or in any manner dispose of to any person any rags, clothing, bedding, bed
clothes, carpets, furniture or any other article which has been used in any
room occupied by any person suffering from any contagious or infectious
disease, or which has been exposed to any such contagion or infection, or to
send out of any dwelling occupied by any such person any of the abovementioned
articles for the purpose of having the same washed, cleaned or repaired or for
any purpose other than for destruction, unless the same shall have been
disinfected or fumigated in a manner satisfactory to the health officer;
provided, that such disinfection shall not authorize the sale, or keeping for
sale, of bedding so exposed. (1970 Code §21.28)
   G.   Control Of Infected Domestic Animals: No domestic animal, afflicted
with a contagious or infectious disease, shall be allowed to run at large or be
exposed in any public place, whereby the health of man or beast may be affected
within the limits of the village nor shall such diseased animal be shipped or
removed from the premises of the owner, except under the supervision of the
department of public health 1 . It is hereby made the duty of such department
to secure such disposition of any diseased animal and such treatment of
infected premises as to prevent the communication and spread of the contagion
and infection. (1970 Code §21.29; amd. Ord. 2025-10, 3-18-2025)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 1 of this title.
8-2-4: DRINKING WATER 1 :
   A.   Water Must Be Pure, Wholesome: No person shall sell or offer for sale
for drinking or other domestic purposes in the village any water that, under
all the circumstances and conditions, is not pure, wholesome and potable and
which endangers the lives or health of human beings. (1970 Code §21.30)
   B.   Bacteria Content: No water shall be sold or offered for drinking or
other domestic purposes which contains coli or pathogenic bacteria or which
contains more than two hundred (200) bacteria per cubic centimeter according to
standards determined by the director of public health or which contains
nitrates or nitrites in such amount as to be injurious to health. (1970 Code
§21.31)
 
Notes
1 2. See also subsection
   8-2-2E of this chapter.
CHAPTER 3
NUISANCES
SECTION:
8-3-1: Nuisance Definitions, Enumeration
8-3-2: Packinghouses, Rendering Plants, Slaughterhouses
8-3-3: Offensive Matter, Premises
8-3-4: Spitting
8-3-5: Offensive Odors
8-3-6: Noise
8-3-7: Vapors And Smoke From Laundries
8-3-8: Dust And Falling Material
8-3-9: Gas Tanks And Reservoirs
8-3-10: Towers Fenced
8-3-11: Lumber Storage
8-3-12: Bees
8-3-13: Keeping Noisy Animals
8-3-14: Rooming Houses
8-3-15: Houses Of Ill Fame
8-3-16: Gambling
8-3-17: Abatement Of Nuisances
8-3-18: Garbage Scavenging
8-3-19: Violations Of Nuisance Regulations
8-3-20: Nuisance Vegetation
8-3-21: Parkway Maintenance
8-3-22:    Pests
8-3-1: NUISANCE DEFINITIONS, ENUMERATION:
   A.   What Constitutes Nuisances Generally; Definitions:
      1.   It shall constitute a nuisance to commit any offense which is in
fact a nuisance or which is a nuisance according to the common law, or which is
made such by this code, the statutes of the state or by any ordinance of the
village.
      2.   The term "public nuisance affecting health" shall mean a nuisance
which is a thing, act, occupation or use of property, premises, equipment or
structure affecting the health of five (5) or more people, or the public, and
shall include:
         a.   Any nuisance specifically declared to be such by any section of
this code or other ordinance of the village.
         b.   Any act, omission of an act, occupation and use of property,
equipment or structure which is deemed by the department of public health to be
a menace to health of the inhabitants of the village or any considerable number
thereof.
      3.   The term "public nuisance" shall mean a thing, act, occupation or
use of property or premises or equipment, or structure of any kind which:
         a.   Shall annoy, injure or endanger the safety, health, comfort or
repose of the public.
         b.   Shall offend public decency.
         c.   Shall unlawfully interfere with, obstruct or tend to obstruct or
render dangerous for passage, a public park, square, street, alley or highway.
         d.   Shall in any way render the public insecure in life or in use of
property. (1970 Code §28.1)
   B.   Schedule Of Health Nuisances Generally:
      1.   The following are hereby declared to be nuisances affecting health
as well as and in addition to any other act, omission of act, occupation or use
of property or premises, equipment or structure deemed to be a menace to the
health of inhabitants of the village as declared in any other section of this
code:
         a.   All diseased animals running at large.
         b.   To obstruct any ravine or gutter, so as to cause water to
stagnate therein, or to permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon any
premises to the prejudice of others.
         c.   Carcasses of animals, or any part thereof, not buried or
destroyed within twenty four (24) hours after death.
         d.   To cause or suffer any animal or vegetable matter, slops, swill,
suds, garbage, filth, stable drippings or offal or noisome substance of any
kind to be collected, deposited or remain in any place in the village to the
prejudice of others.
         e.   To establish, maintain and carry on any offensive or unwholesome
business within the village.
         f.   The distribution of samples of medicines or drugs unless such
samples are placed in the hands of an adult person.
         g.   All buildings, walls and other structures which have been damaged
by fire, decay or otherwise to an extent exceeding one-half (1/2) their
original value, and which are so situated as to endanger the safety of the
public.
         h.   All dangerous or insanitary, unguarded, unprotected machinery or
equipment in any public place, or situated or operated on private property.
(1970 Code §28.6)
         i.   All infestations of flies, fleas, roaches, lice, ticks, rats,
mice, fly maggots, bedbugs, and mosquito larvae. (Ord. 2015-34, 9-1-2015)
         j.   To corrupt or render unwholesome or impure drinking water to the
injury or prejudice of others.
         k.   To permit the growth upon any premises of any noxious plants to
the injury or prejudice of others.
         l.   To permit or cause loose earth, ashes, lime, coal, dry sand or
other similar substances to be used on any property to the injury or prejudice
of others.
         m.   To shake or beat out of any window, door or opening of any
building any mops, mat, carpet, rug, cloth, pillow, bed sheet, bedding or other
similar object, into any public way or into any place or building. No usual or
reasonable precaution shall be omitted by any person to prevent fragments or
other substances from falling, or dust and light material from flying into any
public way or into any place or building.
         n.   To construct or maintain any building or structure which is in an
insanitary, unsafe or dangerous condition, or to maintain or permit any
building or part thereof to be or remain in an insanitary condition by reason
of the basement or cellar being damp or wet or the floor of such basement or
cellar being covered with stagnant water, or by reason of the presence of sewer
gas, or which by reason of any other insanitary, unsafe or dangerous condition
endangers the health or safety of any person.
      2.   The declaration of the above nuisances shall not be construed to
limit the power of the Department of Public Health to review any specific
condition believed to be a nuisance by the Health Officer and after each review
to declare such condition a nuisance whenever the facts presented by the Health
Officer are conclusive that a nuisance within the meaning as defined in this
chapter has been or is being committed. (1970 Code §28.6)
8-3-2: PACKINGHOUSES, RENDERING PLANTS, SLAUGHTERHOUSES:
The following acts shall constitute nuisances:
   A.   To locate and carry on, without having obtained permission of the
President and Board of Trustees to do so, any packinghouse or rendering plant
within the limits of the Village, or within the distance of one mile without
the limits of the Village. (1970 Code §28.8)
   B.   To slaughter or kill any animals or keep or maintain or use any house
or place in which the business of slaughtering any such animals may be carried
on in the Village. (1970 Code §28.10; amd. 1995 Code)
8-3-3: OFFENSIVE MATTER, PREMISES:
It shall constitute a nuisance for any person to:
   A.   Cause or suffer the carcass of any animal, or any animal or vegetable
matter, slops, swill, suds, garbage, filth, stable droppings or offal or
noisome substance of any kind to be collected, deposited or remain in any place
in the Village to the prejudice of others. (1970 Code §28.12)
   B.   Deposit night soil, dead animals or other filthy, offensive or noisome
substance upon any lot, street, alley, highway, park or other place. (1970 Code
§28.13)
   C.   Keep or suffer to be kept in a foul, offensive, nauseous or filthy
condition, any stable, cellar, vault, drain, pool, privy, sewer or sink, upon
any railroad car, building, yard, ground or premises belonging to or occupied
by him. (1970 Code §28.14)
8-3-4: SPITTING:
It shall constitute a nuisance for any person to expectorate in or on any
sidewalk, depot platform or on the floor or wall of any railway car or hall or
other public building. (1970 Code §28.11)
8-3-5: OFFENSIVE ODORS:
   A.   It shall be a nuisance for any person within the limits of the Village
to conduct any business so negligently; or to use any premises in such a manner
as to create an offensive smell which may taint the air and render it
unwholesome or disagreeable to the neighborhood.
   B.   It shall also constitute a nuisance for any person to erect, continue
or use any building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or
manufacture, which, by occasioning noxious exhalations, offensive smells or
otherwise, is offensive or dangerous to the health of individuals or of the
public. (1970 Code §28.15)
8-3-6: NOISE:
   A.   No person owning or in possession, charge or control of any building or
premises shall use the same, or permit the use of the same, or rent the same to
be used, for any business or employment, or for any purpose of pleasure or
recreation, if such use shall, from its noise or its boisterous nature, disturb
or destroy the peace of the neighborhood in which such building or premises is
situated, or be dangerous or detrimental to health. Such use of any building or
premises is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
   B.   No person shall make or cause, permit or allow to be made any noise of
any kind by crying, calling or shouting or by means of any device for the
purpose of advertising any goods, wares or merchandise, or as part of any
political campaign or for the purpose of attracting the attention or inviting
the patronage of any person to any business whatsoever 1 . (1970 Code §28.20;
amd. 1995 Code)
   C.   Except in cases of emergencies or as otherwise provided in this
section, it shall constitute a nuisance for any person to conduct building
construction operations between seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:
00) A.M. (8:00 A.M. on Sundays), or to operate or use any pile drivers, steam
shovels, pneumatic hammers, derricks, steam or electric hoists or other
apparatus, the use of which is attended with loud or unusual noise, in any
block in which more than half of the buildings on either side of the street are
used exclusively for residence purposes. Exceptions to the above time
restrictions are allowed for the maintenance and operation of utilities, public
works projects or mail deliveries authorized by a governmental body, traffic
control systems, the operation of police, emergency, or snow removal vehicles,
the operation of mass transit system, the maintenance and operation of
railways. (Ord. 01-30, 10-16-2001)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  10-10-1 of this Code.
8-3-7: VAPORS AND SMOKE FROM LAUNDRIES:
Vapors and smoke emanating from any laundry shall not at any time be permitted
to become a nuisance to any portion of the premises in which such laundry is
located, nor to any adjoining or nearby premises. (1970 Code §28.17)
8-3-8: DUST AND FALLING MATERIAL:
The following acts shall constitute a nuisance:
   A.   To permit or cause any fragments or other substances to fall, or dust
or light material to fly into any public way or into any place or building. No
usual or reasonable precaution shall be omitted by any person to prevent
fragments or other substances from falling, or dust and light material from
flying into any public way or into any place or building. (1970 Code §28.7)
   B.   To permit or cause loose earth, ashes, lime, coal, dry sand or other
substances which may be scattered by the wind, to be exposed on any property
used for the storage of motor vehicles. (1970 Code §28.24)
8-3-9: GAS TANKS AND RESERVOIRS:
No gas tank or reservoir shall be located within five hundred feet (500') of
any building used in the Village for church, public or parochial school
purposes. Such a structure so located and maintained is hereby declared to be a
public nuisance. (1970 Code §28.18)
8-3-10: TOWERS FENCED:
Any tower used for conducting electricity shall be enclosed within a six foot
(6') chainlink or equivalent fence so secured that children will not have
access to the said tower. This section shall not apply to standard utility
poles. (1970 Code §28.18a)
8-3-11: LUMBER STORAGE:
No lumber shall be piled, for the purpose of storage, seasoning or drying the
same, within fifty feet (50') of any planing mill or woodworking manufactory,
nor within one hundred feet (100') of any private residence, unless within a
lumberyard belonging to a person duly licensed to keep the same, and when such
building has been erected since the establishment, of such yard. (1970 Code
§29.24)
8-3-12: BEES:
It shall constitute a nuisance for any person to keep, harbor or maintain, or
permit to be kept, harbored or maintained, at any place or in or upon any
premises or part thereof in the Village any bees or beehives. (1970 Code
§28.22)
8-3-13: KEEPING NOISY ANIMALS:
No person in the Village, licensed as provided in this chapter, shall keep or
harbor any dog or other animal shut up or tied up in any yard, enclosure or on
the premises of such veterinary hospital which by barking, howling, bawling or
by other noises, shall disturb the peace and quiet of any family, individual or
neighborhood. (1970 Code §6.39)
8-3-14: ROOMING HOUSES:
The maintenance or use of any "hotel" or "rooming house" as defined in and in
violation of the provisions of chapter 19 of this title is hereby declared to
be and shall constitute a nuisance. (1970 Code §28.16)
8-3-15: HOUSES OF ILL FAME 1 :
Every house of ill fame or house of assignation, where men and women resort for
the purpose of prostitution, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. (1970 Code
§28.19)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  10-4-9 of this Code.
8-3-16: GAMBLING 1 :
Except as permitted by this Code, every house, room, yard, boat, vessel or
other structure or premises kept or used for the purpose of permitting persons
to gamble for any valuable thing within the Village is hereby declared to be a
common nuisance and shall be abated as such. (Ord. 2017-25, 9-5-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  10-4-8 of this Code.
8-3-17: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCES:
   A.   Authority Of Health Officer To Order Abatement: Whenever any declared
public nuisance affecting health, or a source of filth, or cause or probable
cause of sickness shall be found by the Health Officer to exist on any private
or public property in violation of this Code, which violation injuriously
affects or may affect the health of the residents, the Health Officer shall
have the power and authority to order, in writing, the owner, occupant or user
thereof, by appropriate action, at the expense of such owner, occupant or user,
to correct and remove such nuisance, source of filth or cause or probable cause
of sickness, within twenty four (24) hours or within such reasonable time as
the Health Officer may order; provided, that it shall not be necessary in any
case for the Health Officer to specify in such notice the manner in which the
nuisance shall be abated. (1970 Code §28.2)
   B.   Refusal To Obey Order: If the person referred to in the preceding
subsection notified accordingly shall refuse or neglect to comply with such
order within the time and in the manner specified, the Health Officer shall
cause the summary abatement of such nuisance at the expense of the party
responsible for, or permitting the same, and such party shall be subject to the
penalties provided for violations of the provisions of this chapter. (1970 Code
§28.3)
   C.   Procedure When Responsible Person Unknown: Whenever the owner,
occupant, agent or person in possession, charge or control of premises, in or
upon which any nuisance may be found, is unknown or cannot be found, the Health
Officer shall proceed to abate such nuisance without notice. (1970 Code §28.4)
   D.   Collection Of Expenses: In either case provided by the two (2)
preceding subsections, the expense of such abatement shall be collected from
the person who may have created, continued or suffered such nuisance to exist.
(1970 Code §28.5)
8-3-18: GARBAGE SCAVENGING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to collect, obtain, possess or pick up any
item placed for garbage pick up from a garbage receptacle, from ten o'clock
(10:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Ord. 94-35, 10-4-1994)
8-3-19: VIOLATIONS OF NUISANCE REGULATIONS:
Any person who commits a nuisance shall be guilty of a violation of this
chapter and shall be subject to the penalty provided in the Village Fine
Schedule. (1970 Code §28.25; amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
8-3-20: NUISANCE VEGETATION:
   A.   Definitions:
   BUILDING COMMISSIONER: The Village of Worth Building Commissioner or his
designee.
   MUNICIPAL PROPERTY: Property owned by the Village of Worth, including
rights-of-way, parkways and medians.
   B.   Public Nuisances: The following are hereby declared public nuisances
under this chapter:
      1.   Any dead or dying tree or shrub, whether located on Municipal
property or private property, which affects or may affect Municipal property.
      2.   Trees infected with Dutch elm disease (Ceratocystis ulmi) as
determined by appropriate laboratory analysis and evaluation of other common
symptoms.
      3.   Trees infected with the emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis
Fairmaire) as determined by the existence of basal sprouting, bark fissures,
woodpecker damage (i.e., holes), one-eighth inch (1/8") "D" shaped holes, the
presence of larvae or the adult emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis
Fairmaire), or bark falling off exposing "S" shaped galleries.
      4.   Trees that are dead or substantially dead that, because of their
condition, may serve as a breeding place for the European elm bark beetle
(Scolytus multistriatus), the native elm bark beetle (Hylurgopinus rufipes), or
the emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis Fairmaire).
      5.   Trees infected with oak wilt (Ceratocystis fagacearum) as determined
by appropriate laboratory analysis and evaluation of other common symptoms.
      6.   Any otherwise healthy tree or shrub, whether located on municipal
property or private property, which harbors insects or diseases which
reasonably may be expected to injure or harm any tree or shrub.
      7.   Any tree or shrub, or portion thereof, whether located on municipal
property or on private property, which affects or may affect municipal
property, which, by reason of location or condition constitutes an imminent
danger to the health, safety or welfare of the general public.
      8.   Any tree or shrub or portion thereof whether located on municipal
property or private property which affects or may affect municipal property,
which obstructs sightlines or the free passage of pedestrian or vehicular
traffic or which obstructs a traffic control device on municipal property.
   C.   Right To Inspect: The building commissioner has the authority to enter
onto private property between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and five
o'clock (5:00) P.M. whereon there is located a tree, shrub, plant or plant part
which is reasonably suspected to be a public nuisance, but only to the extent
necessary to confirm whether a public nuisance exists. The building
commissioner may take photographs, video, or remove specimens from any tree to
conduct any analysis, laboratory or otherwise, to determine if a public
nuisance exists. Nothing in this section authorizes the village to force,
break, or remove any lock or door to gain entry to an area to inspect for a
nuisance.
   D.   Abatement: The following are the prescribed means of abating public
nuisances under this section:
      1.   Any public nuisance under this section which is located on municipal
property shall be pruned, removed or otherwise treated by the village in
whatever fashion is required to cause the abatement of the nuisance within a
reasonable time after its discovery.
      2.   Any public nuisance that is located on privately owned property
shall be pruned, removed, or otherwise treated by the property owner or his/her
agent in whatever fashion is required to cause the abatement of the nuisance
and under the supervision of the building commissioner. No property owner will
be found to have violated this provision unless and until the following notice
requirements have been satisfied:
         a.   The village shall cause a written notice to be personally served
or sent by certified mail to the person to whom the general tax bill was
addressed for the preceding year;
         b.   Such notice shall describe by legal description or by common
description the premises;
         c.   Such notice shall state the actions that the property owner or
occupant may undertake to abate the nuisance;
         d.   Such notice shall require the elimination of the nuisance within
thirty (30) days of the date of service of the notice, or such shorter period
of time as is deemed necessary for public safety and welfare by the building
commissioner.
      3.   If the village removes from any lot or parcel of land, pursuant to
this section, any tree that is a public nuisance, the assessment of the cost of
the work done by the village against the owner of the lot or parcel of land
involved shall be in addition to the penalties imposed herein for any violation
of noncompliance with any provision of this section.
      4.   The building commissioner is empowered to cause the immediate
abatement of any public nuisance provided that the nuisance is determined by
the building commissioner to be an immediate threat to any person or property.
Nothing in this section shall limit or reduce the village's authority,
statutory or otherwise, to define, prevent and abate nuisances.
   E.   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section by failing,
neglecting or refusing to comply with the provisions of any notice provided for
herein, within thirty (30) days after the service thereof, or who shall resist
or obstruct the building commissioner in carrying out the provisions of this
section, may be prosecuted through the village's administrative adjudication
system. As authorized by law, the village may file a lien for unpaid amounts
related to this section, including, without limitation, costs incurred by the
village for tree removal. The remedies identified in this section are
nonexclusive, and nothing stated herein shall limit, waive or in any way reduce
the remedies available to the village under law, equity or otherwise. (Ord.
2014-33, 9-16-2014)
8-3-21: PARKWAY MAINTENANCE:
   A.   Definitions:
   BUILDING COMMISSIONER: The village of Worth building commissioner or his
designee.
   PARKWAY: The portion of land owned by or dedicated to the village located
between a property line and the edge of the street pavement or curb line,
whichever is located closer to the property line.
   PETITIONER: A person or entity filing a hearing request pursuant to
subsection E of this section.
   B.   Responsibilities Of Owners And Occupants:
      1.   Every owner or occupant of real estate within the village shall cut
the weeds and grass on the parkway abutting his real estate at all times as may
be necessary so that the weeds and grass do not exceed eight inches (8") in
height.
      2.   Every owner or occupant of real estate within the village shall trim
bushes and shrubs on the parkway abutting his real estate at all such times as
may be necessary to prevent the same from: a) crossing over property line(s);
b) obstructing the sidewalk, parkway, or street; or c) otherwise impairing or
reducing motorist or pedestrian visibility in a manner that compromises the
public health, safety, and welfare, as determined by the building commissioner.
      3.   Every owner or occupant of real estate located adjacent to a parkway
shall be responsible for removing yard debris, waste, refuse, and natural silt
accumulation from the parkway, so as to permit the free flow of water through
the parkway and to comply with the provisions of this code, including title 12
of this code.
   C.   Public Nuisances: It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance to
allow any conditions to occur that violate subsection B of this section. If an
owner or occupant allows such conditions to occur, the village may abate the
nuisance as provided in this section and/or pursue any and all remedies
available at law or in equity.
   D.   Notice: Whenever a violation of any provision of this section comes to
the attention of the building commissioner, notice of the violation shall be
sent by certified mail to the person to whom the general tax bill was addressed
for the preceding year. The notice shall provide the address of the premises,
describe the nuisance, provide the time period within which the nuisance must
be eliminated, which shall not be less than seven (7) days from the date of
notice being mailed, and describe actions that may be taken to abate the
nuisance. The notice shall be accompanied by a copy of this section.
   E.   Request For Hearing:
      1.   Any person receiving notice pursuant to this section may request,
and shall be granted, a hearing before the building commissioner. Any person
seeking a hearing under this section shall file a written petition with the
village clerk requesting a hearing and containing a brief statement specifying
the grounds for the hearing. All hearing requests shall be filed prior to the
expiration of the time period during which the nuisance must be remedied.
      2.   Upon receiving a request for a hearing, the building commissioner
shall set a time and place for the hearing and give the petitioner written
notice thereof. At the hearing, the petitioner shall be given an opportunity to
be heard and to show why the notice should be withdrawn or modified.
   F.   Notice Becomes Order: Any notice sent pursuant to subsection D of this
section shall automatically become an order if a written request for a hearing
is not filed within the time frame set forth in subsection E of this section.
   G.   Abatement And Penalty: If any person fails or refuses to eliminate the
nuisance identified in a notice or order or fails or refuses to request a
hearing within the time period provided under this section, the village may: 1)
abate the nuisance and recover the reasonable removal costs from the person; 2)
impose a penalty pursuant to the Village Fine Schedule, Appendix A; and/or 3)
pursue any other remedies available, including, without limitation, remedies
available at law or in equity. (Ord. 2016-34, 10-4-2016; amd. Ord. 2025-10, 3-
18-2025)
8-3-22:    PESTS:
   A.   Definitions:
   BUILDING COMMISSIONER: The Village Building Commissioner or his or her
designee.
   PESTS: Undesirable arthropods (including certain insects, spiders, mites,
ticks, and related organisms), wood infesting organisms, rats, mice, and other
obnoxious and undesirable animals, but does not include a feral cat, a
“companion animal” as that term is defined in the Humane Care for Animals Act
(510 ILCS 70/), “animals” as that term is defined in the Illinois Diseased
Animals Act (510 ILCS 50/), or animals protected by the Illinois Wildlife Code
(520 ILCS 5/).
   PEST CONTROL ACTIVITY: The extermination of pests or the prevention of the
ingress or infestation of pests.
   REMOVAL COST: The total cost of the pest-control activity.
   B.   Public Nuisance: The presence, ingress, or infestation of pests on
property within the Village is hereby declared a nuisance subject to the
abatement and penalty provisions of this chapter.
   C.   Right to Inspect: The building commissioner has the authority to enter
onto private property between the hours of seven o’clock (7:00) A.M. and five
o’clock (5:00) P.M. to inspect the interior and exterior of buildings, other
structures, and outdoor premises where the presence or an infestation of pests
is reasonably suspected. Such inspections shall be conducted only to the extent
necessary to confirm whether a public nuisance exists and to determine whether
pest control activities are necessary. The building commissioner may take
photographs or video to conduct any analysis to determine if a public nuisance
exists. Nothing in this section authorizes the village to force, break, or
remove any lock or door to gain entry to an area, building, or structure to
inspect for a nuisance.
   D.   Abatement: The following are the prescribed means of abating public
nuisances under this section:
      1.   Any public nuisance that is located or discovered on privately owned
property shall be subject to pest control activity or otherwise treated by the
property owner, his/her agent, or, in the case where the property is not
occupied by the property owner, the occupant, in whatever fashion is required
to cause the abatement of the nuisance and under the supervision of the
building commissioner. No property owner or occupant will be found to have
violated this provision unless and until the following notice requirements have
been satisfied:
         a.   The village shall cause a written notice to be personally served
or sent by certified mail to (1) the person to whom the general tax bill was
addressed for the preceding year and, if known, (2) the property’s occupant;
         b.   Such notice shall describe the property by legal description or
by common address;
         c.   Such notice shall generally describe the nature of the nuisance;
         d.   Such notice shall require the elimination of the nuisance within
fourteen (14) days of the date of service of the notice, or such shorter period
of time as is deemed necessary by the building commissioner for the public
safety and welfare.
      2.   If the village undertakes or authorizes an agent to undertake pest
control activities on any property pursuant to this section, the village may
record against the property a lien in an amount equal to the removal cost for
the work done by the village or its agent. The lien must include the property’s
legal description, the date pest control activities were undertaken, and the
total cost of the pest control activities. The lien authorized by this section
shall be in addition to the penalties imposed herein for any violation or
noncompliance with any provision of this section.
      3.   The building commissioner is authorized to cause the immediate
abatement of any public nuisance provided that the nuisance is determined by
the building commissioner to be an immediate threat to any person or property.
Nothing in this section shall limit or reduce the village’s authority,
statutory or otherwise, to define, prevent, and abate nuisances.
   E.   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section by failing,
neglecting or refusing to comply with the provisions of any notice provided for
herein, within thirty (30) days after the service thereof may be prosecuted
through the village’s administrative adjudication system. As authorized by law,
the village may file a lien for unpaid amounts related to this section,
including, without limitation, removal costs. The remedies identified in this
section are nonexclusive, and nothing stated herein shall limit, waive or in
any way reduce the remedies available to the village under law, equity or
otherwise including, without limitation, the penalty set forth in section
8-3-19. (Ord. 2024-65, 11-19-2024)
CHAPTER 4
GRAFFITI
SECTION:
8-4-1: Legislative Findings And Declaration
8-4-2: Definitions
8-4-3: Graffiti A Nuisance
8-4-4: Prohibited Acts
8-4-5: Removal Of Graffiti Required
8-4-6: Graffiti Related Offenses
8-4-1: LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS AND DECLARATION:
   A.   The president and board of trustees hereby find and declare that it is
the right of every person, regardless of race, color, creed, religion, national
origin, sex, age, or disability, to be secure and protected from fear,
intimidation, and physical harm caused by the activities of violent groups and
individuals. It is not the intent of this chapter to interfere with the
exercise of the constitutionally protected rights of freedom of expression and
association. The president and board of trustees hereby recognize the
constitutional right of every citizen to harbor and express beliefs on any
lawful subject whatsoever, to lawfully associate with others who share similar
beliefs, to petition lawfully constituted authority for a redress of perceived
grievances, and to participate in the electoral process.
   B.   The president and board of trustees find, however, that urban,
suburban, and rural communities, neighborhoods and schools throughout the state
are being terrorized and plundered by street gangs. The president and board of
trustees find that there are now several hundred street gangs operating in
Illinois, and that while their terrorism is most widespread in urban areas,
street gangs are spreading into suburban areas of Illinois.
   C.   The president and board of trustees further find that street gangs are
often controlled by criminally sophisticated adults who take advantage of our
youth by intimidating and coercing them into membership by employing them as
drug couriers and runners, and by using them to commit brutal crimes against
persons and property to further the financial benefit to and dominance of the
street gang.
   D.   These street gangs' activities present a clear and present danger to
public order and safety and are not constitutionally protected. No society is
or should be required to endure such activities without redress. Accordingly,
it is the intent of the president and board of trustees in enacting this
chapter to control street gang related graffiti that focuses upon patterns of
criminal gang activity and upon the organized nature of street gangs, which
together have been the chief source of their success.
   E.   The presence of graffiti on property within the village offends the
aesthetic sensibilities of its residents, decreases property values, is often
an incitement to crime and is an act destructive to property.
   F.   Graffiti is not only placed on property within the village by
individuals but also by individuals formed into gangs which endorse the act of
placing graffiti on property as a requirement of membership and/or an act
pertaining to membership in said gang.
   G.   Such placement of graffiti by an individual who is a gang member
perpetuates and increases the incidence of graffiti making it more difficult to
make property in the village secure against such destructive acts.
   H.   The definitions in this chapter as they relate to gangs are taken from
the Illinois streetgang terrorism omnibus prevention act, 740 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 147/5 et seq., and should be interpreted in consonance with that
statute. (Ord. 94-16, 5-17-1994)
8-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter, the following words shall have the following
meanings:
   GRAFFITI: Any sign, symbol, marking, drawing, name, initial, word, diagram,
sketch, picture or letter placed without the express, written permission of the
owner upon the real or personal property of said owner.
   STREET GANG MEMBER OR GANG MEMBER: Any person who actually and in fact
belongs to a gang, and any person who knowingly acts in the capacity of an
agent for or accessory to, or is legally accountable for, or voluntarily
associates himself with a course or pattern of gang related criminal activity,
whether in a preparatory, executory, or cover up phase of any activity, or who
knowingly performs, aids, or abets any such activity; or a candidate for gang
membership.
   STREET GANG OR GANG: Any combination, confederation, alliance, network,
conspiracy, understanding, or other similar conjoining, in law or in fact, of
three (3) or more persons:
   A.   1. That, through its membership or through the agency of any member and
at the direction, order, solicitation, or request of any conspirator who is a
leader, officer, director, organizer, or other governing or policy making
person or authority in the conspiracy, or by any agent, representative, or
deputy of any such person or authority engages in a course or pattern of
criminal activity; or
      2.   That, through its membership or through the agency of any member
engages in a course or pattern of criminal activity.
   B.   For purposes of this chapter, it shall not be necessary to show that a
particular conspiracy, combination, or conjoining of persons possesses,
acknowledges, or is known by any common name, insignia, flag, means of
recognition, secret signal or code, creed, belief, structure, leadership or
command structure, method of operation or criminal enterprise, concentration or
specialty, membership, age, or other qualifications, initiation rites,
geographical or territorial situs or boundary or location, or other unifying
mark, manner, protocol or method of expressing or indicating membership when
the conspiracy's existence, in law or in fact, can be demonstrated by a
preponderance of other competent evidence. However, any evidence reasonably
tending to show or demonstrate, in law or in fact, the existence of or
membership in any conspiracy, confederation, or other association described
herein, or probative of the existence of or membership in any such association,
shall be admissible in any action or proceeding brought under this chapter.
   STREET GANG RELATED OR GANG RELATED: Any criminal activity, enterprise,
pursuit, or undertaking directed by, ordered by, authorized by, consented to,
agreed to, requested by, acquiesced in, or ratified by any gang leader,
officer, or governing or policy making person or authority, or by any agent,
representative, or deputy of any such officer, person, or authority:
   A.   With the intent to increase the gang's size, membership, prestige,
dominance, or control in any geographical area; or
   B.   With the intent to provide the gang with any advantage in, or any
control or dominance over any criminal market sector, including, but not
limited to, the manufacture, delivery, or sale of controlled substances or
cannabis; arson or arson for hire; traffic in stolen property or stolen credit
cards; traffic in prostitution, obscenity, or pornography; or that involves
robbery, burglary, or theft; or
   C.   With the intent to exact revenge or retribution for the gang or any
member of the gang; or
   D.   With the intent to obstruct justice, or intimidate or eliminate any
witness against the gang or any member of the gang; or
   E.   With the intent to otherwise directly or indirectly cause any benefit,
aggrandizement, gain, profit or other advantage whatsoever to or for the gang,
its reputation, influence, or membership. (Ord. 94-16, 5-17-1994)
8-4-3: GRAFFITI A NUISANCE:
The village hereby declares graffiti in the public view to be a nuisance and as
a nuisance to be subject to the provisions of this code pertaining to nuisances
as contained in the village ordinances 1 . (Ord. 94-16, 5-17-1994)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 3 of this title.
8-4-4: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Graffiti Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to place
graffiti, or to permit another to place graffiti, upon the real or personal,
public or private, property of another.
   B.   Gang Graffiti Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any gang member to
place graffiti, or for the gang member to permit another to place graffiti, on
the property of another. It shall be unlawful for any person to place gang
related graffiti, or to permit another to place gang related graffiti, on the
property of another.
   C.   Possession Of Graffiti Implements With Intent To Use Prohibited: It
shall be unlawful for any person to possess while in any public building or in
any public facility or while on private property, spray paint containers,
paint, ink, marking brushes, applicator or other materials for marking,
scratching or etching with the intent to use such material(s) to violate
subsections A and/or B of this section. (Ord. 94-16, 5-17-1994)
8-4-5: REMOVAL OF GRAFFITI REQUIRED:
Upon notification by the village, the owner of property upon which graffiti has
been illegally placed shall remove the graffiti within fifteen (15) days of the
date of notice. Failure to remove the graffiti within the specified time shall
cause the summary abatement of this nuisance as proscribed in village
ordinances and the village shall assess the cost of removal against the owner.
The penalty upon conviction for the offense of failure to remove graffiti shall
be a fine pursuant to the Village Fine Schedule, Appendix A, for each offense
and mandatory restitution to the village for any costs incurred in removing the
graffiti. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2014-16, 3-4-2014; amd. Ord. 2025-
10, 3-18-2025)
8-4-6: PENALTIES:
   A.   Placing Graffiti: The penalty for violation of subsection
8-4-4A of this chapter shall be a fine in the amount set forth in the Village
Fine Schedule. In addition to a fine, the court may order the offender to pay
restitution to the property owner for the costs of restoring the property to
its state prior to the application of graffiti. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
   B.   Gang Related Graffiti: The penalty for violation of subsection
8-4-4B of this chapter shall be a fine in the amount set forth in the Village
Fine Schedule. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during
or on which a violation occurs or continues.
   C.   Possession of Graffiti Implements With Intent To Use: The penalty or
violation of subsection
8-4-4C of this chapter shall be a fine in the amount set forth in the Village
Fine Schedule. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during
or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 94-16, 5-17-1994; amd. Ord.
2025-11, 3-18-2025)
CHAPTER 5
GRASS AND WEEDS
SECTION:
8-5-1: Height Restriction
8-5-2: Cost Of Grass And Weed Cutting And Removal
8-5-3: Removal By Village; Lien
8-5-1: HEIGHT RESTRICTION:
It is unlawful for the owner, lessee or occupant of any real estate to refuse
or neglect to cut grass and weeds which are of a height greater than eight
inches (8"). (Ord. 10-18, 5-18-2010)
8-5-2: COST OF GRASS AND WEED CUTTING AND REMOVAL:
The cost and expense of grass and weed cutting and removal, as specified in
section
8-5-3 of this chapter, shall be determined on the basis of labor, time and
material. (Ord. 10-18, 5-18-2010)
8-5-3: REMOVAL BY VILLAGE; LIEN:
   A.   In the event the owner of property neglects or refuses to cut grass and
weeds so that such grass and weeds exceed eight inches (8") in height, the
village may cause such grass and weeds to be cut, and thereafter, in order to
reduce costs and subsequent nuisance of a further growth of weeds, may cause
said lot to be sprayed with grass and weed killer even though at the time of
spraying there is no visible growth of grass and weeds. Said spraying may
continue from year to year until such time as the owner causes grass and weeds
to be removed and resumes maintenance of the lot and advises the village of
that fact in writing.
   B.   If grass and weeds are cut or a lot sprayed with grass and weed killer
by the municipality, as herein provided, or said work is performed by someone
so directed on behalf of the municipality, a notice of lien for the cost and
expense thereof incurred by the village shall be recorded in the following
manner: The village or the person performing the service by authority of the
village, in its or his own name, may file notice of lien in the office of the
recorder of deeds in the county in which said real estate is located or in the
office of the registrar of titles of such county if the real estate affected is
registered under the torrens system. The notice of lien shall consist of a
sworn statement setting out: 1) a description of the real estate sufficient for
identification thereof, 2) the amount of money representing the cost and
expense incurred or payable for the service, and 3) the date or dates when said
cost and expense was incurred by the village, and shall be filed within sixty
(60) days after the cost and expense is incurred.
   C.   Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of lien has been
filed, the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the
lien has been filed and the release shall be filed of record in the same manner
as filing notice of said lien. (Ord. 10-18, 5-18-2010)
CHAPTER 6
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
SECTION:
8-6-1: Definitions
8-6-2: Containers Required, Collection Service
8-6-3: Garbage Containers
8-6-4: Dumpsters
8-6-5: Windblown Refuse
8-6-6: Deposits On Streets
8-6-7: Burning Of Garbage
8-6-8: Accumulation Of Garbage And Debris On Private Property
8-6-9: Yard Waste
8-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings herein
ascribed to them:
   GARBAGE: Wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and
consumption of food; wastes from the handling, storage and sale of produce.
   REFUSE: Combustible trash, including, but not limited to, paper, cartons,
boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, wood furniture,
bedding; noncombustible trash, including, but not limited to, metals, tin cans,
metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, glass,
crockery, other mineral waste; street rubbish, including, but not limited to,
street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catch basin dirt, contents of litter
receptacles; provided, refuse shall not include earth and wastes from building
operations, nor shall it include solid wastes resulting from industrial
processes and manufacturing operations such as food processing wastes, boiler
house cinders, lumber, scraps and shavings. (1970 Code §20.1)
8-6-2: CONTAINERS REQUIRED, COLLECTION SERVICE:
All garbage, refuse and ashes for collection shall be placed in metal
containers equipped with a tightfitting cover and equipped with handles so that
they may be lifted and carried by one man. No such container shall have a
capacity of less than ten (10) gallons nor more than thirty (30) gallons.
Containers for the storage of refuse or garbage shall be kept covered at all
times.
   A.   The owner of every apartment building, hotel, rooming house or
multiple-family dwelling of any kind shall provide the following types of
garbage containers and garbage collection service for each family residing on
said premises:
 
Building Size Container Size            Collection
(Units)
    2 to 6    2 cubic yard leach bOnce every 7 days
   7 to 12    2 cubic yard leach bTwice every 7 days
   13 to 18   4 cubic yard leach bTwice every 7 days
   19 to 24   4 cubic yard leach bThree times every 7 days
 
   B.    Each store or other commercial enterprise shall install and maintain
garbage containers such as the leach box or equivalent of sufficient capacity
to prevent the exposure or overflow of garbage. Each apartment building, hotel,
rooming house or multiple-family dwelling shall ensure it provides sufficient
containers in conjunction to the requirements in Paragraph A of this Section to
prevent the exposure or overflow of garbage.
   C.   Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be
fined in the amount set forth in the Village Fine Schedule for each offense.
(1970 Code §20.5; amd. Ord. 70-1, 2-3-1970; Ord. 2024-68, 12-3-2024; Ord. 2025-
05, 2-4-2025; Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
8-6-3: GARBAGE CONTAINERS:
   A.   Storage Area Restricted: It shall be unlawful for any person to store
any garbage or refuse except in the rear of the premises; provided, however,
that garbage containers may be placed in the front of premises no earlier than
one hour before sunset immediately preceding the collection day of said
garbage. Said garbage containers shall be moved from the front of the premises,
within twelve (12) hours after said garbage is collected. In no event shall
said garbage containers be permitted on the public streets or alleys.
   B.   Covered Containers: All garbage and refuse must be stored in containers
and shall be kept covered at all times.
   C.   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be
fined the amount set forth in the Village Fine Schedule for each offense. (Ord.
91-23, 12-3-1991; amd. Ord. 2014-16, 3-4-2014; amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
8-6-4: DUMPSTERS:
   A.   For the purpose of this section, dumpster shall mean any roll-off
container, used for the collection of garbage and debris, which, when
transported, is transported by way of a truck equipped with an industrial roll-
off hoist.
   B.   Any dumpster used in the village, when not being transported, shall be
located only on private property. In cases of undue hardship, where it is not
feasible to locate a dumpster on private property in conjunction with its use
for the collection of garbage and debris, any person or entity, upon
notification of the public works department, shall be allowed to locate the
dumpster on a street or parkway, as determined by the public works department,
under the following conditions:
      1.   The dumpster shall be located on skids so that it does not damage
the roadway or parkway.
      2.   The dumpster shall be surrounded by warning barriers with flashing
lights.
      3.   The dumpster shall only be located on the roadway or parkway between
eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and four o'clock (4:00) P.M. (Ord. 94-32, 10-4-1994)
8-6-5: WINDBLOWN REFUSE:
It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to accumulate any dust, ashes or trash
of such a material that it can be blown away by the wind anywhere in the
village excepting in a covered container. (1970 Code §20.3)
8-6-6: DEPOSITS ON STREETS 1 :
It shall be unlawful to deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle any garbage,
refuse or ashes on any public street or alley in the village; provided, that
this section shall not be construed to prohibit placing garbage, refuse or
ashes in a container complying with the provisions of this code preparatory to
having such material collected or disposed of in the manner provided herein.
(Ord. 2015-53, 12-1-2015)

  1. See also section
1 8-6-3 of this chapter and subsection
  10-10-2B of this code.
8-6-7: BURNING OF GARBAGE 1 :
The burning of garbage or of other combustible materials in garbage or refuse
containers within the corporate limits of the village is hereby expressly
prohibited. (1970 Code §20.6)
 
Notes
1 2. See title 9, chapter 5 of this code.
8-6-8: ACCUMULATION OF GARBAGE AND DEBRIS ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   Definition Of Garbage: The term "garbage", when used in this section,
shall mean any discarded, used or unconsumed substance or waste. "Garbage" may
include, but is not limited to, any trash, refuse, debris, rubbish, grass
clippings or other lawn or garden waste, newspaper, magazines, glass, metal,
plastic or paper containers, any nauseous or offensive matter of any kind, any
object likely to injure any person or anything else of an unsanitary nature and
waste or scrap building materials that are not completely within a dumpster,
leach box or metal garbage container.
   B.   Accumulation Of Garbage Prohibited: No person shall discard, leave,
cause or allow garbage to accumulate on private property in the village in such
a manner as to constitute a public nuisance or in such a manner that the
garbage may be blown or otherwise carried onto the property of another person.
   C.   Removal Of Garbage And Debris: If the village building commissioner
determines that a property owner is in violation of this section, the owner of
said property shall be given written notice of that violation. If the property
owner refuses or neglects to remove such garbage and debris from the property
within days after receiving said notice, the village may provide for the
removal of the garbage and debris. All costs and expenses incurred by the
village for such removal shall be billed to the property owner. Nothing in this
section shall defer immediate and concurrent prosecution for any violation of
subsection B of this section.
   D.   Enforcement: The building commissioner and law enforcement officers of
the village shall be authorized to issue P tickets or other appropriate
citations or complaints for violations of this section. The village attorney
shall prosecute all violations of this section and take whatever legal measures
are necessary to enforce this section. (Ord. 88-1, 3-15-1988)
   E.   Penalties: Any person who shall violate this section shall be
punishable pursuant to the Village Fine Schedule, Appendix A, . The imposition
of a fine shall not be held to prevent the removal of garbage and debris by the
village. (Ord. 88-1, 3-15-1988; amd. 1995 Code; Ord. 2025-10, 3-18-2025)
8-6-9: YARD WASTE:
   A.   Definition:
      1.   For the purposes of this section, the terms landscape waste and
municipal waste shall be defined as those terms are defined in the
environmental protection act 1 .
      2.   "Landscape waste" means all accumulations of grass or shrubbery
cuttings, leaves, tree limbs and other materials accumulated as the result of
the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees.
      3.   "Municipal waste" means garbage, general household and commercial
waste, landscape waste and construction or demolition debris.
   B.   Prohibited And Restricted Acts:
      1.   No person may knowingly mix landscape waste that is intended for
collection or for disposal at a landfill with any other municipal waste.
      2.   No person may knowingly put landscape waste into a container
intended for collection or disposal at a landfill, unless such container is
biodegradable. In addition, plastic bag containers intended for disposal at a
landfill, even if biodegradable, may not be used as the container.
      3.   No person shall dump or deposit his landscape waste or municipal
waste on the land of another.
   C.   Penalties: Any person violating subsection B1, B2 or B3 of this section
shall be penalized in accordance with the Village Fine Schedule. (Ord. 90-14,
6-19-1990; amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
 
Notes
1 1. 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
CHAPTER 7
GARBAGE COLLECTORS
SECTION:
8-7-1: License Required, Application
8-7-2: License Term, Proration
8-7-3: Garbage Collection Vehicles, Restrictions
8-7-1: LICENSE REQUIRED, APPLICATION:
   A.   No person shall manage, operate, carry on or conduct the business of
collection of garbage in the village without first having obtained a license
therefor. (1970 Code §20.7)
   B.   Every person desiring a license under this chapter shall make
application in writing therefor to the village clerk setting forth in such
application the full name or names and address or addresses of such applicant.
Upon the receipt and approval of such application and the payment by applicant
to the village clerk of the license fee provided for in section
3-1-5 of this code, a license shall be issued for each vehicle so licensed
authorizing such applicant to carry on the business of garbage collection in
the village. (1970 Code §20.8)
8-7-2: LICENSE TERM, PRORATION:
All annual licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire on December 31
of each year and no annual license shall be issued upon payment of the full
license fee, except that licenses issued for less than a six (6) month period
may be issued upon payment of fifty percent (50%) of the license fee as
provided therein. (1970 Code §20.9)
8-7-3: GARBAGE COLLECTION VEHICLES, RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Parking Or Standing: No cart or other vehicle for carrying any garbage,
or having upon it or in it, any manure or other nauseous or offensive substance
shall, without necessity therefor, stand or remain, nor shall a needless number
gather, before any building, place of business or other premises where any
person may be, nor shall any such cart or vehicle occupy an unreasonable length
of time in loading or unloading or in passing along any street or through any
inhabited place or ground; nor shall any such cart or vehicle, or the driver
thereof, or anything thereto pertaining be (or by any person having a right to
control the same, be allowed to be) in a condition needlessly filthy or
offensive, and when not in use, such carts, vehicles and all implements used in
connection therewith, shall be stored and kept in some place where no needless
offense shall be given to any of the inhabitants of the village. (1970 Code
§20.10)
   B.   Soundness Of Containers And Covers: All carts and vehicles mentioned in
subsection A of this section, and boxes, tubs and receptacles thereon in which
any substance in said subsection referred to may be or is carried, shall be
strong and tight so that no part of such contents or load shall fall, leak or
spill therefrom, and shall be adequately and tightly covered so as to prevent
the same from being offensive or give access to flies 1 . (1970 Code §20.11)
   C.   Overloading: No person shall allow any cart or vehicle to be so
overloaded or to be in such bad condition of repair, or of such faulty
construction, or to be so improperly driven or managed that any of its contents
shall fall off such cart or vehicle in any place, street or premises in the
village. (1970 Code §20.12)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  7-5-2 of this code.
CHAPTER 8
CATCH BASIN AND SEWER CLEANERS
SECTION:
8-8-1: License Required, Exception
8-8-2: Application For License, Fee, Revocation
8-8-3: Bond Required
8-8-1: LICENSE REQUIRED, EXCEPTION:
No person shall engage in or carry on the business of removing or transporting
the contents of catch basins, sewers or refuse of like nature, or in any manner
engage in or carry on the business of cleaning catch basins or sewers within
the village without first having obtained a license from the clerk of the
village so to do; provided, however, that licensed plumbers or licensed sewer
builders may clean catch basins or sewers in connection with repairing the
same, without obtaining such a license. (1970 Code §21.7)
8-8-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, FEE, REVOCATION:
Every person desiring a license as a cleaner of catch basins and sewers shall
make application in writing therefor to the village clerk, setting forth in
such application the full name or names and address or addresses of such
applicant or applicants. Upon the receipt and approval of such application by
the village clerk, and upon payment of an annual license fee as provided by
section
3-1-5 of this code, for each vehicle used by such person in such business, the
village clerk shall, if said applicant has filed a bond as hereinafter
provided, cause to be issued to such applicant, a license for each vehicle so
licensed authorizing such applicant to engage in and carry on the business of a
cleaner of catch basins and sewers. (1970 Code §21.9)
8-8-3: BOND REQUIRED:
Every person applying for a license or for licenses to engage in the business
of cleaning catch basins or sewers, shall at the time of making application for
such license or licenses, execute a bond to the village in the penal sum of
five hundred dollars ($500.00) with sureties to be approved by the village
clerk, conditioned that such catch basins and sewer cleaner will comply with
all the provisions of this chapter, and with all reasonable rules and
regulations that the department of public health of the village may adopt
during the license year for which the license is issued, in respect to the
removal and transportation of the contents of catch basins and sewers and all
matters appertaining to the cleaning of the same. (1970 Code §21.8)
CHAPTER 9
JUNK DEALERS
SECTION:
8-9-1: Definitions
8-9-2: Licenses Required; Fee, Issuance
8-9-3: Application For License
8-9-4: Bond Required
8-9-5: Restriction On Licenses
8-9-6: Separate License Required
8-9-7: Collection Vehicles
8-9-8: Location Restrictions
8-9-9: Enclosure Required
8-9-10: Revocation Of License, Continuation Of Business
8-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
   JUNK: Includes iron, chain, brass, copper, tin, lead or other base metals,
old rope, old bags, rags, wastepaper, rubber, glass and empty bottles of
different kinds and sizes when the number of each kind or size is less than one
gross, and all articles and things discarded or no longer used as a
manufactured article composed of or consisting of any one or more of the
materials or articles herein mentioned.
   JUNK DEALER: Includes every person, firm or corporation that is engaged in
the business of buying, selling or bartering or exchanging, or that shall
collect receive, store or hold in possession for sale, barter or exchange, any
of the things defined herein as junk, whether dealing at wholesale or retail or
as a junk peddler.
   JUNK STORE: Any store, shop, warehouse or building where junk is bought,
sold, bartered or exchanged, or where junk is collected, received, stored or
held in possession for resale, barter or exchange, either at wholesale or
retail.
   JUNKYARD: Any yard, place or enclosure other than a junk store as herein
defined, where junk is bought, sold, bartered or exchanged, either at wholesale
or retail, or where junk is collected, received, stored or held in possession
for resale, barter or exchange, either at wholesale or retail.
   RETAIL JUNK DEALER: Includes every person, firm or corporation that shall
engage in the business of buying, selling, bartering or exchanging, or that
shall collect, receive, store or hold in possession for sale, barter or
exchange, any of the things in and by this section defined as junk where the
usual and customary purchases consist of quantities of less than the amounts
customarily purchased by "wholesale junk dealers" as herein defined, or
purchases from junk peddlers; provided, that a junk peddler, who does not
occupy premises leased or purchased especially for the purpose of such business
shall not be deemed a retail junk dealer under the terms of this chapter.
   WHOLESALE JUNK DEALER: Includes every person, firm or corporation engaged in
the business of buying, selling, bartering or exchanging in large quantities,
or that shall collect, receive, store or hold in possession for sale, barter or
exchange in large quantities, any of the things in and by this section defined
as junk; provided, that dealing in large quantities shall be understood to mean
that the customary and usual separate transactions, both of purchases and
sales, shall consist of the purchase or sale of car-load lots, or lots of ten
(10) tons or more of metals, or lots of ten (10) bales or more of rags, and
correspondingly large lots of any other junk dealt in; and provided, further,
that purchasers of old or waste metals in large quantities shall be regarded as
wholesale junk dealers unless they actually operate within the village a plant
for the smelting or refining of such metals. (1970 Code §23.1)
8-9-2: LICENSES REQUIRED; FEE, ISSUANCE:
   A.   No person shall engage in the business of keeping a junk store or
junkyard without being first licensed for such purpose. (1970 Code §23.5)
   B.   No person shall engage in the wholesale or retail junk business or
conduct the business commonly known as a junk dealer, wholesale or retail, or
operate what is commonly known as a junk wagon or junk truck without first
securing a license as hereinafter provided. (1970 Code §23.6)
   C.   The village clerk may, upon payment of the license fee required by
section
3-1-5 of this code, issue licenses to any person, store or yard to keep what is
commonly called junk. (1970 Code §23.11)
8-9-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring to operate or engage in the business commonly known as junk
dealer, wholesale or retail, or to operate an automobile, wagon or truck in
connection with such business, shall first make a written application to the
village clerk, containing the following information:
   A.   The name and address of the applicant.
   B.   The location of the store or junkyard.
   C.   The number of automobiles, wagons or trucks used in connection
therewith and the place of residence of the applicant. (1970 Code §23.8)
8-9-4: BOND REQUIRED:
Every person licensed as provided for in this chapter shall, at the time of
receiving such license, enter, with sufficient surety, into a joint and several
bond to the village in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00),
conditioned for the due observance of this code and such ordinances of the
village as may be passed or shall be in force respecting the keeping of junk
shops at any time during the continuance of such license. (1970 Code §23.12)
8-9-5: RESTRICTION ON LICENSES:
   A.   No person licensed under the terms of this chapter as a retail junk
dealer shall be permitted under his retail dealer's license to purchase junk
from another retail junk dealer or to purchase junk in carload lots or in large
quantities; provided, that any retail junk dealer who desires to purchase junk
in such manner or such quantities may secure a separate license as a wholesale
junk dealer. (1970 Code §23.9)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to purchase any article
whatever from any minor without the written consent of the parents or guardian
of such minor. (1970 Code §23.4)
8-9-6: SEPARATE LICENSE REQUIRED:
Every person who shall keep, maintain or conduct both a retail junk or
wholesale junk business shall procure a separate license for each, and if more
than one retail junk business, then one license for each such retail business.
A separate license shall be procured by every junk dealer for each separate
junk store or junkyard and for each junk wagon or truck or automobile used in
the business. (1970 Code §23.10)
8-9-7: COLLECTION VEHICLES:
No person shall draw or drive, or procure to be drawn or driven, through the
streets of the village, any handcart, wheelbarrow or other cart or vehicle for
the purpose of collecting junk, nor shall any person be entitled to have a cart
or other vehicle to be used for the aforesaid purpose, without being first
licensed to keep a junk shop. (1970 Code §23.7)
8-9-8: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to locate, conduct or operate any
junkyard, junk store or junk shop within four hundred feet (400') of any
church, hospital or school. (1970 Code §23.2)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to locate, conduct or operate any
junkyard or junk store in any block in which half of the buildings on both
sides of the street are used exclusively for residential purposes, without the
written consent of a majority of the property owners according to frontage on
both sides of the street. (1970 Code §23.3)
8-9-9: ENCLOSURE REQUIRED:
Every premises or enclosure, except a completely enclosed building used for the
purpose of storing parts of dismantled automobiles or vehicles shall be
entirely surrounded by a fence eight feet (8') in height, which fence shall be
located at least ten feet (10') from all public sides surrounding the property,
and none of said articles shall be piled higher than said fence 1 . (1970 Code
§23.4)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  4-5-5 of this code.
8-9-10: REVOCATION OF LICENSE, CONTINUATION OF BUSINESS:
No person shall continue to use, exercise or carry on the business of a keeper
of a junk store or yard after the license provided for in section
8-9-2 of this chapter has been revoked. (1970 Code §23.13)
CHAPTER 10
LAUNDRY TRUCKS
SECTION:
8-10-1: License Required
8-10-2: Application For License, Fee
8-10-3: Vehicle Regulations
8-10-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any vehicle for the carrying
of laundry in the village where such laundry has either been picked up or is to
be delivered to any place in the village, unless a license for such vehicle is
first secured and the provisions of this code are fully complied with. (1970
Code §24.1)
8-10-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, FEE:
Application for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk, and shall
recite the name and address of the owner of the vehicle, and the name or names
of the person for whom such deliveries are made. The village clerk shall issue
such licenses if the provisions of this chapter and all other applicable
ordinances of the village are complied with. The annual fee shall be as
provided in section
3-1-5 of this code. (1970 Code §24.2)
8-10-3: VEHICLE REGULATIONS:
All such vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and it shall
be the duty of the duly authorized inspecting officer to periodically inspect
said vehicles. (1970 Code §24.3)
CHAPTER 11
LAUNDROMATS
SECTION:
8-11-1: Definition
8-11-2: License Required, Fee
8-11-3: Regulations
8-11-1: DEFINITION:
The word "laundromat" is defined to mean any place or building or portion
thereof having within such premises one or more automatic washing machines
which are rented, leased or hired out to any member of the public for a
consideration and for use upon the premises. (1970 Code §241/2.1)
8-11-2: LICENSE REQUIRED, FEE:
No person shall conduct, operate, maintain or carry on the business of a
laundromat as herein defined without first obtaining a license to do so and
paying the fee set forth in section
3-1-5 of this code. (1970 Code §241/2.2)
8-11-3: REGULATIONS:
All laundromats shall be equipped with adequate ventilation and lighting and
with flooring of impervious material. There shall be adequate sanitary,
plumbing and drainage facilities and the installation of all drains and
plumbing fixtures shall be in accordance with the requirements of village
ordinances. If any laundromat shall remain open between the hours of eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., there shall be an adult
attendant on duty during said hours. (1970 Code §241/2.3)
CHAPTER 12
DRY CLEANERS
SECTION:
8-12-1: Definition
8-12-2: License Required
8-12-3: Application For License, Approval
8-12-4: Issuance Of License, Fee
8-12-5: Posting License
8-12-6: Inspection Of Establishments
8-12-7: Frontage Consents
8-12-8: Health, Sanitation And Safety Regulations
8-12-9: Employees
8-12-10: Revocation Of License
8-12-1: DEFINITION:
