8-22-1: DEFINITIONS:
   ACT: Public act 95-17 of the Illinois general assembly, 410 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 82/1 et seq.
   BAR: An establishment that is devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages
for consumption by guests on the premises and that derives no more than ten
percent (10%) of its gross revenue from the sale of food consumed on the
premises. "Bar" includes, but is not limited to, taverns, nightclubs, cocktail
lounges, adult entertainment facilities, and cabarets.
   EMPLOYEE: A person who is employed by an employer in consideration for
direct or indirect monetary wages or profits, or a person who volunteers his or
her services for a nonprofit entity.
   EMPLOYER: A person, business, partnership, association, or corporation,
including a municipal corporation, trust, or nonprofit entity, that employs the
services of one or more individual persons.
   ENCLOSED AREA: All space between a floor and a ceiling that is enclosed or
partially enclosed with: a) solid walls or windows, exclusive of doorways, or
b) solid walls with partitions and no windows, exclusive of doorways, that
extend from the floor to the ceiling, including, without limitation, lobbies
and corridors. An enclosed area shall not include an "outdoor smoking
structure" as defined herein.
   ENCLOSED OR PARTIALLY ENCLOSED SPORTS ARENA: Any sports pavilion, stadium,
gymnasium, health spa, boxing arena, swimming pool, roller rink, ice rink,
bowling alley, or other similar place where members of the general public
assemble to engage in physical exercise or participate in athletic competitions
or recreational activities or to witness sports, cultural, recreational, or
other events.
   GAMING EQUIPMENT OR SUPPLIES: Gaming equipment/supplies as defined in the
Illinois gaming board rules of the Illinois administrative code.
   GAMING FACILITY: An establishment utilized primarily for the purposes of
gaming and where gaming equipment or supplies are operated for the purposes of
accruing business revenue.
   HEALTHCARE FACILITY: An office or institution providing care or treatment of
diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical,
physiological, or psychological conditions, including, but not limited to,
hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals, weight control clinics, nursing homes,
homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons,
chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, dentists, and all specialists
within these professions. "Healthcare facility" includes all waiting rooms,
hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within healthcare
facilities.
   OUTDOOR SMOKING STRUCTURE: Any structure that meets one of the following
criteria: a) the structure is completely open on one side; b) the structure has
two (2) or more walls where fifty five percent (55%) of the area between the
floor and ceiling is open; or c) the structure has no overhead covering. The
doors for entering and exiting an outdoor smoking structure shall remain closed
at all possible times.
   PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT: Any area under the control of a public or private
employer that employees are required to enter, leave, or pass through during
the course of employment, including, but not limited to, entrances and exits to
places of employment, including a minimum distance, as set forth in section
8-22-2 of this chapter, of fifteen feet (15') from entrances, exits, windows
that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is
prohibited; offices and work areas; restrooms; conference and classrooms;
breakrooms and cafeterias; and other common areas. A private residence or home
based business, unless used to provide licensed childcare, foster care, adult
care, or other similar social service care on the premises, is not a "place of
employment".
   PRIVATE CLUB: A not for profit association that: a) has been in active and
continuous existence since at least January 1, 2005, whether incorporated or
not, b) is the owner, lessee, or occupant of a building or portion thereof used
exclusively for club purposes at all times, c) is operated solely for a
recreational, fraternal, social, patriotic, political, benevolent, or athletic
purposes, but not for pecuniary gain, and d) only sells alcoholic beverages
incidental to its operation. For purposes of this definition, "private club"
means an organization that is managed by a board of directors, executive
committee, or similar body chosen by the members at an annual meeting, has
established bylaws, a constitution or both to govern its activities, and has
been granted an exemption from the payment of federal income tax as a club
under 26 USC 501.
   PRIVATE RESIDENCE: The part of a structure used as a dwelling, including,
without limitation: a private home, townhouse, condominium, apartment, mobile
home, vacation home, cabin, or cottage. For the purposes of this definition, a
hotel, motel, inn, resort, lodge, bed and breakfast or other similar public
accommodation, hospital, nursing home, or assisted living facility shall not be
considered a private residence.
   PUBLIC PLACE: That portion of any building or vehicle used by and open to
the public, regardless of whether the building or vehicle is owned in whole or
in part by private persons or entities, the state of Illinois, or any other
public entity and regardless of whether a fee is charged for admission,
including a minimum distance, as set forth in section
8-22-2 of this chapter, of fifteen feet (15') from entrances, exits, windows
that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is
prohibited. A "public place" does not include a private residence unless the
private residence is used to provide licensed childcare, foster care or other
similar social service care on the premises. A "public place" includes, but is
not limited to, hospitals, restaurants, retail stores, offices, commercial
establishments, elevators, indoor theaters, libraries, museums, concert halls,
public conveyances, educational facilities, nursing homes, auditoriums,
enclosed or partially enclosed sports arenas, meeting rooms, schools,
exhibition halls, convention facilities, polling places, private clubs, gaming
facilities, all government owned vehicles and facilities, including buildings
and vehicles owned, leased, or operated by the state or state subcontract,
healthcare facilities or clinics, enclosed shopping centers, retail service
establishments, financial institutions, education facilities, ticket areas,
public hearing facilities, public restrooms, waiting areas, lobbies, bars,
taverns, bowling alleys, skating rinks, reception areas, and no less than
seventy five percent (75%) of the sleeping quarters within a hotel, motel,
resort, inn, lodge, bed and breakfast, or other similar public accommodations
that are rented to guests, but excludes private residences.
   RESTAURANT:
   A.   An eating establishment, including, but not limited to, coffee shops,
cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, that
gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees, and
   B.   A kitchen or catering facility in which food is prepared on the
premises for serving elsewhere. "Restaurant" includes a bar area within the
restaurant.
   RETAIL TOBACCO STORE: A retail establishment that derives more than eighty
percent (80%) of its gross revenue from the sale of loose tobacco, plants, or
herbs and cigars, cigarettes, pipes, and other smoking devices for buying
tobacco and related smoking accessories and in which the sale of other products
is merely incidental. "Retail tobacco store" does not include a tobacco
department or section of a larger commercial establishment or any establishment
with any type of liquor, food, or restaurant license.
   SMOKE OR SMOKING: The carrying, smoking, burning, inhaling, or exhaling of
any kind of lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette, hookah, weed, herbs, or any other
lighted smoking equipment.
   VILLAGE: The village of Worth, Cook County, Illinois. (Ord. 12-21, 11-20-
2012)
8-22-2: SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES OF EMPLOYMENT AND GOVERNMENTAL VEHICLES
PROHIBITED:
No person shall smoke in a public place or in any place of employment or within
fifteen feet (15') of any entrance to a public place or place of employment. No
person may smoke in any vehicle owned, leased, or operated by the state or a
political subdivision of the state. Smoking is prohibited in indoor public
places and workplaces unless specifically exempted by section
8-22-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 09-25, 10-6-2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
8-22-3: POSTING OF SIGNS; REMOVAL OF ASHTRAYS:
   A.   "No Smoking" signs or the international "no smoking" symbol, consisting
of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle
with a red bar across it, shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in each
public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this
section by the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of that
place.
   B.   Each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited
by this section shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly
stating that smoking is prohibited.
   C.   All ashtrays shall be removed from any area where smoking is prohibited
by this section by the owner, operator, manager, or other person having control
of the area. (Ord. 09-25, 10-6-2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
8-22-4: DESIGNATION OF OTHER NONSMOKING AREAS:
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, any employer, owner,
occupant, lessee, operator, manager, or other person in control of any public
place or place of employment may designate a nonenclosed area of a public place
or place of employment, including outdoor areas, as an area where smoking is
also prohibited provided that such employer, owner, lessee or occupant shall
conspicuously post signs prohibiting smoking in the manner described in section
 8-22-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 09-25, 10-6-2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
8-22-5: EXEMPTIONS:
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, smoking is allowed in the
following areas:
   A.   Private residences or dwelling places, except when used as a childcare,
adult daycare, or healthcare facility or any other home based business open to
the public.
   B.   Private and semiprivate rooms in nursing homes and long term care
facilities that are occupied by one or more persons, all of whom are smokers
and have requested in writing to be placed or to remain in a room where smoking
is permitted and the smoke shall not infiltrate other areas of the nursing
home.
   C.   Hotel and motel sleeping rooms that are rented to guests and are
designated as smoking rooms, provided that all smoking rooms on the same floor
must be contiguous and smoke from these rooms must not infiltrate into
nonsmoking rooms or other areas where smoking is prohibited. Not more than
twenty five percent (25%) of the rooms rented to guests in a hotel or motel may
be designated a room where smoking is allowed. The status of rooms as smoking
or nonsmoking may not be changed, except to permanently add additional
nonsmoking rooms. (Ord. 09-25, 10-6-2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
   D.   Retail tobacco stores as defined in the smoke free Illinois act 1
that: 1) are located in freestanding structures occupied solely by a retail
tobacco store; and 2) do not allow smoke to migrate into an enclosed area where
smoking is prohibited. (Ord. 2014-42, 11-18-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. 410 ILCS 82/10.
8-22-6: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   The Worth police department shall enforce the provisions of this
chapter and may assess fines as set forth in the Village Fine Schedule.
   B.   Any person may register a complaint with the Worth police department
for a violation of this chapter. In addition any person may register a
complaint with the department of public health or a state certified local
public health department for a violation of the Smoke Free Illinois act, 410
Illinois Compiled Statutes 82/1 et seq. (Ord. 09-25, 10-6-2009, eff. 1-1-2010;
amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
8-22-7: VIOLATIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation, partnership,
association or other entity to fail to comply with this chapter. Each day that
a violation occurs is a separate violation.
   B.   A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited shall be
fined in an amount as set forth in the Village Fine Schedule.
   C.   A person who owns, operates or otherwise controls a public place or
place of employment who violates this chapter shall be fined as set forth in
the Village Fine Schedule and may also have their business license or liquor
license suspended or revoked pursuant to section
3-1-14 of this code. (Ord. 12-16, 10-25-2012; amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
8-22-8: INJUNCTIONS:
The village of Worth through its corporation counsel or any individual
personally affected by repeated violations may institute, in a circuit court,
an action to enjoin violations of this chapter or the act. (Ord. 09-25, 10-6-
2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
8-22-9: DISCRIMINATION PROHIBITED:
No individual may be discriminated against in any manner because of the
exercise of any rights afforded by this chapter or the act. (Ord. 09-25, 10-6-
2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
8-22-10: ENTRANCES, EXITS, WINDOWS, AND VENTILATION INTAKES:
Smoking is prohibited within a minimum distance of fifteen feet (15') from
entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an
enclosed area where smoking is prohibited under this chapter so as to ensure
that tobacco smoke does not enter the area through entrances, exits, open
windows, or other means. (Ord. 09-25, 10-6-2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
8-22-11: NONRETALIATION:
No person or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire or in any manner
retaliate against any employee, applicant for employment or customer because
that employer, applicant or customer reports a violation of this chapter. (Ord.
09-25, 10-6-2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
CHAPTER 23
DONATION AND RECYCLING BOXES
SECTION:
8-23-1: Definitions
8-23-2: Permits Required
8-23-3: Standards
8-23-4: Maintenance
8-23-5: Revocation Of Permit
8-23-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, whenever the following terms appear, they
shall have the following meaning unless a different meaning is clear from the
context:
   DONATION BOX: Any receptacle or container located outside of an enclosed
building designed, intended, or used for collection and storage of donated
items or materials.
   PAPER RECYCLING BOX: A donation box specifically designed for the collection
and temporary storage of paper products to be recycled. (Ord. 11-32, 12-6-2011)
8-23-2: PERMITS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person or business to place or allow to be placed
on their own property a donation box or paper recycling box within the village
of Worth without first making application and securing a permit from the
village.
An application and dimensioned site plan must be submitted for approval by the
village. In the event this application is being submitted by persons other than
the owner of the subject property, a letter of authorization from the property
owner must also accompany the application request. (Ord. 11-32, 12-6-2011)
8-23-3: STANDARDS:
A permit shall not be issued for a donation box or paper recycling box unless
donation boxes and paper recycling boxes demonstrate compliance with the
following standards:
   A.   May only be placed on commercial properties;
   B.   May only be permitted to public or private schools, churches, hospitals
and nonprofit charitable organizations;
   C.   Shall not be placed within a required parking space;
   D.   Shall not be placed within a required front or corner side yard, or
major arterial setback. To the extent feasible, donation boxes shall be placed
in the rear or side of a property so as to be inconspicuous as viewed from
public rights of way;
   E.   Shall not be placed in such a manner as to cause a sight obstruction
for pedestrians or motorists;
   F.   Only one donation box and one paper recycling box shall be permitted
per lot or per shopping center, office park or industrial park, whichever is
more restrictive;
   G.   Shall not exceed six feet (6') in height;
   H.   Shall not possess a footprint exceeding seventy five (75) square feet;
   I.   Shall be ten feet (10') away from the building; and
   J.   Shall contain the following contact information in two inch (2") type
visible from the front of the box: the name, address, e-mail, and phone number
of both the permittee and operator. (Ord. 11-32, 12-6-2011)
8-23-4: MAINTENANCE:
Donation boxes and paper recycling boxes shall be maintained in good condition
and appearance with no structural damage, holes, or visible rust, and shall be
free of graffiti. All boxes shall be free of debris and shall be serviced
regularly so as to prevent overflow of donations or the accumulation of junk,
debris or other material. (Ord. 11-32, 12-6-2011)
8-23-5: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
Any permit granted pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may be subject to
revocation for cause by the village, including, but not limited to, the failure
to comply with this chapter or any other applicable provisions of this code.
(Ord. 11-32, 12-6-2011)

CHAPTER 1
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
9-1-1: Fire Department Created
9-1-2: Appointment And Selection Of Department Members
9-1-3: Secretary-Treasurer Of Department
9-1-4: Firefighters' Pension Fund
9-1-5: Rules And Regulations
9-1-6: Mutual Aid Agreements
9-1-7: Illinois Fire Protection Training Act
9-1-8: General And Special Orders
9-1-9: Foreign Fire Insurance Company Fees Rate
9-1-10: Fire And Emergency Service Fee Schedule
9-1-1: FIRE DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created and established the Fire Department of the Village. The
Fire Department shall consist of a full time Fire Chief, twelve (12) full time
firefighter II/paramedics, part time paid firefighter/paramedics and such paid
on call volunteer firefighters, emergency medical technicians (EMTs) and
paramedics as may volunteer and qualify for service in the Fire Department. No
rank shall exist within the Fire Department other than full time firefighter
II/paramedics although additional compensated duties may be assigned to one
Emergency Medical Services Coordinator, three (3) Shift Commanders, and one
Director of the Fire Prevention Bureau 1 . (Ord. 07-03, 2-6-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  9-2-2B of this title.
9-1-2: APPOINTMENT AND SELECTION OF DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
   A.   Fire Chief: In accordance with the authority contained in 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-4, the Fire Chief shall be appointed by the Village
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 91-4, 4-
16-1991; amd. 1995 Code)
   B.   Full Time Firefighter II/Paramedics: The twelve (12) full time
firefighter II/paramedics shall be tested and hired by the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners of the Village in accordance with the rules of the Board
of Fire and Police Commissioners. (Ord. 91-4, 4-16-1991; amd. 1995 Code; Ord.
95-20, 8-15-1995; Ord. 97-2, 2-18-1997; Ord. 01-18, 8-7-2001)
   C.   Part Time Firefighter/Paramedics: The Village President shall hire part
time firefighter/paramedics with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. (Ord. 91-4, 4-16-1991; amd. 1995 Code)
9-1-3: SECRETARY-TREASURER OF DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Election: Members of the Fire Department shall elect a Secretary-
Treasurer of the Fire Department.
   B.   Bond: Before entering upon the duties of his office, the Secretary-
Treasurer of the Fire Department shall give bond in an amount equal to the
monies coming into his hands as Secretary-Treasurer to the Village. The bond
shall be approved by the Village President and conditioned upon the faithful
performance by the Secretary-Treasurer of his duties. (Ord. 91-4, 4-16-1991)
9-1-4: FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND:
   A.   Establishment: There is hereby established a Firefighters' Pension Fund
in and for the Village as provided by 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes, article
IV.
   B.   Board Of Trustees Of Fund:
      1.   Board Established: There is hereby established a Board of Trustees
to be known as the Board of Trustees of the Firefighters' Pension Fund.
      2.   Membership: The membership of the board shall be as provided in
article IV of the Pension Code, 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes.
      3.   Term Of Office: Each elected member of the Board of Trustees shall
hold office for a term of three (3) years and until his or her successor has
been duly elected and qualified. The election of the said Trustees shall be
held at such times and places as are required by law and in the manner required
by law.
      4.   Organization; Meetings: The said board shall be organized and shall
hold meetings as provided by State Statute.
      5.   Powers And Duties Of Board: The Board of Trustees of the fund shall
have all of the powers, duties and obligations conferred or imposed upon it by
the applicable State Statute.
   C.   Sources Of Funds: The Firefighters' Pension Fund shall consist of such
taxes, accumulations, assessments and deductions as are provided for by
Illinois State Statutes. (Ord. 86-13, 6-17-1986; amd. 1995 Code)
9-1-5: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The officers of the Fire Department shall adopt such rules and regulations with
respect to the management of the money to be paid to the Fire Department
Secretary-Treasurer, provided the rules and regulations do not conflict with
State Statutes, other Village ordinances, or the collective bargaining
agreement concerning full time firefighter II/paramedics of the Worth Fire
Department. The Secretary-Treasurer of the Fire Department shall file a copy of
all rules and regulations adopted with the Fire Chief and the Village Clerk
together with his certification as to the adoption and authenticity thereof.
The rules and regulations of the Fire Department shall provide for regular
meetings of the membership, the conduct of business at such meetings and the
expenditure of the foreign fire insurance company fees. (Ord. 91-4, 4-16-1991)
9-1-6: MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS:
The Village, by approval of the Village President and Board of Trustees, may
enter into mutual aid agreements with other municipalities and fire protection
districts pursuant to 5/11-6-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code 1 . (Ord. 91-4,
4-16-1991)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS.
9-1-7: ILLINOIS FIRE PROTECTION TRAINING ACT:
   A.   The Village hereby elects to participate in the training programs
provided for under the Illinois Fire Protection Training Act 1 .
   B.   Before an individual may commence regular full time employment as a
firefighter, he must have been certified by the Illinois State Fire Marshal as
a firefighter II, as having successfully completed an approved training course
as provided in said Act.
   C.   The firefighter II training must be completed by the trainee within his
probationary period of twelve (12) months, except for volunteers, part time and
paid on call personnel, as provided by rule of the Office of the State Fire
Marshal. (Ord. 82-32, 12-28-1982)
 
Notes
1 2. 50 ILCS 740/1 et seq.
9-1-8: GENERAL AND SPECIAL ORDERS:
   A.   The Fire Chief shall issue such general and special orders concerning
the management and operation of the Worth Fire Department as he deems
advisable, provided such general or special orders do not conflict with State
Statutes, other ordinances of the Village or any collective bargaining
agreement concerning full time firefighter II/paramedics. In the event of a
conflict between any rule or regulation of the Fire Department and the general
or special order issued by the Fire Chief, then the general or special order
shall prevail.
   B.   The general and special orders promulgated by the Fire Chief shall
provide for the discipline of all members of the Fire Department other than
full time firefighter II/paramedics, the qualifications of part time and paid
on call volunteers, the chain of command within the Fire Department, rules of
conduct and such other matters as he deems advisable for the effective and
efficient operation of the Fire Department. The discipline of full time
firefighter II/paramedics shall be exclusively within the jurisdiction of the
Worth Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. (Ord. 91-4, 4-16-1991)
9-1-9: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANY FEES RATE:
Every corporation, company and association which is not incorporated under the
laws of the State and which is engaged in effecting fire insurance in the
Village shall pay to the Village Treasurer two percent (2%) of the gross
receipts received from fire insurance upon property situated within the
Village, excluding marine insurance even though receipts therefrom include
insurance against fire. Said fees shall be received for the maintenance, use
and benefit of the Worth Fire Department. The Municipal Treasurer shall pay the
sums received from these insurance companies to the Secretary- Treasurer of the
Worth Fire Department. The Secretary- Treasurer of the Fire Department shall
pay out the money upon the order of the Worth Fire Department for the purposes
stated above. (Ord. 91-4, 4-16-1991)
9-1-10: FIRE AND EMERGENCY SERVICE FEE SCHEDULE:
   A.   Definitions: When used in this section, the following terms shall have
the following meanings:
   ADVANCED LIFE SUPPORT/MOBILE INTENSIVE CARE (ALS): An advanced level of pre-
hospital and inter-hospital emergency care that includes basic life support
functions, including cardiopulmonary resuscitation plus cardiac monitoring,
cardiac defibrillation, electrocardiography, administration of anti-arrhythmic
agents, intravenous therapy, administration of medications, drugs and
solutions, use of adjunctive medical devices, trauma care, and other authorized
techniques and procedures initiated for the treatment of real or potential
acute life threatening conditions under the direction of a physician licensed
to practice medicine in all of its branches or a registered professional nurse/
MICN or registered professional nurse/field RN and where authorized by the
Project Medical Director in an Illinois Department of Public Health approved
advanced life support system.
   AMBULANCE: Any publicly owned vehicle that is specifically designed,
constructed or modified and equipped and is intended to be used for, and is
maintained or operated for the emergency transportation of persons who are
sick, injured, wounded or otherwise incapacitated or helpless.
   BASIC LIFE SUPPORT SERVICES (BLS): The rendering of basic level of pre-
hospital and inter-hospital management, including, but not limited to, airway
management, cardiopulmonary resuscitation, control of shock and bleeding and
splinting of fractures, as outlined in a basic emergency care course approved
by the Illinois Department of Public Health.
   RESIDENT: Someone who permanently resides within the boundaries of the North
Palos Fire Protection District.
   USER: The person receiving ambulance, basic or advanced life support, mobile
intensive care services, or fire prevention services from the North Palos Fire
Protection District.
   B.   Emergency Medical Services Fee Schedule: A user shall pay the following
fees for the services listed below.
      1.   When emergency medical services are rendered by the North Palos Fire
Protection District to persons, businesses or other entities who are not
residents of the North Palos Fire Protection District, such persons, businesses
or other entities shall be assessed a fee of one thousand five hundred dollars
($1,500.00) for each BLS transport; one thousand eight hundred dollars
($1,800.00) for each ALS Level 1 transport; or two thousand three hundred
dollars ($2,300.00) for each ALS Level 2 transport and a fee of two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) for a response requiring treatment but no
transportation.
      2.   When emergency medical services are rendered by the North Palos Fire
Protection District to persons, businesses or other entities who are residents
of the North Palos Fire Protection District, such persons, businesses or other
entities shall be assessed a fee of one thousand two hundred dollars
($1,200.00) for each BLS transport; one thousand five hundred dollars
($1,500.00) for each ALS Level 1 transport; or two thousand dollars ($2,000.00)
for each ALS Level 2 transport and a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00)
for a response requiring treatment but no transportation.
      3.   In addition to the charges described in subsections B1 and B2 of
this section, the North Palos Fire Protection District shall also charge the
person, business or other entity receiving emergency medical services and/or
emergency ambulance service sixteen dollars ($16.00) for each mile a person is
transported by an ambulance to reimburse the North Palos Fire Protection
District for the cost and expense of fuel, oil and wear and tear on the
vehicle.
      4.   When the North Palos Fire Protection District responds to any
emergency service response involving persons, businesses, or other entities who
are non-residents of the North Palos Fire Protection District, the North Palos
Fire Protection District may charge the non-resident(s) up to two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00) per vehicle for district vehicles responding and up to
seventy dollars ($70.00) per hour per person for personnel responding as
provided in 70 Illinois Compiled Statutes 705/11f, and may charge for
extraordinary expenses of materials used in rendering such services.
      5.   When emergency medical services are rendered by the North Palos Fire
Protection District to persons, businesses or other entities who are residents
of the North Palos Fire Protection District, such persons, businesses or other
entities shall be billed for any additional charges which may exist once
payment has been received from the residents' health insurance provider.
Residents who are unable to pay for any portion of the fee for emergency
medical services shall have that portion waived.
When emergency medical services are rendered by the North Palos Fire Protection
District to persons, businesses or other entities who are not residents of the
North Palos Fire Protection District, such persons, businesses or other
entities shall be billed for any additional charges which may exist once
payment has been received from the residents' health insurance provider. Unpaid
balances shall be assigned to a debt collection agency of the North Palos Fire
Protection District's choice.
   C.   Fire Prevention Services Fee Schedule: A user shall pay the following
fees for the fire prevention services listed below.
      1.   Certificates Of Completion: All buildings within the Village shall
be required to have a certificate of completion permit in accordance with the
following:
         a.   A certificate of completion permit shall be required for new and
remodeled existing buildings of all use groups excluding detached one and two
family dwellings.
         b.   No certificate of completion permit shall be issued unless there
is conformance with the requirements of the North Palos Fire Protection
District's Fire Prevention Code and applicable laws.
         c.   Initial certificate fees shall be paid in accordance with the fee
schedule.
 
Certificate of completion fee $50.00
 
      2.   Compliance Inspections: The North Palos Fire Protection District
shall conduct periodic inspections of commercial buildings to ensure
compliance. There shall be no fee issued, unless any cited violations are not
brought into compliance by the second re-inspection.

   D.   Hazardous Materials (Spiller Pays) Discharge Schedule: The Village

District Ordinance 2017-03, titled "An Ordinance Revising the Hazardous

CHAPTER 2
FIRE PREVENTION CODE
SECTION:
9-2-1: Fire Prevention Code Adopted; Amendments
9-2-2: Bureau Of Fire Prevention
9-2-3: Duties Of Fire Chief
9-2-4: Duties Of Fire Inspectors
9-2-5: Life Safety Code
9-2-6: Motor Vehicle Routes For Transportation Of Explosives And Hazardous
Chemicals
9-2-7: Variances
9-2-8: Appeals
9-2-9: Conflicts
9-2-10: Enforcement
9-2-11: Violation Of Fire Prevention Code
9-2-1: FIRE PREVENTION CODE ADOPTED; AMENDMENTS:
The 2006 international fire code as published by the International Code
Council, Inc., is hereby adopted as the fire prevention code of the village
with the following changes, additions or insertions:
   Section 101.1, insert "village of Worth".
   Section 103.2, change to read "The code official is the fire chief."
   Section 105.1.1, add the following, "The code official shall establish a
schedule of permit fees which are required to be paid in conjunction with the
issuance of any required permit".
   Section 108, delete in full. All appeals shall be taken as provided in the
building code.
   Section 109.3, change the first sentence to read, "A penalty pursuant to the
Village Fine Schedule, Appendix A, is hereby imposed for each violation of this
code".
   Section 111.4, delete in full.
   Section 3204.3.1.1, add the following, "The code official shall establish
the limits in which storage is prohibited".
   Section 3404.2.9.5.2, add the following, "The code official shall establish
the limits in which storage is prohibited".
   Section 3406.2.4.4, add the following, "The code official shall establish
the limits in which storage is prohibited".
   Section 3804.2, add the following, "The code official shall establish the
limits in which storage is prohibited".
   Appendix B, Fire-Flow Requirements For Buildings, is hereby adopted.
   Appendix C, Fire Hydrant Locations And Distribution, is hereby adopted.
   Appendix D, Fire Apparatus Access Roads, is hereby adopted.
   Appendix E, Hazard Categories, is hereby adopted.
   Appendix F, Hazard Ranking, is hereby adopted.
   Appendix G, Cryogenic Fluids-- Weight And Volume Equivalents, is hereby
adopted.
In the event that the 2006 international fire code does not contain provisions
on an issue, then the provisions of the life safety code, as published by the
National Fire Protection Association shall govern unless waived by the code
official for due cause in hardship situations. (Ord. 07-21, 7-24-2007; amd.
Ord. 2014-16, 3-4-2014; Ord. 2025-10, 3-18-2025)
9-2-2: BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION:
   A.   Bureau Established: There is hereby established a bureau of fire
prevention which shall enforce all fire prevention ordinances adopted by the
village. Said ordinances shall be referred to as the fire prevention code of
the village. The bureau of fire prevention shall be under the direction and
supervision of the fire chief, and all fire inspection work of the bureau shall
be under his authority.
   B.   Director Of Bureau 1 :
      1.   Appointment And Term: The village president shall appoint a member
of the Worth fire department as director of the bureau of fire prevention. The
director's appointment shall be for one year from May 1 through April 30 of the
following year.
      2.   Duties:
         a.   The director and his assistants shall enforce all the fire laws
and regulations of the village and the state.
         b.   The director shall maintain reports of all inspections made
according to insurance services office (ISO) guidelines and shall submit a
written monthly report to the fire chief of the Worth fire department detailing
bureau activities.
         c.   The director shall maintain memberships in the basic national
fire prevention code of the Building Officials And Code Administrators
International, Inc. (BOCA) and the International Fire Inspectors' Association.
         d.   The director shall submit to the fire chief any requests for
additional fire inspectors or training for fire inspectors as may be necessary.
   C.   Annual Report: A report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made
annually on May 30 and transmitted to the chief executive officer of the
village; it shall contain all proceedings under this code, with such statistics
as the chief of the fire department may wish to include therein; the chief of
the fire department shall also recommend any amendments to the code which, in
his judgment, shall be desirable. (Ord. 87-14, 6-16-1987)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
   9-1-1 of this title.
9-2-3: DUTIES OF FIRE CHIEF:
   A.   The chief of the fire department shall:
      1.   Have the management and control of all matters and things pertaining
to the fire department, and all the officers, persons, members and volunteers
of the fire department shall be under the direction and supervision of the fire
chief.
      2.   Be responsible for having the cause, origin and circumstances of
every fire occurring in the village, investigated to determine whether such
fire was the result of carelessness or by design. Such investigation shall
begin as close to the occurrence of the fire as possible and not later than two
(2) days thereafter. The assigned person responsible for making such
investigation shall notify the chief of the fire department as soon as the
cause of the fire is determined.
      3.   Cause all fires to be investigated where the causes are undetermined
or wherein incendiarism is suspected and shall maintain a record of such
investigations and of the evidence in each case.
      4.   Be responsible for the keeping and the making of necessary reports
to the state fire marshal and shall aid and assist the state fire marshal in
any investigation the said marshal shall deem expedient or necessary to make.
      5.   Keep and maintain a proper record of all inspections made and a
summary of violations, together with a memorandum of the disposition of all
fire prevention violations found to exist.
      6.   Cause an inspection to be made at least annually of all fire
apparatus, equipment and firehouses and make his report and findings to the
president and village board in time for their consideration of the budget and
appropriation ordinance.
   B.   It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department or such other
members of the bureau of fire prevention assigned as a fire investigator to
determine the cause, origin and circumstances of all fires of suspicious
nature, fires where arson (incendiary nature) is suspected, fires where death
(s) occurred, fires where the cause(s) cannot be readily determined and to
other fires or fire related incidents as required.
   C.   The chief of the fire department may detail such members of the fire
department as inspectors as shall, from time to time, be necessary. The chief
of the fire department shall recommend to the president and the village board
of trustees the employment of technical inspectors. (Ord. 87-14, 6-16-1987)
9-2-4: DUTIES OF FIRE INSPECTORS:
   A.   Fire inspectors shall make annual inspections to determine the safety
of occupants in the event of fire, panic or accident and to ascertain whether
the fire prevention regulations of the village are being efficiently carried
out.
   B.   It shall be the duty of each fire inspector to faithfully and
completely perform each inspection assigned to him and to perform such other
duties as may be required by the fire chief. (Ord. 87-14, 6-16-1987)
9-2-5: LIFE SAFETY CODE:
The NFPA 101, life safety code, 2006 edition, as published by the National Fire
Protection Association is hereby adopted as the life safety code of the
village. (Ord. 07-21, 7-24-2007)
9-2-6: MOTOR VEHICLE ROUTES FOR TRANSPORTATION OF EXPLOSIVES AND HAZARDOUS
CHEMICALS:
   A.   The following routes for vehicles transporting explosives, blasting
agents, hazardous or other dangerous chemicals are hereby established as
follows:
      1.   Route 7 (Southwest Highway);
      2.   Route 43 (Harlem Avenue);
      3.   111th Street; and
      4.   Ridgeland Avenue.
   B.   There shall be no overnight parking of vehicles containing hazardous
chemicals, other dangerous chemicals, explosives, or blasting agents within the
limits of the village.
   C.   The fire department shall be notified of any vehicles transporting
hazardous chemicals, other dangerous chemicals, explosives or blasting agents
which incur mechanical breakdowns within the limits of the village. (Ord. 87-
14, 6-16-1987)
9-2-7: VARIANCES:
The chief of the fire department shall have the authority to grant a variance
from any of the provisions of the fire prevention code upon application, in
writing, by the owner or lessee or his duly authorized agent when there are
practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the fire
prevention code; provided, that the spirit of said code shall be observed,
public safety secured and substantial justice done. The particulars of such
variance, when granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of the fire
department thereon, shall be entered upon the records of the department and a
signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. (Ord. 87-14, 6-16-1987)
9-2-8: APPEALS:
Whenever the chief of the fire department shall disapprove an application for a
building permit, occupancy permit, electrical permit or business license or
refuse to grant a variance applied for or when it is claimed that the
provisions of the fire prevention code do not apply or that the true intent and
meaning of said code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the
applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief of the fire department to
the president and the village board of trustees within thirty (30) days from
the date of the decision appealed. (Ord. 87-14, 6-16-1987)
9-2-9: CONFLICTS:
In the event any ordinance or code of the village is found to be in conflict
with any portion of the fire prevention code, building code, the life safety
code or NFPA pamphlets 13 or 13A, the ordinances and codes of the village shall
be controlling. (Ord. 87-14, 6-16-1987; amd. Ord. 05-22, 6-7-2005, eff. 9-1-
2005)
9-2-10: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   The code enforcement officer shall be authorized to issue tickets for
violations of the fire prevention code.
   B.   The village attorney shall prosecute all violations of the fire
prevention code and take whatever legal measures are necessary to enforce the
fire prevention code of the village. (Ord. 87-14, 6-16-1987; amd. Ord. 2023-20,
6-6-2023)
9-2-11: VIOLATION OF FIRE PREVENTION CODE:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or the codes adopted
herein shall be fined the amount set forth in the Village Fine Schedule for
each violation. Each day a violation continues to exist shall constitute a
separate violation. The imposition of a fine hereunder shall not excuse the
violation or permit it to continue and all such violations shall be corrected
within a reasonable time. The application of the above penalty shall not be
held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. (Ord. 2014-16,
3-4-2014; amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
CHAPTER 3
PETROLEUM PRODUCTS
SECTION:
9-3-1: Bulk Storage, License Required
9-3-2: Application For License, Fee, Issuance
9-3-3: Inspections
9-3-4: Restrictions And Prohibitions
9-3-1: BULK STORAGE, LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall use any premises or structure in the village for the bulk
storage of gasoline or petroleum products without first having obtained a
license to do so; provided, however, that this chapter shall not apply to duly
licensed filling stations. (1970 Code §31.1)
9-3-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, FEE, ISSUANCE:
Any person desiring a license to use any premises or structure for the bulk
storage of gasoline shall make written application therefor, to the village
clerk in which shall be set forth the full name of the applicant and the
location at which such premises or structure is located. The application shall
be accompanied by the fee provided for in section
3-1-5 of this code. Such application shall be transmitted to the president and
shall be accompanied by evidence that the applicant, being an individual, or
the person in charge of the business, if a corporation, is a person of good
character and reputation, and that if the president shall be satisfied that
such person is of good character and reputation, and is suitable to be
entrusted with the management of such premises or structure in the village, and
after due inspection by the fire chief, the president shall cause the village
clerk to issue a license to such applicant upon the payment to the village
clerk of the proper fee. Every such application shall state the storage
capacity in gallons of the said structure or premises. (1970 Code §31.2)
9-3-3: INSPECTIONS:
The fire chief shall, from time to time, inspect or cause to be inspected any
such establishment for the purposes of ascertaining whether all applicable
ordinances of the village and the laws of the state are being complied with.
(1970 Code §31.6)
9-3-4: RESTRICTIONS AND PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Storage At Specified Location: Such license shall authorize the person
herein named to store gasoline at the place designated therein, and there only.
(1970 Code §31.3)
   B.   Location Restricted: No premises or structure shall be permitted to be
used for the bulk storage of gasoline that are located within two hundred feet
(200') of any school, hospital or theater. (1970 Code §31.5)
   C.   Smoking Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to permit
smoking in or about any premises or structure used for the bulk storage of
gasoline. (1970 Code §31.4)
CHAPTER 4
SERVICE STATIONS
SECTION:
9-4-1: Definition
9-4-2: License Required
9-4-3: Nonbusiness Filling Stations
9-4-4: Bulk Sales Prohibited
9-4-5: Care And Attendance
9-4-6: Fire Extinguishers Required
9-4-7: Reserved
9-4-8: Storage Underground, Limited
9-4-9: Requirements And Restrictions
9-4-1: DEFINITION:
   A.   A service station is a place of business where gasoline or any highly
volatile fuels for motor vehicles or internal combustion engines are sold or
offered for sale at retail, and dispensed into the fuel tanks of such motor
vehicles.
   B.   This definition shall include also a private storage tank and
dispensing of such products for the same purposes as those served by a service
station, whether the storage is maintained for the use and benefit of the
owner, lessee, agents or employees of either, or of any other.
   C.   The requirements covering service stations shall also govern
underground storage maintained at general storage plants and places other than
service stations, so far as applicable. (1970 Code §19.19)
9-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a service station in
the village without first having obtained a license therefor. No such license
shall be issued unless the location and equipment to be used fully comply with
the ordinances of the village 1 . (1970 Code §19.18)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-5 of this code.
9-4-3: NONBUSINESS FILLING STATIONS:
Any person maintaining or operating any storage tank for gasoline for the use
of automobiles for the owner, lessees, employees or agents of such person shall
comply with all of the provisions of this chapter other than the requirement
for the payment of a license fee. (1970 Code §19.20)
9-4-4: BULK SALES PROHIBITED:
No motor fuel shall be dispensed at any service station except into the fuel
tank of motor vehicles, when such tanks are connected with the carburetion
system of such vehicles; provided, however, that individual sales up to five
(5) gallons may be made in metal receptacles when painted red and labeled in
full conformity with the ordinances of the village, such individual sales to be
limited to five (5) gallons to any one person. (1970 Code §19.21)
9-4-5: CARE AND ATTENDANCE:
   A.   No motor vehicle fuel tank shall be serviced until the motor and
ignition has been shut off.
   B.   No open lights or flames shall be permitted except within a stove
within the station building.
   C.   No smoking shall be permitted on the premises at any time.
   D.   Premises must be kept neat and clean, free from rubbish and trash.
   E.   Cleaning with gasoline, naphtha or other highly flammable liquids of
classes I and II shall not be permitted in or around service stations.
   F.   Underground tanks which develop leaks or which are permanently
discontinued in service shall be removed promptly or shall be filled with sand.
The sand is to be flushed in with water until a complete sand fill is secured.
(1970 Code §19.37)
9-4-6: FIRE EXTINGUISHERS REQUIRED:
Each service station shall be equipped with at least one chemical fire
extinguisher suitable for oil or gasoline fires. (1970 Code §19.38)
9-4-7: RESERVED:
(Ord. 05-69, 12-6-2005)
9-4-8: STORAGE UNDERGROUND, LIMITED:
   A.   Service station storage shall be underground and the combined capacity
of the storage tanks of class I and class II flammable liquids shall not exceed
twenty thousand (20,000) gallons.
   B.   Class III flammable liquids storage, at service stations, shall be
underground and shall not exceed twenty thousand (20,000) gallons.
   C.   Underground fuel oil tank connected to the station heater and
underground tank for receiving crankcase drainage need not be counted in
computing the combined capacity. (1970 Code §19.22)
9-4-9: REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Setting Of Tanks:
      1.   Where tanks are not subject to being driven over, they shall be
buried so that their tops will be not less than two feet (2') below the surface
of the ground or beneath twelve inches (12") of earth and a slab of reinforced
concrete not less than four inches (4") in thickness; slab shall be set on a
firm, well tamped earth foundation and shall extend at least one foot (1')
beyond the outline of the tank in all directions. (1970 Code §19.23)
      2.   Where tank site is subject to traffic by heavy vehicles, the total
coverage above the top of the tank shall be not less than three feet (3');
provided, however, that where the area over tanks is paved with not less than
six inches (6") in thickness, the total coverage may be reduced to two feet
(2'). (1970 Code §19.23; amd. 1995 Code)
      3.   Where necessary to prevent floating, tanks shall be securely
anchored or weighted.
      4.   Tanks shall be set on a firm foundation and surrounded with earth or
sand well tamped in place.
      5.   Tops of tanks shall be below the level of any piping to which tanks
may be connected.
      6.   Tanks shall not be installed under any building or structure. (1970
Code §19.23)
   B.   Clearance Required:
      1.   To Basement And The Like: Individual tanks of a capacity up to two
thousand (2,000) gallons shall be buried so that tops of tanks shall be lower
than all floors, basements, cellars or pits of buildings within ten feet (10')
thereto, on or off the property, or tanks shall maintain a clearance of ten
feet (10') thereto. For individual tanks of a capacity of more than two
thousand (2,000) gallons and up to six thousand (6,000) gallons, this distance
shall be twenty feet (20'). For individual tanks with a capacity of more than
six thousand (6,000) and up to twenty thousand (20,000) gallons, twenty five
feet (25').
      2.   To Sewer And The Like: Individual tanks of a capacity up to two
thousand (2,000) gallons shall be buried so that the tops of tanks shall be
lower than the bottom level of all sewers, manholes, catch basins, cesspools,
septic tanks, wells or cisterns within ten feet (10') on or off the property,
or tanks shall maintain a full clearance of ten feet (10') thereto. For
individual tanks with a capacity of more than two thousand (2,000) gallons and
up to six thousand (6,000) gallons, this distance shall be twenty feet (20').
For individual tanks of a capacity of more than six thousand (6,000) gallons
and up to twenty thousand (20,000) gallons, this distance shall be twenty five
feet (25'). The term "sewer" includes sewer line out of station building;
provided, however, that these clearances shall not be required to a sewer line
out of service station if such sewer line is constructed throughout of cast
iron with leaded joints.
      3.   To Property Lines: Individual tanks of a capacity up to two thousand
(2,000) gallons shall maintain a ten foot (10') clearance to property lines.
For individual tanks of a capacity of more than two thousand (2,000) gallons
and up to six thousand (6,000) gallons, this distance shall be twenty feet
(20'). For individual tanks of a capacity of more than six thousand (6,000)
gallons and up to twenty thousand (20,000) gallons, this distance shall be
twenty five feet (25'); provided, however, that these clearances on the side
adjacent to a public street, alley or highway may be waived by consent of the
authorities having immediate jurisdiction over the public street, alley or
highway, if it can be shown that the required sewer clearances can be
maintained.
      4.   To Special Classes Of Property: Tanks and pumps shall maintain a
clearance of not less than eighty five feet (85') to any schoolhouse, hospital
or church. The distance shall be measured from the nearest point of tanks and
pumps to the nearest point of buildings. (1970 Code §19.24)
   C.   Material And Construction Of Tanks: Tanks shall bear label of
Underwriters' Laboratories or meet equivalent specifications.
      1.   Tanks shall be thoroughly coated on the outside with tar, asphaltum
or other suitable rust-resistant material.
      2.   Tanks shall not be surrounded or covered by cinders or other
material of corrosive effect. If the soil contains corrosive material, special
protection must be provided. (1970 Code §19.25)
   D.   Venting Of Tanks: Each tank shall be provided with a vent pipe,
connected with the top of the tank and carried up to the outer air. The pipe
shall be arranged for proper drainage to the storage tank and its lower end
shall not extend through the top of the tank for a distance of more than one
inch (1"); it shall have no traps or pockets.
      1.   The upper end of the pipe shall be provided with a gooseneck or T
attachment or weatherproof hood.
      2.   The vent pipe shall be of sufficient cross-sectional area to permit
escape of air and gas during the filling operation and in no case less than one
inch (1") in diameter. If a power pump is used in filling the storage tank, and
a tight connection is made to the fill pipe, the vent pipe shall not be smaller
than the fill pipe.
      3.   The vent pipe shall terminate outside of a building not less than
twelve feet (12') above the top of the fill pipe, and not less than four feet
(4'), measuring vertically and horizontally, from any window or other building
opening, and not less than fifteen feet (15') measured horizontally from any
opening into the basement, cellar or pit of any building, and in a location
which will not permit pocketing of gas. If a tight connection is made in the
filling line, the terminus of the vent pipe shall be carried to a point one
foot (1') above the level of the highest reservoir from which the tank may be
filled.
      4.   The vent pipes from two (2) or more tanks of the same class of
liquid may be connected to one upright or main header; area of the header shall
equal the combined area of the pipes connected to it. Connection of the header
shall be not less than one foot (1') above the level of the top of the highest
reservoir from which the tank may be filled. (1970 Code §19.26)
   E.   Fill Pipes: Fill pipes shall be carried to a location outside of any
building, as remote as possible from any doorway or other opening into any
building and in no case closer than five feet (5') from any such opening.
      1.   Location shall be in a place where there is a minimum danger of
breakage from trucks or other vehicles.
      2.   Each fill pipe shall be closed by a screw cap or other tight-fitting
cap, preferably of a type which can be locked. The cap should be locked at all
times when filling or gauging process is not going on. (1970 Code §19.27)
   F.   Unloading Operations: The unloading hose from the tank truck into an
underground tank shall be metallic lined or its equivalent and shall be
equipped with a nonferrous nozzle or tight connection metal nipple.
      1.   During unloading operations a competent person shall be present and
in charge at all times.
      2.   If an underground tank is supplied through a permanent pipe
connection to an aboveground general storage tank, the filling process may be
by a power-driven pump or gravity. In addition to valves at aboveground tanks,
a valve shall be installed within the control of service station personnel.
(1970 Code §19.28)
   G.   Pumps: Class I and II flammable liquids shall be transferred from
underground tanks by means of fixed pumps so designed and equipped as to allow
control of the flow and to prevent leakage or accidental discharge.
Supplemental means shall be provided outside of the dispensing device whereby
the source of power may be readily disconnected in the event of fire or other
accident. Dispensing devices for Class I or Class II flammable liquids shall be
of an approved type. Liquids shall be withdrawn from tanks by means of approved
pumps equipped with metallic lined hose and nonferrous discharge nozzle.
      1.   No pump shall be located within a building.
      2.   Curb pumps or pumps located in any portion of a public street are
prohibited.
      3.   Wiring of electric pumps and all electrical equipment in connection
therewith shall conform to article 500 of the 1956 edition of the National
Electrical Code, NFPA Pamphlet No. 70, published by the National Fire
Protection Association.
      4.   Devices which discharge by gravity shall be so designed that it is
impossible to retain in the gauging compartment materially more than ten (10)
gallons of liquid, and so that it is not possible to lock the device without
draining the liquid.
      5.   Systems which employ continuous air pressure on storage tanks in
connection with gauging or venting devices are prohibited.
      6.   The use of aboveground storage tanks in connection with gauging or
venting devices is prohibited.
      7.   Setback of pump islands from street lines and drive-in arrangements
are subject to approval of the authorities having jurisdiction over the street,
highway or road. (1970 Code §19.29)
   H.   Piping: Piping shall conform to the requirements set out in the rules
under general storage in the fire prevention code. (1970 Code §19.30)
   I.   Building: No basement or excavation shall be permitted under any
service station building.
      1.   Floor level shall be above grade so as to prevent the flow of
liquids or vapors into the building.
      2.   Floors shall be of concrete. (1970 Code §19.31)
   J.   No Inflammable Liquids Within Building, Exception:
      1.   No gasoline, naphtha or other liquids of Class I, as defined in the
fire prevention code, shall be kept inside of a service station.
      2.   No alcohol or other flammable antifreeze solution shall be kept
inside a service station except in the original sealed container. No transfer
of such liquids from these receptacles shall be made inside the service
station. (1970 Code §19.32)
   K.   Heating Systems: Heating systems in service stations that have rooms or
stalls for greasing or servicing motor vehicles shall be of a type that will
preclude the likelihood of gasoline gas reaching the heaters. The following
types are acceptable:
      1.   Steam, hot water or warm air furnaces, cut off from the balance of
the building by eight inch (8") masonry walls are acceptable. The ceiling shall
be of two (2) coats of cement plaster over metal lath or equivalent fire-
resistive construction. The door to a heater room shall open from the outside
of the building. No opening shall be permitted on the inside walls except those
necessary for passage of heat ducts. If warm air heat is used, no cold air
return shall be taken closer than thirty inches (30") from the level of the
grease room floor.
In the heater room, the door may open from the office room, where the heater
room door is sufficiently distant from the grease room door to prohibit the
travel of gasoline gas to the heater room. The floor of the office must be
higher than the floor of the grease room, or a six inch (6") concrete ledge
must be placed across the door opening at the floor in the grease room door or
furnace room door, or both, as gasoline gas is heavier than air and these
features will tend to block its flow.
      2.   The following types of heat are acceptable without enclosure:
         a.   Suspended, approved type, oil or gas fired, warm-air furnaces.
These shall be suspended from the ceiling joists and shall be approximately
eight feet (8') above the level of the grease room floor. Cold air returns
shall be not less than thirty inches (30") from the level of the grease room
floor.
         b.   Gas or oil fired unit heaters shall be mounted eight feet (8')
above the level of the grease room floor.
         c.   Electric heating units and equipment located within the possible
path of vapor travel shall be designed and installed so as not to create an
ignition hazard and shall conform with the 1956 edition of the National
Electrical Code, NFPA Pamphlet No. 70, as published by the National Fire
Protection Association.
         d.   In single stall stations, a stove may be used, if mounted
eighteen inches (18") above the floor. Oil heat is required for such stove.
         e.   Stoves may be used in the office section if they are cut off by
partitions from the grease room and the stoves are mounted above the floor
level. (1970 Code §19.33)
   L.   Greasing Pits: Every greasing pit installed in a building or enclosed
by three (3) or more walls, shall be ventilated by a vent duct not less than
six inches (6") in diameter or equivalent cross-sectional area of a noncircular
duct if used. The duct shall start within four inches (4") of the floor and
shall extend on an upward diagonal or by an easy bend over to the sidewall,
thence straight up through the roof to a height sufficient to draw off gasoline
vapors which may accumulate at the bottom of the pit. The floor or pit should
slope slightly toward a corner where a duct is located to facilitate the flow
of gases to said duct.
      1.   Gasoline or naphtha shall never be used to clean out any pit,
whether the pit is located within a building or enclosure, or outside in the
open.
      2.   No sewer connection shall be permitted from any greasing pit, unless
protected with an approved grease trap which will effectively intercept greases
and oils and prevent their entry into the sewer. The trap shall be kept cleaned
out.
      3.   If electrically lighted, globes shall be of vapor-proof construction
and wiring shall be in conduit. (1970 Code §19.34)
   M.   Washing And Greasing Rooms: If sewer connection is made, an adequate
grease trap shall be provided to intercept grease and oils. The trap shall be
cleaned out at least every thirty (30) days. (1970 Code §19.35)
CHAPTER 5
OPEN BURNING 1
SECTION:
9-5-1: Restrictions
9-5-2: Open Burning
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  8-6-7 of this code.
9-5-1: RESTRICTIONS:
No person shall burn or set fire to, or allow to be burned or set fire to, any
combustible material whatsoever out of doors within the village. However, it
shall be lawful to:
   A.   Burn fires to cook food outdoors in devices designed for that purpose.
   B.   Burn clean, dry, non-painted or non-treated wood in an outdoor wood
burning device, sold and marketed specifically for outdoor residential use, of
no more than three (3) cubic feet in capacity, which has been certified as safe
and efficient by a nationally recognized agency in the business of certifying
such devices, under the following conditions:
      1.   No such fire may be burned during an ozone alert covering the
village of Worth declared by the environmental protection agency or similar
authority;
      2.   No such fire may be burned when the last reported outdoor
temperature at Midway Airport is ninety degrees Fahrenheit (90°F) or higher;
and
      3.   The fire may not be burned between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:
00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
   C.   The fires listed in subsections A and B of this section must be
continuously monitored by a responsible adult present in the immediate vicinity
of the fire. Such person must situate the fire so as to minimize the escape of
smoke, fumes or noxious gases onto neighboring properties in such quantities as
to create a nuisance or to endanger or injure the health of any person. (Ord.
01-28, 10-16-2001; amd. Ord. 2024-24, 4-16-2024)
9-5-2: OPEN BURNING:
Any person who shall be convicted of violating any provision of this chapter
shall be fined the amount set forth in the Village Fine Schedule for each
offense. Each day of burning in violation of this chapter shall be deemed a
separate offense. (Ord. 2014-16, 3-4-2014; amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025))
CHAPTER 6
FIREWOOD STORAGE
SECTION:
9-6-1: Definitions
9-6-2: Regulations For Firewood Storage
9-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms are defined in this section:
   FIREWOOD: Any wood or wood product intended to be burned for the purpose of
generating heat or for any other purpose, including for aesthetic reasons.
(Ord. 07-06, 2-20-2007, eff. 5-1-2007)
9-6-2: REGULATIONS FOR FIREWOOD STORAGE:
   A.   Firewood may be stored outdoors, but within the boundaries of any side
or rear yard of a structure. Firewood shall not be stored in the front yard of
any building.
   B.   Firewood shall be cut or split and stored in a neat stack. The stack
shall be secure so that the firewood does not pose a health and safety risk
during heavy rains or strong winds. Firewood shall be stacked on a well
supported, nonrotting base or rack that is not less than eight inches (8") tall
so that the firewood is at least eight inches (8") above the ground.
   C.   Unless a particular location is engaged in the business of selling
firewood to the general public and is licensed to do so, all firewood stored
upon a particular location shall be for use solely at that location by its
occupants and shall not be stored for the purpose of resale.
   D.   Firewood shall not be stored outside in an area designated as being
within the floodplain. (Ord. 07-06, 2-20-2007, eff. 5-1-2007; amd. Ord. 2025-
11, 3-18-2025)
CHAPTER 7
FIREWORKS
SECTION:
9-7-1: Definitions
9-7-2: Restrictions
9-7-3: Violations Of Fireworks Restrictions
9-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms are defined in this section:
   FIREWORKS: Any explosive composition or any substance or combination of
substances, or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or
audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by explosion, combustion,
deflagration, or detonation, and shall include blank cartridges, toy cannons in
which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath
to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, roman candles, bombs
or other fireworks of like construction and any fireworks containing any
explosive compound; or any tablets or other device containing any explosive
substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual effects. The
term "fireworks" shall not include snake or glowworm pellets; smoke devices;
sparklers; trick noisemakers known as "party poppers", "booby traps",
"snappers", "trick matches", "cigarette loads" and "auto burglar alarms"; toy
pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper or plastic caps
containing twenty five hundredths (0.25) grain or less of explosive compound
are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact
with the cap when in place for the explosion; and toy pistol paper or plastic
caps which contain less than twenty five hundredths (0.25) grain of explosive
mixture; the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times. (Ord. 11-
19, 9-20-2011)
9-7-2: RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly possess, offer for sale,
expose for sale, sell at retail, or use or explode any fireworks. It shall be
unlawful for any person to sell or use sparklers on public property. (Ord. 11-
19, 9-20-2011)
9-7-3: VIOLATIONS OF FIREWORKS RESTRICTIONS:
Any person who shall be convicted of violating any provision of this chapter
shall be fined the amount set forth in the Village Fine Schedule for each
offense. Each day of violation of this chapter shall be deemed a separate
offense. Proceedings to enforce violations of this chapter may be initiated and
conducted in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of this code
providing for administrative adjudication of code violations or by any other
means provided by law. (Ord. 2014-16, 3-4-2014; amd. Ord. 2025-11, 3-18-2025)
